fields.headline: Sparta Prague 0 - 1 Arsenal
fields.standfirst: Match report
fields.trailText: Sparta Prague: 1-Tomas Postulka; 2-Zdenek Grygera, 6-Zdenek Svoboda, 8-Jiri Novotny, 9-Marek Kincl, 11-Josef Obajdin, 13-Rene Bolf, 17-Pavel Novotny, 23-Petr Papousek, 25-Tomas Rosicky, 27-Radek Mlynar.
fields.body:
Sparta Prague: 1-Tomas Postulka; 2-Zdenek Grygera, 6-Zdenek Svoboda, 8-Jiri Novotny, 9-Marek Kincl, 11-Josef Obajdin, 13-Rene Bolf, 17-Pavel Novotny, 23-Petr Papousek, 25-Tomas Rosicky, 27-Radek Mlynar.

Arsenal: 1-David Seaman; 2-Lee Dixon, 5-Martin Keown, 22-Oleh Luzhnyi, 16-Silvinho; 4-Patrick Vieira, 7-Robert Pires, 8-Fredrik Ljungberg, 18-Gilles Grimandi; 25-Kanu, 14-Thierry Henry.

Referee: Gilles Veissiere (France).

1 Sparta Prague kick-off with a roar from their home support.
3 Both teams grapple for possession. Keown chops down Obajdin on the halfway line and is lucky to escape without a booking.
5 Arsenal gain a corner but the tall Czech defenders clear the danger.
7 Sparta Prague string a series of crisp passes together in the Arsenal half. The partnership between the pacey Obajdin and the tricky Rosicky flusters the Arsenal backline.
11 Sparta Prague carve out the game's first chance with a long-range effort from Marek Kincl that flies a few feet over the bar.
13 Another sweeping counter-attack from Sparta Prague. But they are caught offside when trying drop in behind the Arsenal backline.
15 Tomas Rosicky, the 19-year-old Czech tipped for the top, looks bright breaking forward from the midfield but his progress is halted by a full-blooded challenge from Grimandi.
16 Arsenal win a free kick 35 yards out. But Henry's effort is easily collected by the Tinas Postulka, the Sparta Prague keeper.
20 The clearest chance of the game so far comes when Henry sneaks in front of the Sparta Prague defence to meet Dixon's cross but his glancing head flashes wide.
23 Arsenal begin to raise their game, concentrating their efforts down the left flank with Silvinho, Pires and Ljungberg combining well.
24 Sparta Prage gain a free-kick near the Arsenal corner flag. But the cross lacks precision and is easily dealt with by the Gunners.
26 Zdnek Grygera scampers away from Dixon, leaving the ageing Arsenal full back in his wake. He gains a corner when his cross cannons over the goal-line.
28Coiffed keeper David Seaman remains unflustered by a series of Sparta Prague corners.
30 Grygera again breaks down the left side of the Arsenal defence and gets a good cross in. Seaman does well to save the resulting header from Novotny. Arsenal look rattled by the sustained Czech pressure.
33 GOAL Silvinho collects the ball on the left side of the penalty area. He shows remarkable balance to cut inside, skip past the flailing lunges of Sparta defenders, and chip a ball past the advancing 'keeper. North London holds its breath as the ball trickles off the post and over the line.
37 Sparta Prague regroup and tentaively begin piecing together moves on the right flank. The resulting attack earns them a free-kick near the corner. Despite a decent delivery, Arsenal are first to the ball and hoof it out of danger.
43 Arsenal, looking increasingly composed in midfield, break through devastating agility of Silvinho. The Brazilian, whose fitness belies his pre-match injury worries, plays in the overlapping Pires, but the Frenchman's cross is too heavy for Henry, loitering in the penalty box. Half-time.

46 Early pressure from Sparta Prague results in a corner to the home team. Though the set play is dealt with comfortably, the Czechs look to be getting closer to the target.
51 A sweeping attacking move from Sparta Prague. But Marek Kincl fails to connect with a deep cross as he is hustled, harried, tumbled and stamped on by Keown, a man who redefines style and grace. Kincl's subsequent penalty pleas fail to impress the referee.
55 Arsenal show patience in their build up play. They try to slow the game's tempo with a series of simple passes. However, their spell of posession ends after the calm passage of play seemingly unnerves Keown, who then launches it to nobody in particular.
57 Sparta Prague's best moment of the match so far. The Czechs charge forward through the middle of the park. The ball is delicately worked from left to right but the Mynar's resulting shot on goal hits the outside netting.
62 Substituion Siegl on for Kincl
66 Sparta Prague look to be running out of ideas as the tactical superiority of the Arsenal starts to become apparent.
68 Arsenal win a corner. But Silvinho's cross, as has been the case with the majority of the game's dead ball situations, is woeful.
72 An alert Henry latches on to a mistake by a Sparta Prague defender. He wins a throw in deep inside the opposition area. But Ljungberg gives the ball away cheaply.
77 Substitution Wiltord on for Henry
78 A flying run down the left wing from the Prague's prodigal playmaker Rosicky leaves Vieira and then Dixon eating dust. But, rapidly running out of steam, his pass is to weak for any of his teammates to collect.
79 Substitution Mynar on for Papousek
80 Substitution Vivas on for Ljungberg
84 Sparta Prague carve open a half-chance. But Obajdin fires over from a tight angle.
85 Substitution Flachbart on for Mynar
87 The Czech's kick and throw the ball as far as they can into the opposition half at every opportunity. Their desperate measures fail to dent Arsenal's steely determination to contain their opponents.
90 Fulltime Arsenal make a positive first step in Europe.

fields.headline: Hard core tunesmith
fields.standfirst:
Andy Sheppard
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
Andy Sheppard
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating:****
fields.body:
Andy Sheppard's live programme is a shrewdly accessible balance of oppositional forces: most dramatically rugged improv set against graceful, movie-score worldbeat themes. But its secret is that it doesn't sound calculating or manipulative. Like a British Pat Metheny, he is a formidable and fearless jazz improviser and a classy contemporary Tin Pan Alley tunesmith rolled into one.

The result of this chemistry has been that Sheppard, at a boyish 43, and with one of the biggest regular followings for a UK jazz musician, has kept the jazz hardcore and added a steady flow of passing trade who like his catchy themes and lazily stretching African and Caribbean grooves. If he drops into squalling jazz free fall every now and again, it's with the teasing promise that you'll catch one of his graceful, softly whistling tunes creeping back in sooner or later if you keep your ears pinned back.

Sheppard has been at the Pizza Express for a full-house, five-night run - the curtain-raiser to a week-long showcase by the adventurous indie label he records for (composer Colin Towns's Provocateur). The saxophonist's repertoire is largely drawn from his two latest CDs, Learning to Wave and Dancing Man and Woman, but Sunday's show was a powerful blend of hard-driving ensemble spontaneity and the cool set-pieces of the compositions, with little of Sheppard's occasional tendency to preoccupied, water-treading doodlings. The presence of a deputy keyboard player in Spencer Cousins (covering for the formidable Steve Lodder) also kept down the vaporous synth textures that sometimes give Sheppard shows a somnambulent air.

The sensuous sway of Natural brought an animatedly conversational guitar/sax duet between Sheppard and John Parricelli (as if in subconscious tribute to Steely Dan, who were playing the same night, the two suggested some of that band's loose, singing, jazz-rock feel). Sheppard recalled the brooding, restrained heat of the Argentinian Gato Barbieri in the Mediterranean shimmer of Sugar Beach Hotel. Dancing Man and Woman turned from lyrical folksiness to a kind of manic rumba under pressure from the ingenious Paul Clarvis's percussion - a typical Sheppard counterweight to the spiky free jazz of Looking for Ornette.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Scorn for euro ministers
fields.standfirst:
'If it's so good why don't they buy it' message from traders as currency suffers worst day yet
Money Unlimited
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Traders yesterday scorned attempts during the weekend by European finance ministers to talk up the beleaguered euro, daring policymakers to back their words with intervention by driving the single currency to fresh lows against the American dollar.
fields.body:
Traders yesterday scorned attempts during the weekend by European finance ministers to talk up the beleaguered euro, daring policymakers to back their words with intervention by driving the single currency to fresh lows against the American dollar.

Brushing aside a joint statement by the finance ministers of the 11 eurozone countries that said the euro's present weakness did not reflect the strength of the European economy, traders dumped the currency, sending it plunging to a new low of 85.67 cents against the dollar in early trading. It recovered some ground during the day to close in London at just above 86 cents.

Analysts said the markets had been disappointed that the statement made no reference to intervening in the market in order to prop up the euro - after veiled hints by ministers ahead of Friday's meeting that they were considering taking action.

"If they think the currency is that good, why don't they buy it?" said Graham Cocks, manager of corporate treasury at Mellon Bank. Nick Parsons, currency strategist at Commerzbank, said the threat of intervention was "irrelevant" unless it was backed up with action. "They have got a very difficult job which they are handling very badly," Mr Parsons added.

Bank of England governor Eddie George, speaking on behalf of central bankers from the industrialised nations, yesterday reiterated the message of the Eurozone finance ministers that the euro was undervalued, but he sidestepped questions about whether intervention was on the cards.

Mr George said: "In the euro zone, where I think everybody feels the euro is kind of out of line with the fundamental influences,I think the expecta tion is that the euro will at some point bottom and tend to strengthen, because the expected growth in the euro zone is really very encouraging."

But his message was contradicted by a report from the International Monetary Fund report which said the success of the US economy in attracting inward investment was driving the dollar's strength, and it was hard to see when the US currency would fall.

Euro supporters have been pinning their hopes on the ballooning trade gap in the US sparking a fall in the dollar, but the IMF said that as long as capital inflows were plugging the current account deficit there was no reason for the dollar to weaken.

Analysts said the market reaction yesterday amounted to a kick in the teeth for the finance ministers' efforts and that negative views about the euro were so widely entrenched that intervention could be the only way of saving the euro from further falls.

"I can't see what will stop the euro falling unless the European Central Bank intervenes," said Keith Lewis, manager of treasury markets business at American Express Bank in London.

"The problem is that the negative psychology on the euro is itself becoming a fundamental factor, and they need to do something to reverse that," said Mr Parsons at Commerzbank. "I think they should intervene but fear they won't."

UK firms are absorbing higher oil costs rather than passing them on to consumers, government figures show. Raw material and fuel costs rose by 0.6% in August, but despite higher input costs factories cut the price of goods at the factory gate by 0.3%. It is the first fall in output prices in more than a year.

webTitle: Pop review:  Neko Case and Her Boyfriends

fields.headline: Neko Case and Her Boyfriends
fields.standfirst:
Union Chapel, London
***
fields.trailText:
Union Chapel, London
***
fields.body:
Neko Case and Her Boyfriends are making their UK debut in a house of God. But a blast of feedback brings them down to earth. "What the fuck is that?" asks Case in an exasperated voice. Probably not the best way to assure a place in heaven, but then Case doesn't pretend to be holy. An ex-punk drummer who realised her heart was a lot more country, a little less rock'n'roll, she has looked back to the good ol' days when Loretta Lynn made it hip to be a country chick and given it a modern twist. Where once your man broke your heart and left you crying, Case is more likely to find him, seduce him - and then drown him.

With her long, red flowing hair and short, red velvet dress, Case isn't your standard country gal. She's strikingly reminiscent of Janis Joplin, shoulders back, eyes skyward, a woman who knows she's good. And then there's the voice. While Case has forsaken the pouty Shania antics, her voice has a warmth and depth shared by Patsy Cline. But where kd lang tried for a sweet copy of country's greatest female vocalist, Case has taken the legacy and run with it. Her voice practically hits the beams of the chapel as it soars, but it's full of the weight of experience, enhanced with the knowingness that Cline made her own.

Case is a honky-tonk angel, make no mistake. "If I'd known heartbreak was coming, I would have set out running," she sings, swaying her hips to the drowsy sound of the steel guitar. Porchlight sees her in angelic mood, backed up by the tender vocals of bandmate Kelly Hogan. An enthusiastic Case gives her some of the spotlight. As a slightly embarrassed Hogan comes centre stage, she begins a cover version of the Magnetic Fields' Papa Was a Rodeo in a surprising moment of country-singer-meets-country-pastiche.

But it's Case who shines the brightest. It's her birthday and she's having a good time. Until it starts to go wrong. First her guitar refuses to cooperate. "For your birthday, your guitar will break," she mutters as she tries to strum for the third time. Then there's that feedback. Soon she can't sing for laughing as she awaits the next disaster. Thankfully, it doesn't appear. Instead she glides into Twist the Knife. "Take my breath from me," she pleads, her problems restricted to men once more. Which is just how it should be.

 Neko Case and Her Boyfriends play the Maze, Nottingham (0115-947 2923), tonight.

fields.headline: What a song and dance
fields.standfirst:
Rough Crossing
Playhouse, Salisbury
Rating:**
fields.trailText:
Rough Crossing
Playhouse, Salisbury
Rating:**
fields.body:
If you are going to revive a Tom Stoppard play, it seems perverse - with so many to choose from - to opt for one of his lamest: his 1983 adaptation of Ferenc Molnar's Play at the Castle. This is froth, nothing more. Having said that, Salisbury's artistic director, Joanna Read, makes a fine job of it, giving this farcical tale set on a 1930s ocean liner the kind of classy production it demands. Nancy Surman's Art Deco design recreates a bygone era of opulent elegance. The evening is as easy on the eye as it is on the brain.

Sandor Turai (Matthew Kelly of Stars in Their Eyes fame) and Alex Gal are famous playwrights about to premiere their latest musical comedy in New York. Joining the ship earlier than expected, they overhear the play's leading lady, Natasha, canoodling with her former lover and the play's leading man, Ivor Fish. This is a disaster because in tow with the playwrights is Adam Adam, their protégé and composer, and Natasha's fiancé. So Turai concocts a scheme that will save both Adam and Natasha's relationship and the play.

That is about it, folks. The play is such a trifle that you are still waiting for it to really get going when it rolls to a close. It is all mildly entertaining and full of the kind of Stoppardian wordplay and punning that will either make you grin or groan. But it is never farcical enough to be really funny or sufficiently substantial to be satisfying and, most damagingly, Stoppard never successfully persuades that there is anything really at stake to make such a song and dance about.

Singing and dancing are integral to the plot. After a hesitant start, Read keeps up a good pace, the cast work like demons and, in the play's best part - that of the steward Dvornichek who gets everything wrong - John Ramm puts you in mind of the loveable roguishness of the late Leonard Rossiter.

Until September 30. Box office: 01722 320333

fields.headline: Purity and smut
fields.standfirst:
Earthly Delights
South Bank Centre, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Earthly Delights
South Bank Centre, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The final day of the South Bank's early music weekend celebrated the current strength of this field of musical performance in France with recitals by two of the country's leading ensembles - Dominique Visse's Ensemble Clément Janequin and Christophe Rousset's Les Talens Lyriques.

The Ensemble Clément Janequin consists of five male singers and their virtuoso lutenist and guitarist, Eric Bellocq. The very secular, sometimes downright smutty, part-songs that made up their programme would originally have been performed in various stages of inebriation during or after a long evening's dining. With this in mind, the group always sings seated around a table. On this occasion, though, this didn't add any atmosphere as the best table that could be found in the Queen Elizabeth Hall was a flimsy thing draped with a black cloth, bringing to mind a hastily arranged press conference.

Their presentation may not have been so polished, but their performance certainly was slick and very entertaining. Two lengthy, rollicking hunting songs had the singers barking like dogs and bleating like sheep as Bellocq played on solemnly, while the four-part Fricassée, with each performer singing different words, was a classic example of how a song of this period can seem piously honourable on the surface when it's actually pretty filthy underneath.

The ensemble are utterly attuned to one another's voices, and their intonation for the first few songs at least was astonishingly pure (though it later wavered slightly). It was the countertenor and director Dominique Visse whose voice was dominant. In the best sense, his voice is like a razor, cutting cleanly through thick vocal textures - it's a very pure sound, with an amazing amount of edge without being harsh. For most of this repertoire no one voice is supposed to dominate the group, but Visse's individual tone makes a large contribution to the ensemble's character.

Accompanied by harpsichordist Jean-Marc Aymes, Kiehr communicated her programme of 17th-century Italian songs and monologues gently but effectively, with a limpid, ringing tone.

However, the most direct, expressive singing of the day came from Valérie Gabail, performing in a programme of 18th-century French music with Les Talens Lyriques. Led by Christophe Rousset at the harpsichord, the group gave an involving recital, with every phrase musically and thoughtfully played.

fields.headline: GE 'bids for Scottish Life'
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Mutual insurer Scottish Life was yesterday at the centre of mounting speculation that it has received a takeover approach from GE Capital, the financial services arm of US conglomerate General Electric.
fields.body:
Mutual insurer Scottish Life was yesterday at the centre of mounting speculation that it has received a takeover approach from GE Capital, the financial services arm of US conglomerate General Electric.

One report said an announcement could be made as early as tomorrow or Thursday, though the rumoured £2bn bid amount quoted in some Scottish newspapers is significantly higher than previous analysts' valuations of £800m-£1bn. A £2bn takeover would trigger average windfalls of around £4,000 to qualifying policyholders.

Edinburgh-based Scottish Life, which specialises in selling pensions, has long been described as a potential takeover target and it is said to have been reviewing its mutual status for several months.

If it were to be acquired, it would be the latest in a string of mutual life insurers to shed their member-owned status or announce plans to do so.

Last Thursday Abbey National said it was acquiring Scottish Provident for £1.8bn, and during the past few weeks more than 1.6m policyholders with Scottish Widows have been receiving windfall payments after its acquisition by Lloyds TSB. Equitable Life put itself up for sale in July after losing a legal battle involving pension guarantees, and in May, Friends Provident announced plans to float on the stock market.

The Scottish Provident takeover will leave Scottish Life and Standard Life the only two remaining mutuals in Scotland.

Scottish Life declined to comment on what it said was "speculation". It said there may be a strategic review going on but this was something that happened from time to time. "The directors have a responsibility to ensure they consider what is in the best interest of members," said a spokesman.

Scottish Life was founded as a proprietary company in 1881 and became a mutual in 1968. It has about £10bn of funds under management and around 550,000 policyholders, half of whom hold with-profits policies. Scottish Life sells all its products through independent financial advisers.

GE Capital reportedly wants to use Scottish Life as a springboard for its ambitions in financial services in Britain.

webTitle: Deutsche Bank blamed as shares hit by rogue trade

fields.headline: Deutsche Bank blamed as shares hit by rogue trade
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The stability of trading on London's equity market was brought into question yesterday after a rogue trade sent share prices plunging and led to the temporary suspension of trading in 23 blue chip stocks.
fields.body:
The stability of trading on London's equity market was brought into question yesterday after a rogue trade sent share prices plunging and led to the temporary suspension of trading in 23 blue chip stocks.

Early yesterday the share prices of household names such as Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham were sent reeling by the trade, which insiders blamed on the German securities house Deutsche Bank. At one point the FTSE 100 was down more than 200 points at 6,392.1. It recovered to close down 18.7 points at 6,582.

Deutsche's suspect dealings involved a £15m computerised "program" trade for an institutional client, covering simultaneous dealings in 102 individual shares. Rather than selling shares at the so-called "mid-price", the trader entered "at best" into his terminal, causing Deutsche's computers to trade at any price where a buyer could be found.

It could not have come at a worse time for the London Stock Exchange, which is trying to repel a hostile takeover from OM Gruppen, owner of the Swedish stock exchange. OM yesterday published its offer, again highlighting the effi ciency of its trading technology. Chief executive Per Larsson said: "Our offer today brings state-of-the-art technology, clarity and real commercial drive that will secure London as Europe's leading exchange."

However, London rejected OM's approach and said the offer was deeply flawed: "OM's proposal represents a cul-de-sac for the UK market. The offer provides nothing new for our shareholders to consider."

Germany's Deutsche Börse last night delayed a vote on plans to merge with the London exchange after OM officially tabled its terms.

The ballot of shareholders, due to be held on Thursday, was postponed following a board meeting yesterday afternoon. A Börse spokesman said no new date had been fixed and insisted all options were being kept open.

But Rolf Breuer, the supervisory board chairman of Deutsche Börse, said the directors were still behind the merger plans and called it "the most attractive option".

The move came on the day the New York-based Nasdaq market was rumoured to be poised to join OM's bid. Neither company was prepared to comment on the speculation.

fields.headline: Four face insider dealing charges
fields.trailText: Two former employees of the London Stock Exchange and two others went on trial yesterday on charges of insider dealing.
fields.body:
Two former employees of the London Stock Exchange and two others went on trial yesterday on charges of insider dealing.

Stephen Porter, 37, of Gurton Road, Sydenham - one of the exchange staff - was charged with disclosing information contrary to Section 52 of the Criminal Justice Act 1993, when he appeared at Marylebone magistrates' court, London.

Also in court were Julian Daw of North Road, Hertford, who is facing three counts of disclosing information under the same act, and Dilip Chohan, 40, of Stonehaven Drive, Finham, Coventry, who was charged with two counts of misusing inside information.

Anthony Hadnutt, of Tudor Drive, Gidea Park, Essex - another former exchange employee - faces one charge of disclosing information. He did not appear and is reported to be in New Zealand.

The case was adjourned until October 16. All four were granted bail.

Mr Hadnutt is charged with one count of disclosing information on a former listed company called David Brown to Mr Porter in October 1997. Mr Porter is charged with three counts of disclosing information to Mr Daw between July and November 1997 relating to three companies - Central Transport Rental, David Brown and Faber Prest.

Mr Daw is charged with passing information on Central Transport and David Brown to Dilip Choham. He is also alleged to have passed on information on Faber Prest to another individual, Mukesh Chohan, who has not been charged with any offence.

Dilip Chohan is charged with dealing in share options in Forte during 1995 and South West Water in October 1996 on the basis of information supplied by unknown sources.

webTitle: Elderly in savings trap to get cash boost

fields.headline: Elderly in savings trap to get cash boost
fields.trailText: Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, yesterday promised a cash boost for pensioners with modest savings as ministers prepared to face down criticism at the Labour conference this month that they are not doing enough for the elderly.
fields.body:
Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, yesterday promised a cash boost for pensioners with modest savings as ministers prepared to face down criticism at the Labour conference this month that they are not doing enough for the elderly.

He outlined the principles of a pension credit to help those caught in a savings trap which has infuriated hundreds of thousands of pensioners with small sums in banks or building societies.

Mr Darling said the present arrangements made pensioners feel that it had not paid to save because they would have been better off relying entirely on the state.

Under plans due in a consultation paper this autumn, a pension credit would be available to top up the minimum income guarantee (MIG).

"For every pound saved, pensioners receiving the credit will get a cash addition," he told the Institute of Public Policy Research. "For the first time in the history of the welfare state, people will get something more for saving... Instead of falling between two stools, where they have too much income to qualify for MIG but too little to raise them above that level of benefit, they will earn a top-up that gives them a higher weekly income than if they were relying on the MIG or solely on savings."

Mr Darling said he could not yet indicate the size of the concession. Details of who would qualify and how much they will get would not be available until the autumn.

Ministers have been distancing themselves from reports that Gordon Brown, the chancellor, will tell the conference of plans for a £100 a week minimum for pensioners to head off a revolt by a coalition of trade unions including the TGWU, the GMB and Unison. They are preparing to table resolutions demanding restoration of the link between the rise in earnings and increases in the basic state pension. Since the Tories abolished the link 20 years ago, the basic state pension has risen only in line with inflation.

Mr Darling firmly rejected union leaders' demand for a restoration of the link between pensions and increases in average earnings. This could cost an extra £20bn a year by 2002 and would not solve the problem of those on low and modest incomes, he said.

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said Mr Darling's speech was motivated more by pre-conference politics in the Labour party than concern for the welfare system. "Every pensioner with any savings whatsoever will have to give full details to the government," he said.

Steve Webb, the Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, said: "The government has announced these changes to the minimum income guarantee because the state pension is clearly too low.

"They have now effectively admitted that the MIG excludes many pensioners. The pensioner credit is designed to dig the government out of a hole of its own making. It has created a gulf between the inadequate basic state pension and the level of the means test. It would be far simpler and fairer for the government to pay a decent basic state pension."

Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern in England, said the government was right to tackle the problem of pensioners penalised for their thrift.

fields.headline: Real grant McManaman conditional reprieve
fields.trailText: Real Madrid's sporting director Jorge Valdano yesterday confirmed that Steve McManaman will stay at the club this season but said that the former Liverpool player will have no right to protest if he finds himself spending more time on the bench than on the pitch.
fields.body:
Real Madrid's sporting director Jorge Valdano yesterday confirmed that Steve McManaman will stay at the club this season but said that the former Liverpool player will have no right to protest if he finds himself spending more time on the bench than on the pitch.

"McManaman won't be leaving Real Madrid," said Valdano after Real's 2-1 victory over Valencia on the opening day of the Spanish league season. McManaman, who was outstanding against the same opponents in the European Cup final less than four months ago, did not get off the bench.

"He's said that he wants to stay and fight for his place and that's something we value at Real Madrid," added Valdano. "He's the sort of player we want here. But we have repeated that he won't have many chances to play this year. He has to know that he won't have the right to complain if he doesn't play."

Against Valencia, Real fell behind to a Gaizka Mendieta penalty but Raul equalised and the world record signing Luis Figo, already rumoured to be unhappy at his new club, scored the winner five minutes from time. Real kick off their defence of the Champions League away at Peter Schmeichel's Sporting Lisbon tomorrow night.

The Dutch striker Patrick Kluivert is ready to return to the Barcelona line-up for their Champions League encounter with Leeds on Wednesday. Kluivert injured his ankle in Holland's recent World Cup qualifier against Ireland.

He missed Saturday's first game of the season against Malaga, which Barcelona won 2-1 thanks to two first-half goals from Rivaldo, but Kluivert was given the all-clear by the club's medical staff and trained yesterday.

The return of Kluivert means there is likely to be no place for either Alfonso Perez or Dani Garcia, and one of the Spanish internationals will have to settle for sitting on the bench for the Yorkshire club's visit to the Nou Camp.

fields.headline: Gazza finds life after dearth
fields.trailText: The wheels are starting to turn on the Gazza-for-England campaign bus. The movement is based predominantly on sentiment, memories of the player he was rather than the one who made a low-key but effective contribution to this Everton victory.
fields.body:
The wheels are starting to turn on the Gazza-for-England campaign bus. The movement is based predominantly on sentiment, memories of the player he was rather than the one who made a low-key but effective contribution to this Everton victory.

Yet those who believe he can produce one final flourish on the international stage - and Paul Gascoigne is among them - were given extra encouragement, not least by the fact that he outlasted Paul Ince, a midfield rival who will certainly figure in Kevin Keegan's World Cup thinking.

Ince was plainly angry that Bryan Robson substituted him after 75 minutes. He said: "I don't know why I was brought off. I felt OK. I wasn't very happy about coming off, that's for sure. But it was good to see Gazza last 90 minutes."

Presumably Robson did nothing to improve Ince's mood later with the suggestion that he failed to match the energy levels of Gascoigne, who now looks leaner than at any time during 18 unfulfilling months at Middlesbrough.

Robson said: "Paul Gascoigne is still a very good player if he's fit and working hard. Our midfield players have to look at the way we were outfought and outrun and make sure they get on top of their fitness."

Those words were also an indictment of the France international Christian Karembeu, whose impact was negligible once Gascoigne and the even more impressive Thomas Gravesen started to locate the intelligent runs of Francis Jeffers. With Everton trailing to an own-goal by Steve Watson, Jeffers crisply converted Gravesen's pass and sealed victory by scrambling home Gascoigne's angled through-ball.

Jeffers has now scored five Premiership goals this season and is undoubtedly a more realistic England contender than Gascoigne. His manager Walter Smith sees a more mature and committed player. "Francis is definitely showing an appetite for the game now," he said. "Sometimes previously he didn't but people forget he's only 19."

Everton, now lying seventh, are offered further optimism by the appearance in the closing stages of Kevin Campbell after a six-month absence through injury. Jeffers' link-up with Mark Hughes is good; the one with Campbell promises to be even more productive.

In contrast Robson is aware of a groundswell of discontent among fans who clearly echo the verdict of Ince. "For a club with ambitions of playing in Europe, we have no chance on that display," admitted the Middlesbrough captain.

Only Alen Boksic supplied value for money before fading towards the end. Karembeu, Noel Whelan and Joseph- Desire Job were anonymous apart from a dreadful challenge on Abel Xavier that would have earned Whelan a red card from some referees.

fields.headline: Glamorgan fall despite Maynard stand
fields.trailText:
Nottinghamshire 229
Glamorgan 226
Nottinghamshire win by three runs
fields.body:
Glamorgan's captain Matthew Maynard fell agonisingly short of guiding his team to a dramatic last-over win in an enthralling encounter yesterday.

The Welsh county went into the match needing a win to keep alive any hopes of promotion, while victory for Nottinghamshire would guarantee them a place in the First Division of the National League.

In the end the tense match went down to the final ball when Maynard, batting in awful light and on 87 not out, needed to hit Andrew Harris's last ball for six to reach the target of 230.

He swung hard but the ball squirted to midwicket for a single, leading to a pitch invasion by the young Nottinghamshire fans of the kind normally reserved for Lord's finals and international games.

For long periods of their chase Glamorgan had looked likely to slip irreparably behind the asking rate, but they steadied their nerves and kept plugging away to stay in contention.

Needing 64 runs from the last eight overs, the Dragons appeared to have lost all chance of victory until Maynard launched Harris for six in an over that went for 12 and rekindled their faltering challenge.

Harris was removed to make way for Paul Franks, who tipped the balance back Nottinghamshire's way by bowling Michael Powell for 28 and then claiming Robert Croft thanks to a remarkable catch by Chris Read, who made up yards to his right to cling on to the ball.

But for all Nottinghamshire's perceived dominance, while Maynard remained there was always a chance. After hitting nine fours and a six on his way to 88 not out, he looked crestfallen to leave the field on the losing side having gone so close.

In the end Nottingham-shire's early work proved too much for the visitors, who really should have been chasing a total in excess of 250. Of the nine Notts wickets to fall only Franks, trapped leg-before by a yorker from Steve Watkin, was not largely responsible for his own downfall.

fields.bodyText: Glamorgan's captain Matthew Maynard fell agonisingly short of guiding his team to a dramatic last-over win in an enthralling encounter yesterday. The Welsh county went into the match needing a win to keep alive any hopes of promotion, while victory for Nottinghamshire would guarantee them a place in the First Division of the National League. In the end the tense match went down to the final ball when Maynard, batting in awful light and on 87 not out, needed to hit Andrew Harris's last ball for six to reach the target of 230. He swung hard but the ball squirted to midwicket for a single, leading to a pitch invasion by the young Nottinghamshire fans of the kind normally reserved for Lord's finals and international games. For long periods of their chase Glamorgan had looked likely to slip irreparably behind the asking rate, but they steadied their nerves and kept plugging away to stay in contention. Needing 64 runs from the last eight overs, the Dragons appeared to have lost all chance of victory until Maynard launched Harris for six in an over that went for 12 and rekindled their faltering challenge. Harris was removed to make way for Paul Franks, who tipped the balance back Nottinghamshire's way by bowling Michael Powell for 28 and then claiming Robert Croft thanks to a remarkable catch by Chris Read, who made up yards to his right to cling on to the ball. webTitle: Safety first keeps Leicester secure on home front

fields.headline: Safety first keeps Leicester secure on home front
fields.trailText: Leicester are still hoping not to go to Belgrade for their Uefa Cup second leg on Thursday week against Red Star. Uefa, having moved the tie to precede Yugoslavia's presidential election, requires written assurances of players' safety from the authorities by tomorrow. Meanwhile Leicester prepared for Thursday's home leg with a win that keeps them level on points with Manchester United on top of the table.
fields.body:
Leicester are still hoping not to go to Belgrade for their Uefa Cup second leg on Thursday week against Red Star. Uefa, having moved the tie to precede Yugoslavia's presidential election, requires written assurances of players' safety from the authorities by tomorrow. Meanwhile Leicester prepared for Thursday's home leg with a win that keeps them level on points with Manchester United on top of the table.

United have scored 13 goals, Leicester four and conceded only one, a last-minute penalty. Tim Flowers said at the weekend the trip to Belgrade was "not cast-iron yet". His goalkeeping is just that. A first-half, double parry from 12 yards, then three was spectacular. Gerry Taggart, who landed him in it, more than made up for it with his second-half header from a corner to settle the issue.

Leicester's defence is well built about Matt Elliott but, where United score freely, the Foxes peter out. Ade Akinbiyi is lightning without the strike; Darren Eadie is more comfortable wide; and Stan Collymore, short of match fitness, had his promised 45 minutes - but half a loafer is worse than nothing. Tony Cottee, last season's top scorer, was last night released to Norwich.

So far City have got away with this, wasting the service of Neil Lennon and Muzzy Izzet. They are alarmingly dependent on these two, neither fully fit, for midfield control. When both had been replaced, after the goal, the Saints raised a siege, coincident also with James Beattie's arrival for Uwe Rösler. Glenn Hoddle persists with Rösler as line leader in a 4-3-2-1 formation. Beattie's movement might give it point and bring Marian Pahars and Hassan Kachloul more encouragement.

Unusually for opposing managers Hoddle and Peter Taylor, friends for 20 years and recent England allies, had dinner together on Friday. Within 20 hours the pupil Taylor, given his chance with the Under-21s by Hoddle, had had his master tactically for breakfast. Sometimes Hoddle seems in danger of vanishing up his own theories.

Both are exponents of the so-called "beautiful game", a term apparently coined by people who still refer to the Dome as "the attraction". This was less beautiful than frustrating because so many patient attacks ended with mindless or incompetent centres. How can two such thinking managers not attend better to the end product?

Taylor may have the greater streak of realism and to City's famous spirit he has harnessed a belief in individual ability. Hoddle was impressed. "I think he's very approachable and he switches on the right head to cope with different circumstances at the right time," he said. At present Elliott is the one like Cerberus and, as for Hoddle, it is a case of "Heads you win, tails I lose".

At times his sayings rival those of Colin Murphy, City's football co-ordinator, whose programme notes as manager of Lincoln were a legend of highfalutin obscurity. Flowers said hopefully that Murphy had been sent to Belgrade to help sort things out. Presumably his Serbo-Croat is more intelligible than his English.

webTitle: Scholes puts United in good heart

fields.headline: Scholes puts United in good heart
fields.trailText: Manchester United have two homes: Old Trafford and top of the Premiership. They returned to both on Saturday and it is difficult to see anyone ending the relationship.
fields.body:
Manchester United have two homes: Old Trafford and top of the Premiership. They returned to both on Saturday and it is difficult to see anyone ending the relationship.

Sir Alex Ferguson's team, by his own admission, did not play particularly well but the fact that they still beat Sunderland 3-0 - following Tuesday's 6-0 filleting of Bradford - and preserved an unbeaten home record that stretches back to December 1998, shows why the term Theatre of Dreams is a laughable concept for most visiting teams.

But it is not just at Fortress Trafford where United feel at home. They last lost in the Premiership in Feburary, 18 games ago, a level of consistency which their so-called title rivals have been consistent in failing to match.

On the first day of the season Arsenal actually lost to Sunderland. And four days after an under-strength United hit Bradford for six, Arsenal could only draw with them. As for Chelsea, they have been beaten by Bradford, Leeds have lost at home to Manchester City, and Liverpool had to accept a draw at Southampton.

No wonder United are considering offering their players shares in the club to try to entice them to stay. They must be bored rigid in a league where the question is not whether they will win it but by how many points.

It is hardly surprising, therefore, to see Ferguson turning his thoughts towards more testing challenges. According to Paul Scholes, the scorer of two stunning goals: "The manager has said to us that, if we want to be known as one of the really great teams, we have to win the Champions Cup maybe three or four times."

The team's quest for triumph No2 begins on Wednesday at home to Anderlecht with the players secure in the knowledge that, on the early evidence, the domestic league is all but secure already. The exhausting effects of United's participation in the Champions League last season proved such a handicap that they won the Premiership title by only 18 points.

Saturday's game reflected United's current thinking. Hav ing produced a coruscating opening spell to go 1-0 ahead - Scholes heading in David Beckham's cross after a wonderful passing sequence through the middle - the United players took their foot off the pedal having, it seemed, already worked out that Sunderland were about as threatening as a mild curry and with self-preservation uppermost given the proximity of the Anderlecht tie.

As a result Peter Reid's in jury-hit side suddenly found themselves with plenty of possession. But they lacked the pace, movement and invention to worry Fabien Barthez, who might as well have been cruising in the Med with Linda Evangelista for all he had to do.

That is, until the 75th minute. Emerson Thome headed a Sunderland corner goalwards and Niall Quinn helped it on. But, just as the ball looked to be heading over the line, Barthez's arm appeared from nowhere to push it away. From spectator to saviour: the true test of a great goalkeeper.

Annoyed by such impudence, United marched down the other end to put the match beyond reach, Cole setting up Teddy Sheringham for his third goal in four days. Scholes added a third with a screamer from 20 yards to end another day at the office for United.

Reid's team have now slipped to third bottom and his troubles were not helped by the thought that this was not even United's full-strength side. Roy Keane was suspended, Dwight Yorke injured - though there was some suspicion he was being disciplined for returning late from international duty - and Jaap Stam was taken off at half-time with an achilles problem.

Reid would also probably shake his snow-capped head in amazement at the thought that Ferguson is still looking to sign another defender, with Lazio's Portugal international Fernando Couto a possible target.

So, while Ferguson remains modest about United's title chances - "The best time to judge is the new year when all the big guns have played each other" - Reid has no doubts. "Who will win the title? That's the easiest question I've been asked today."

fields.headline: Wolves under a black cloud
fields.trailText: Two defeats into yet another black September for Wolves and any shred of pre-season optimism has all but dissipated.
fields.body:
Two defeats into yet another black September for Wolves and any shred of pre-season optimism has all but dissipated.

Old Gold shirts may still be de rigueur on the terraces - though most are without number or name now that Keane and Bull are gone - but the air of resignation from the lowest league crowd for seven years was all too evident as their patched-up side trudged off at the final whistle.

Colin Lee's squad has been ravaged by injuries and with the Saudi Arabian Sami Al Jaber still awaiting international clearance, the Wolves manager gave a league debut to Adam Proudlock, recently recalled from a successful loan spell at Clyde and given a three-year deal into the bargain.

The promising 19-year-old should have quickly justified his manager's faith only to drag a shot narrowly wide from 10 yards. And though Carl Robinson soon made amends with a neat header, a spirited Tranmere fought back from one down for the third time in a week to record their third win.

Wayne Allison headed in directly from a free-kick and the substitute Stuart Barlow left his shirt on while celebrating his winner from the penalty spot, which at least spared Stephen Lodge the dilemma of whether or not to book him.

"We are missing a lot of very good players but the crowd stuck with us," said Lee. "I think they understood the difficulties we are facing. We are trying to pick up points here and there until we get the players back."

Lee is giving priority to recruiting a central defender to help shore up the backline but will have to do without his captain Kevin Muscat for one match - sent off for upending Sean Flynn in conceding the penalty - and for the season without Scott Taylor, after rupturing a tendon in a kneecap.

Tranmere had lost their previous seven games here, the last win coming in 1993 when Sir Jack Hayward was building Wolves a stadium fit for the Premiership and only two stands were complete. For Lee, the third manager to try to satisfy "Golden Tit's" ambitions since, the future looks rocky.

webTitle: City owe it all to Styles not substance

fields.headline: City owe it all to Styles not substance
fields.trailText: A cricket-playing Birmingham supporter, seduced by the stylish demolition of Barnsley a fortnight earlier, tried to get the best of both worlds on Saturday by opting to bat last and nipping down to St Andrews in the interim.
fields.body:
A cricket-playing Birmingham supporter, seduced by the stylish demolition of Barnsley a fortnight earlier, tried to get the best of both worlds on Saturday by opting to bat last and nipping down to St Andrews in the interim.

But, with City's display having more in common with ballroom dancing in Wellington boots than stylish football, it was difficult to know whether to sympathise or question his sanity. The City manager Trevor Francis had two expla nations for his side's inability to turn on the style that had brushed aside Barnsley and Nottingham Forest in the two previous league games: late team changes, with Jerry Gill and Marcelo dropping out through injury, and a smother- everything-at-source approach from the Blades.

"Dave Bassett told me how Barnsley were beaten at St Andrews and I made my plans accordingly," United's manager Neil Warnock explained.

They might have worked if the referee Robert Styles had not awarded the ninth-minute penalty from which Martin O'Connor settled matters. Styles had no hesitation in awarding the kick after Peter Ndlovu was fouled by George Santos. Two seasons ago he had sent off Ndlovu for two bookable offences, both of them diving.

Later the referee endeared himself even more to City supporters when he sent off Michael Brown in the last minute. By then it was too late for United, even though they had gone close through Marcus Bent and Bobby Ford, and prevented City from troubling Simon Tracey in open play.

"They worked very hard and made life difficult for us," Francis admitted. "We're going to get a number of games like that." Indecisive supporters have been warned.

By then it was too late for United, even though they had gone close through Marcus Bent and Bobby Ford, and prevented City from troubling Simon Tracey in open play. "They worked very hard and made life difficult for us," Francis admitted. "We're going to get a number of games like that." Indecisive supporters have been warned.

fields.headline: Bargains underpin O'Neill record run
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill has only been in Glasgow for two footballing months and already his name is inscribed in one of the city's blood-red record books.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill has only been in Glasgow for two footballing months and already his name is inscribed in one of the city's blood-red record books.

This bludgeoning of Hibernian was O'Neill's ninth straight win as Celtic's manager, beating the record for a debutant Old Firm coach which had stretched back to the 20s and Bill Struth at Rangers.

Struth was a martinet, a man who wore a bowler and heavy three-piece suits, and who, if he could, would not employ any Catholics at Ibrox. His record is not the only aspect which has changed remarkably over 80 years.

One thing O'Neill does share with Struth is an unerring eye when it comes to spotting a player. Given the expensive trash that both Rangers and Celtic have spent a decade importing, it is refreshing to see O'Neill's reborn Celtic being nicely hemmed at the edges by some good, if unspectacular, signings.

O'Neill has bought Joos Valgaeren, the unheralded Belgian international defender, for a modest £2.5m, and has been repaid by Valgaeren's pace and steadying influence on an excitable defence. On Saturday Alan Thompson also made his second appearance for Celtic and was instrumental in much of his new club's foraging play.

No recent Celtic signing, though, even including that of the talismanic Henrik Larsson, has represented the same pound-for-pound bargain as Lubomir Moravcik. At a time when Rangers were racking up Dutchmen and Italians by the plane-load it is amusing to recall the disparaging press which greeted Jozef Venglos's signing of the unknown little Slovakian.

But Moravcik had won over 70 caps with the former Czechoslovakia and his native Slovakia, and at 35 his spritely runs and squirming changes of direction are as potent as ever. Moravcik heaped misery on Rangers two weeks ago, and on Saturday he tore at Hibs, who, lying top of the Scottish Premier League, had suffered delusions of survival.

"He's a little genius, a marvellous player," O'Neill says of Moravcik. "The only problem is he's older than me."

Moravcik's teasing cross just before half-time brought a flashing Larsson header for Celtic's second goal, the Swede having already rammed home a 16th-minute penalty. Mark Burchill scored the third a minute from time.

Poor Hibs. In a stadium of 60,000 their meagre allocation of 1,500 fans was penned into a corner to see their side crushed. Alex McLeish's team had gambolled into this new season but on Saturday they met a Celtic team whose imminent domestic and European adventures promise to be interesting, to say the least.

webTitle: Bad break puts pressure on Ellis

fields.headline: Bad break puts pressure on Ellis
fields.trailText: Once Doug Ellis has used his casting vote today to secure his future in office, Aston Villa's chairman will have an early opportunity to rebut the charge of penny-pinching by angry shareholders who have campaigned against one of the most powerful men in English football.
fields.body:
Once Doug Ellis has used his casting vote today to secure his future in office, Aston Villa's chairman will have an early opportunity to rebut the charge of penny-pinching by angry shareholders who have campaigned against one of the most powerful men in English football.

Ellis is under even more acute pressure to reopen the Villa Park purse to finance a signing after the cruel loss of their Belgian striker Luc Nilis with a horrendous injury in only his fifth game for the club. A double fracture of the right leg, sustained in a collision with Ipswich's goalkeeper Richard Wright, has put him out until next season. At the age of 33 there must be strong fears that his distinguished playing career is over.

Even since Nilis's arrival on a Bosman free transfer from PSV Eindhoven in the summer, John Gregory has been trying to sign another forward to strengthen this department. Attempts to bring in Celta Vigo's £10m-rated Benni McCarthy collapsed and since then overtures to Steve McManaman, surplus to Real Madrid requirements, have been spurned.

Those names, and the sums involved, will have heightened expectations among Villa fans which may now be satisfied only by a headline signing.

The Belgian international's misfortune after only four minutes can be said to have added injury to insult to Villa's week given Gregory's outburst against Chelsea and the invective hurled at Ellis from within his own empire. If the manager was delighted to oversee Villa's first win of the season - particularly as he lost his captain Gareth Southgate with a jarred ankle not long after Nilis - he was not immediately express ing it, declining to attend the post-match press conference.

Instead his No2 Steve Harrison confirmed everyone's worst fears about Nilis's injury which left his right leg contorted and hanging awkwardly. "It's a compound fracture - a very nasty one -and he was taken to hospital straight away. The two players had their eyes on the ball. Nobody was to blame."

The collision came as the striker pursued a flick by Dion Dublin into the penalty area. Wright explained: "He got to the ball before me and hooked it against me. My momentum took me through into him. He was in a lot of pain."

Play was held up for five min utes - contributing to an extraordinary 13 of injury-time in all. It said much for Villa's organisation and eye for opportunity that they withstood this setback, took the lead and then doubled it after losing Southgate on 28 minutes.

Slick passing between four colleagues culminated in Lee Hendrie curling a shot beauti fully into Wright's left-hand corner and there was collective Ipswich embarrassment as Dublin delivered the simplest of headers from Paul Merson's inswinging corner.

Ipswich rallied bravely towards the end of a long, humid afternoon. Marcus Stewart, smarting at being dropped, made a swift point to George Burley by coming on and scoring cleverly. Another substitute, David Ginola, was frustrating and frustrated. Booked for a foul on Fabian Wilnis, he risked a red card by later disputing Andy d'Urso's failure to punish the same defender's challenge on him in the area. It was a clear penalty; once again Ginola's name had preceded him.

fields.headline: Surrey count down to glory
fields.standfirst:
Somerset 132 and 222
Lancashire 463-9 dec
Lancashire won by an innings and 109 runs
fields.trailText:
Somerset 132 and 222
Lancashire 463-9 dec
Lancashire won by an innings and 109 runs
fields.body:
Lancashire ensured that the County Championship will stretch into the final round of matches, if only theoretically, when they completed an overwhelming victory against Somerset nine balls into the afternoon session yesterday.

But the championship decider, when Surrey visit this ground in a match beginning on Wednesday, will actually be a non-event. Surrey hold a 19-point advantage and, even though a maximum of 20 points are available for a win, a tactical declaration of Surrey's first innings at the fall of the fifth wicket would be enough to deny Lancashire two bowling bonus points and ensure they cannot be overhauled at the top of the table.

Under Adam Hollioake's uncompromising leadership, Surrey are unlikely to have any qualms about such a recourse. The spectators who celebrated a second successive Surrey championship after their innings win against Durham at the Oval on Saturday were not being premature, merely realistic. What occurred at Old Trafford yesterday was largely inconsequential.

Surrey's 272-run victory against Lancashire in south London last month, when the northerners collapsed to the pace of Alex Tudor in the first innings and the spin of Ian Salisbury and Saqlain Mushtaq in the second, proved the decisive moment in a title race in which they have again been the outstanding side.

But it is difficult to whip up the enthusiasm to celebrate any success, however worthy, while English cricket braces itself for the revelations from India's Central Bureau of Investigation that two England internationals are alleged by illegal bookmakers to have been involved in match-rigging.

Lancashire escaped being docked points for a poor or unfit pitch when an England and Wales Cricket Board inspection team decided that no punishment was necessary. The fact that Lancashire were speeding at the time to 463 for nine declared, with the centurions Graham Lloyd and Warren Hegg sharing a sixth-wicket stand of 152, must have helped speed them to their decision.

The antipodean upbringing of Bobby Simpson, Lancashire's Australian coach, makes deliberate preparation of poor surfaces an anathema. "We have had good marks all season for our pitches," he said yesterday. "When I first came to this club I told Peter Marron, our groundsman, that he should prepare as good a wicket as possible. I don't believe in docking pitches because it is cheating. The problem that the pitch liaison officer system has is consistency. There are 12 of them, all of whom have different views.

"We bowled as well in this game as we have at any stage of the season. I have always said that if you get good swing bowling most batsmen can't handle it, and both [Mike] Smethurst and [Glen] Chapple did it very well."

Somerset, safely in mid-table, revived bad memories of the uncommitted late-season displays that were commonplace before the advent of the two-divisional system. Their collapse to 65 for four on Saturday evening suggested their resistance would be little more than tokenism, and on a muggy Manchester morning - in front of a few hundred spectators - so it proved.

Michael Burns nibbled at a Peter Martin outswinger and Graham Rose fell cutting at Smethurst, Hegg taking the catch off the bottom edge, before Ian Blackwell intervened with a lusty 36 from 24 balls, including five fours and two sixes, with the leg-spin of Chris Schofield proving most to his tastes.

Blackwell eventually top-edged a hook to give Hegg his 635th first-class catch for Lancashire, beating the county record set by George Duckworth between 1922-38. Hegg might have done his share of standing up this season, with the spin of Gary Keedy and Schofield a key to Lancashire's success, but he will never come remotely near Duckworth's tally of stumpings.

Peter Bowler also played freely, advancing his overnight 22 to 75 before Keedy had him caught at bat-pad. Smethurst's direct hit to run out Steffan Jones in the second over after lunch ended a match that Surrey's victory had rendered largely meaningless.

 Kent will also be chasing a solitary point later this week, after Gavin Hamilton's four for 34 condemned them to a 32-run loss to Yorkshire yesterday. Yorkshire's win was their first at Canterbury since 1987 and lifted them to third, but Kent need to pick up just one point at Leicester to avoid relegation. Hampshire are almost certain to join Durham and Derbyshire in the Second Division, despite their innings victory over Derbyshire on Saturday.

webTitle: Hamann the man in team of two halves

fields.headline: Hamann the man in team of two halves
fields.trailText: This could be Liverpool's year of living dangerously. They seem to be approaching their football this season as a game of two halves, except that one half is their attack, the other their defence.
fields.body:
This could be Liverpool's year of living dangerously. They seem to be approaching their football this season as a game of two halves, except that one half is their attack, the other their defence.

Their attack, spearheaded by Emile Heskey and Michael Owen, who could both lead the England line against Germany on October 7 (although please God not with Nicky Barmby), is irresistible.

Their defence, charged with protecting a panicky goalkeeper Sander Westerveld, whose attitude to crosses is Transylvanian - he shrivels in a corner and dies when he sees one - is all over the place.

Liverpool have already distinguished themselves by letting slip one three-goal lead, at Southampton. Against Manchester City on Saturday they tried a different permutation, scoring two, letting in two, scoring again and then being fortunate to see Alf-Inge Haaland's "goal" disallowed in the 85th minute after Westerveld dropped another cross.

"Liverpool are a good young team but they made too many mistakes," explained the former world player of the year George Weah. "They looked slack at the back and every time the ball went into the box it looked like we were going to score."

Defences may be becoming more generous but a team with title expectations can usually afford to let in only 40 or so goals in total. If the Reds continue on their present rate it will be up around the 60 mark, which is roughly what Southampton let in to finish 15th last season.

Gérard Houllier, however, was sanguine. "It's the beginning of the league," he shrugged. "I know there are plenty of things we have to im prove. But the good thing is that, even if we're not too good, we get points at the moment."

Houllier rightly pointed to the absence in defence of the captain Sami Hyypia, who will also be missing when Liverpool go to Rapid Bucharest in the first round of the Uefa Cup on Thursday. But at least he can rely on his attack to bail him out, Michael Owen taking just 11 minutes to continue his remarkable run of form with his sixth goal in five league games this season, his 54th in his 100th Premiership match.

The German Dietmar Hamann gave England something to think about on the volley, but the game really picked up with the introduction of Weah in the 57th minute. First the Liberian pulled a goal back, then he put through Haaland, who was tripped by Djimi Traore, Trevor Horlock converting the penalty. Hamann had to go to work again for Liverpool's third but it was a nervous end to a match Liverpool should have wrapped up by the hour.

Joe Royle refused to attend the press conference but he appeared on television to suggest that the Professional Footballers' Association "should name and shame the divers", a reference to a spat that had occurred when Heskey took a typical tumble.

Royle was clearly not about to get carried away by his side's improvement since they last visited Anfield in the league, a 6-0 drubbing in October 1995, but he may have been distracted by the first sign of discontent behind the scenes.

Weah was politely letting it be known he was not impressed with a seat on the bench. "It was disappointing not to start but I have to respect the coach's decision," he said. "I do not want to question the decision, so I did not go after him looking for an explanation."

Paul Dickov in for George Weah: who would have predicted that in 1995?

fields.headline: Derby cede comeback crown
fields.trailText: Derby County were given a taste of their own medicine yesterday and did not find it to their liking. After nurturing a talent for improbable feats of escapology Jim Smith's team - Houdini FC, he has taken to calling them - found the task of protecting a two-goal lead beyond their limited means.
fields.body:
Derby County were given a taste of their own medicine yesterday and did not find it to their liking. After nurturing a talent for improbable feats of escapology Jim Smith's team - Houdini FC, he has taken to calling them - found the task of protecting a two-goal lead beyond their limited means.

Having created what should have been a winning margin through first-half goals from Malcolm Christie and Simo Valakari, the Premiership's comeback kings were dethroned by goals from Claus Jensen and Jonatan Johansson in the space of three second-half minutes.

It was the eighth time this season a side has recovered from being two goals down or worse in the Premiership and by the end Derby's supporters could be excused for being overcome by a sense of giddiness.

Smith's team have been the main players in the comeback stakes this season, having salvaged draws from being three down against Middlesbrough and two down to Everton and Southampton. This time they were to finish on the receiving end. "The script was the wrong way around," wheezed the Charlton manager Alan Curbishley.

Charlton were fortunate to survive a late penalty appeal but they were good value for their draw during a match in which the case for both defences was indefensible.

Derby's breakthrough came in the seventh minute courtesy of Christie's third goal since beginning his season belatedly as a second-half substitute against Middlesbrough last Wednesday.

Bjorn Otto Bragstad hoofed the ball into Charlton's penalty area and, when the ball fell, Christie was the only player to react, taking one touch to control the ball and another to drive a left-foot shot into the far corner of Dean Kiely's goal. Such was the ponderous inactivity of Charlton's defenders it all seemed to have happened in slow motion.

If that was route-one stuff, Derby's second came with frills attached, Valakari starting and finishing an intricate move with a left-foot drive from the edge of the penalty area.

Charlton's frustration was palpable. For most of the opening 45 minutes they had produced the more cultured football only to be let down by some feeble finishing. But in the second half they found their range, with the ubiquitous Johansson flourishing and their midfielders full of zestful running.

Johannson created Charlton's first with his sense of awareness, dragging the ball back for Claus Jensen to score from eight yards after a sparkling counter-attack stemming from a Derby corner.

With the inquest ongoing in the home defence, Johansson then ran on to a long bouncing ball, dinked it over the oncoming goalkeeper Mart Poom and finished into an empty goal. "Amateur goals," bemoaned Smith.

At that point Charlton looked the more likely victors but it was Derby's players who left the field harbouring a burning sense of injustice. With 10 minutes remaining Mark Kinsella upended Stefano Eranio in the penalty area but the referee Peter Jones inexplicably waved aside the appeals before booking Eranio for protesting.

If Kinsella was embarrassed, Jones should be humiliated. Referees get £900 for officiating Premiership matches, which is an awful lot of money for misjudgments such as this.

Curbishley is clearly an alum nus of the Arsène Wenger school of management, stating he "had not seen the incident", but Smith, predictably, had. "If you don't give a penalty for that you shouldn't be refereeing," he said. "The referee was so close to the foul he could have made the tackle himself. It was too obvious for words."

To compound Derby's dismay, 22,310 was the lowest league attendance since Pride Park was opened four seasons ago. It was a bad day all round.

If that was route-one stuff, Derby's second came with frills attached, Valakari starting and finishing an intricate move with a left-foot drive from the edge of the penalty area. Charlton's frustration was palpable. For most of the opening 45 minutes they had produced the more cultured football only to be let down by some feeble finishing. But in the second half they found their range, with the ubiquitous Johansson flourishing and their midfielders full of zestful running. Johannson created Charlton's first with his sense of awareness, dragging the ball back for Claus Jensen to score from eight yards after a sparkling counter-attack stemming from a Derby corner. With the inquest ongoing in the home defence, Johansson then ran on to a long bouncing ball, dinked it over the oncoming goalkeeper Mart Poom and finished into an empty goal. "Amateur goals," bemoaned Smith. At that point Charlton looked the more likely victors but it was Derby's players who left the field harbouring a burning sense of injustice. With 10 minutes remaining Mark Kinsella upended Stefano Eranio in the penalty area but the referee Peter Jones inexplicably waved aside the appeals before booking Eranio for protesting. If Kinsella was embarrassed, Jones should be humiliated. Referees get £900 for officiating Premiership matches, which is an awful lot of money for misjudgments such as this. Curbishley is clearly an alum nus of the Arsène Wenger school of management, stating he "had not seen the incident", but Smith, predictably, had. "If you don't give a penalty for that you shouldn't be refereeing," he said. "The referee was so close to the foul he could have made the tackle himself. It was too obvious for words." To compound Derby's dismay, 22,310 was the lowest league attendance since Pride Park was opened four seasons ago. It was a bad day all round.

webTitle: Cole fires another rescue mission but Arsenal lack ruthlessness

fields.headline: Cole fires another rescue mission but Arsenal lack ruthlessness
fields.trailText: There were no celebratory strains of "One-one to the Arsenal" drifting up from the visitors' dressing room. But, while Arsène Wenger insisted this was not a result to be ashamed of, his title chances look bleak - according to a man who should know.
fields.body:
There were no celebratory strains of "One-one to the Arsenal" drifting up from the visitors' dressing room. But, while Arsène Wenger insisted this was not a result to be ashamed of, his title chances look bleak - according to a man who should know.

Having come close to a back injury from picking the ball out of the net six times at Old Trafford last Tuesday, Bradford's keeper Matt Clarke is well placed to judge the relative strengths of the championship contenders. He feels Arsenal's lack of ruthlessness does not bode well.

Had Wenger's players taken their chances, they would have made Bradford's progress look more suited to the US Open than the Premiership. After that 6-0 result in Manchester, Arsenal should have taken the second set 6-3. Instead Ashley Cole's equaliser and Benito Carbone's failure with two late opportunities saved them.

"I know United were at home and they were lucky with a couple of deflections, but they stick things away," said Clarke, who did much to deny Arsenal on Saturday.

"To be championship teams Chelsea and Arsenal have got to come and beat teams like us. With the pace Arsenal have up front and the balls they play in behind teams, they're hard to defend against. But they had a lot of chances and only took one. United get one chance and they score."

For Wenger this is a familiar story. At Sunderland his team lost 1-0 after running the match in similar fashion. At Chelsea he needed to risk playing four strikers to salvage a draw. This was two points lost. "When you look at the game," Wenger said, "we should have won."

Arsenal have now fallen behind in all three away matches and, despite Silvinho's goal at Chelsea and Cole's here, may soon run out of left-backs to save them. Without Tony Adams and Patrick Vieira, they never looked entirely happy.

Yet there was much to admire, particularly Thierry Henry's speed and Fredrik Ljungberg's passing. Their attacking potential is frightening and they are not alone in struggling on their travels. Manchester United, Liverpool and Chelsea have yet to win away at sides including Ipswich, Southampton and Bradford.

Bradford, though, does not promise to be easy for anyone. They play with more panache under Chris Hutchings but retain their old grit."We always do well against the big boys," said Clarke. "It's the clubs in the middle and lower sections we've got to turn over."

Bradford could have fallen behind before Stuart McCall scored when a Martin Keown header reached him 20 yards out. Henry had hit the post and Clarke made several good saves either side of Cole's equaliser.

Henry crossed for the 19-year-old Cole to sidefoot his first Premiership goal on a composed, if occasionally wobbly, second start. But how much more damning Arsenal's profligacy would have looked had Carbone been sharper. Their Champions League opponents, beginning with Sparta Prague tomorrow, will surely not be so generous.

webTitle: Card chaos but Fulham hold the aces

fields.headline: Card chaos but Fulham hold the aces
fields.trailText: So much good football flows on the banks of the Thames, so great is the potency in Fulham's attacking positions that it is almost possible to understand referees wanting to give the opposition a helping hand.
fields.body:
So much good football flows on the banks of the Thames, so great is the potency in Fulham's attacking positions that it is almost possible to understand referees wanting to give the opposition a helping hand.

Yesterday Andy Hall allowed Barnsley's Mitch Ward to remain on the pitch despite showing him a second yellow card. It had been an unequal struggle with 11 v 11, so why load the scales further in favour of Jean Tigana's trailblazers?

So engrossing had been the spectacle provided by a fifth successive victory and the ritual dismantling of another sacrificial back line that even Fulham's own supporters had failed to notice Hall's mistake.

Four minutes elapsed before the fourth official brought it to the attention of the man sporting black and now a red face as well. Off, belatedly, went Ward, shown, bizarrely, a third yellow followed by red from the Birmingham referee.

Fulham were so superior as they maintained their faultless pursuit of maximum points that they gave no suggestion that they were weaker for the absence through injury of the man who has sourced so many of their ideas, the former Scotland international John Collins.

Starting a First Division fixture for the first time in his place was Fabrice Fernandes and he splendidly contributed to their devastating rhythms as the Londoners resumed their place on top of the table with all the ease of a Sunday stroll.

Yet it was his fellow Frenchman Louis Saha who drew most credit from this perfor mance with a first-half hat-trick that began on six minutes when he headed home Fernandes' free-kick.

There was so little resistance it was a wonder that another 24 minutes passed before Saha stroked in his second after Barry Hayles had seen his shot kept out by Keith Miller.

In between Mike Sheron put the ball into the net only for an offside flag to be raised - errantly, according to Dave Bassett after watching television replays - and the same player also scooped over an invitation to equalise.

"I was not too disappointed with our first-half display but clearly at 3-0 down the deckchairs are up and the cigars are out and they gave us a torrid second half," admitted the Barnsley manager.

On the Ward oversight Bassett added: "Nothing surprises me in football. But, to be honest, I'm much more concerned the officials see other things such as offside decisions."

Saha's third before the break came from a penalty after Hayles, first executing an audacious Pele-style feint, fed Bjarne Goldbaek, who was brought down by Miller. The referee got his card selection exactly right on that occasion, showing the goalkeeper yellow.

During Barnsley's "torrid" period Fulham scored twice but that was a meagre return for the number of times they sliced apart the defensive cover.

Fernandes hit the post and Hayles twice went close before scoring from Saha's low centre. Greed and complacency set in but there was a fifth for the substitute Luis Boa Morte at the end after Matt Appleby had rolled in a solitary reply.

Even now Fulham had sufficient energy to head off for the swimming baths and a warm-down.
