fields.headline: Staying put
fields.standfirst: The humanitarian motives are to be applauded, says Ewen MacAskill of the decision to keep British troops in Sierra Leone. But more still could be achieved in cooperation with the UN
fields.trailText: The humanitarian motives are to be applauded, says Ewen MacAskill of the decision to keep British troops in Sierra Leone. But more still could be achieved in cooperation with the UN.
fields.body:
The death of a British paratrooper has focused attention on why the UK is involved in an African civil war. The Conservatives called for British troops to be withdrawn, claiming the soldiers had no clear role and that peacekeeping should be left to the UN force stationed there.

Both foreign secretary Robin Cook and defence secretary Geoff Hoon rejected the demand: British forces will be staying.

Since the end of the Cold War ten years ago, the West has had to rethink its military strategy. No longer confronting the Soviet Union along the German border, both the US and Britain have taken up the cry of intervention for humanitarian reasons. Most conflicts in the last ten years have been within states rather than between them. Was the world to stand by and watch, or should it do what it could to help?

It is a controversial policy. At the UN millennium summit last week, countries such as Russia and China remain suspicious of intervention for humanitarian purposes, wondering if it was just an opportunity for the west to meddle.

The US, since the loss of soldiers in Somalia, has drawn back from intervention, unless it is "cost-free" to the US: bombing by air and keeping its ground troops out of harm's way as in Iraq and Kosovo. But Britain is prepared to commit ground troops, and is doing so in Bosnia, Kosovo and Sierra Leone.

The intervention is Sierra Leone is a moral one. In spite of suspicion on the left that Britain only acts in its own national self-interest, there is no political or strategic interest for Britain in this part of west Africa. There is no oil and Britain cannot lay claim to Sierra Leone's diamond industry.

Ministers such as Robin Cook and international development secretary Clare Short have visited Sierra Leone and have been appalled by the atrocities inflicted on the civilian population by the rebel forces. The British government's argument is that its ability to intervene worldwide is limited but wherever it can make a difference, it will.

While parts of the Sierra Leone government are dubious - such as the presence in the cabinet of Johnny Paul Koroma, the former leader of the West Side Boys - the rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF) is much worse. The hacking off of limbs as standard practice has alienated world opinion against them.

The British strategy is to train the Sierra Leone army to a level at which it can fight and beat the RUF: that will take years.

The population round Freetown profess their thanks that the British troops are there and when the bulk of them pulled out in June, it was in the face of pleas by the Sierra Leone government to stay.

Where the British position is weak is in its refusal to serve under the UN flag. As the Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman Menzies Campbell argued yesterday, Britain should contribute to the UN force rather than continue as a separate force.

After all, the UN force is in disarray at present. It had 500 of its peacekeepers taken hostage by the RUF in May, though they have subsequently been released. But there is much internal fighting, especially between the tough Nigerian contingent and the Indians.

UN peacekeepers have had a bad decade, suffering humiliation in Rwanda, Bosnia and Sierra Leone. It needs a success. The people of Sierra Leone do too.

As the Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman Menzies Campbell argued yesterday, Britain should contribute to the UN force rather than continue as a separate force. After all, the UN force is in disarray at present. It had 500 of its peacekeepers taken hostage by the RUF in May, though they have subsequently been released. But there is much internal fighting, especially between the tough Nigerian contingent and the Indians. UN peacekeepers have had a bad decade, suffering humiliation in Rwanda, Bosnia and Sierra Leone. It needs a success. The people of Sierra Leone do too. ewen.macaskill@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Black to sell Jerusalem Post
fields.trailText: The Jerusalem Post, one of the world's most famous newspapers, has been put up for sale for at least $80m (£56m) by Conrad Black's Hollinger International, the owner of the Daily Telegraph.
fields.byline: John Cassy  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
The Jerusalem Post, one of the world's most famous newspapers, has been put up for sale for at least $80m (£56m) by Conrad Black's Hollinger International, the owner of the Daily Telegraph.

Investment bank Morgan Stanley's New York office is conducting an auction of the title which has a loyal following among Jewish communities worldwide. More than three-quarters of the hits on the Jerusalem Post's popular jpost.com website come from the United States.

The auction comes a month after Mr Black sold the bulk of his Canadian newspapers and magazines to CanWest Global Communications, Canada's third largest television network, for £1.6bn.

Mr Black has owned the Jerusalem Post since 1990, during which time he has shifted its political allegiance from the left to the right of Israeli politics. It has also developed links with The Wall Street Journal and successfully embraced the internet.

Jpost.com has become one of the most visited newspaper websites and is a potentially lucrative source of e-commerce and advertising revenues.

Several bidders are thought to have held talks with Morgan Stanley including Michael Sinclair, publisher of the London Jewish News, though it is thought his offer of about $20m was turned down. Mr Black is believed to be prepared to hold on to the title until the right offer emerges.

The Post's readership, made up of immigrants from English-speaking countries and an older generation of Israelis of Central European extraction who never entirely mastered Hebrew, remains static and is believed to stand at under 30,000. Since 1998, the Post has been challenged by the liberal Ha'aretz newspaper which launched an eight-page English language edition as an insert in the International Herald Tribune.

Many of the Post's readers drifted to Ha'aretz though the paper has solid support from orthodox English-speaking immigrants who support its rightwing policies.

Mr Black first bought into the Telegraph Group in 1985 when he took a 15% stake and the group under Lord Hartwell was struggling. Within six months he had control of the newspapers. Four years later they were making a profit.

Last year the Hollinger group had revenues of $2.1bn (£1.3bn) and had an operating profit of just under $213m.

Parsimonious publisher turned deaf ear to breaking news

The defining moment of the Hollinger era of ownership of the Jerusalem Post arrived with the outbreak of the Gulf war in 1991, writes Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem.

The news that American missiles had landed on Iraq broke at 2am local time but the publisher refused to pay the printers overtime so the Post was the sole Israeli paper not to cover the attack on the night.

Such cost-cutting zeal, and a marked shift to the right, have eroded the reputation of the Post since Conrad Black acquired it in 1989. Within months, the takeover prompted the walkout of 29 of the Post's most seasoned journalists in a protest against editorial interference.

Many saw the walkout as the beginning of the end for the Post. Founded in 1932, the paper over the decades had managed to transcend its status as a small town newspaper by virture of its location in a country that is a news treadmill. It earned an international reputation for thoroughness and reliability, and for tolerating a wide range of opinion.

That changed when Hollinger came into the picture. The intifada, the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories that erupted in 1987, sharpened focus on the management's move of the paper to the right of Israeli politics. Since the election last year of a more liberal prime minister, Ehud Barak, the Post has shifted back towards the centre, in response to the changing realities in Israel.

However, the Post relies heavily on foreign news agencies reporting Israeli politics and diplomacy, running the material unattributed under the bylines of its poorly paid and largely young staff.

fields.headline: Government launches £1bn UK Online drive
fields.trailText: The government today launched a £1bn drive to get all of its services online by 2005.
fields.body:
The government today launched a £1bn drive to get all of its services online by 2005.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, unveiled initiatives for the UK Online project at a speech in Loughborough, as part of his drive to get business, people and the government hooked up to the internet.

Some £15m of the funding is to be allocated to small businesses, and 600 online centres are being set up to provide internet access in poorer communities.

Mr Blair also disclosed details of the first annual report by government e-envoy Alex Allan, who recently submitted his resignation. It states that 90% of workers are employed in businesses connected to the internet and a third of the UK population is online.

Additionally, it claims the UK is Europe's largest e-commerce market, with £2bn spent online last year.

"I am determined that by 2005 at the latest all government services will be online. The whole shape of our economy will be changed by this new technology, that's why UK Online is so vital," said Mr Blair.

Meanwhile, technology company Cityspace has revealed a service that will make it easier for people to pay their TV licence. The scheme involves roadside kiosks, called I-plus, that will enable consumers to pay for their licence without incurring domestic web connection charges or having to queue at the post office.

The six-month trial is intended as a precursor to more high-street-based e-government initiatives, including electronic payment services for council tax, rent and parking fines.

The I-plus kiosks were in March launched by Cityspace and outdoor advertising specialist Adshel.

webTitle: Granada Media buys stake in TV3

fields.headline: Granada Media buys stake in Irish broadcaster
fields.trailText: Granada Media makes inroads into Ireland with 45% stake in Irish broadcaster TV3. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Granada Media took its first steps into Ireland today when it unveiled a 45% stake in Irish broadcaster TV3 for £18.7m in cash.

The deal will see Granada's major programme brands, such as Coronation Street and Emmerdale, move from Irish state broadcaster RTE to TV3 from next year.

Granada bought the stake from Canada's CanWest Global Communications, which retains 45% of the commercial broadcaster.

The move forms part of Granada's planned push into Europe and its new strategy to be vertically integrated as a broadcaster in key European markets.

The two-year-old TV3 is now Ireland's third most watched channel with an audience share of around 10%.

fields.headline: Lastminute.com hit by drop in share price
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com's share price tumbled in early trading as private investors jumped ship. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com's share price tumbled 6% in early trading as private investors jumped ship following the end of the six-month lock-up on their shares.

The online booking agent's stock fell 12.5p to 172.5p this morning, in stark contrast to its offer price of 380p in March. Co-founders Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox own 17% of the company, but a spokesperson said they have no intention of selling their shares.

Heidi Fitzpatrick, analyst at Lehman Brothers, said: "Retail investors have panicked because of the negative press coverage of the company, and I expect some of the venture capital backers to sell. The valuation of the company is not very challenging at the moment, and I would not be surprised if they put their cash elsewhere."

The company's investors include Global Retail Partners and venture capitalists Arts Alliance, though today's low volume of trading in Lastminute shares showed the big stakeholders were not releasing their shares onto the market.

Lastminute's fortunes have showed signs of improvement over the past month, with the £59.8m acquisition of French rival Degriftour and the announcement that the company has enough money to last until mid-2002.

Lastminute's turnover from April to June this year was £1.01m, with pre-tax narrowing from £11m to £9.2m. The small revenues and big losses make it difficult to put a value on the company, which has cash reserves of £100m thanks to its flotation.

webTitle: Channel 4's West Wing wins nine Emmys

fields.headline: Channel 4's West Wing bags nine Emmys
fields.standfirst: Full list of Emmy Award-winners
fields.trailText: A series expected to form part of Channel 4s new E4 line-up cleaned up at last nights Emmys award ceremony in Los Angeles.
fields.body:
A series expected to form part of Channel 4s new E4 line-up cleaned up at last nights Emmys award ceremony in Los Angeles.

The West Wing, from John Wells Productions, aired its first season on Sky One, but Channel 4 now owns both terrestrial and satellite rights to the show and is expected to save it for its new youth and entertainment channel due to launch later this year.

Starring Martin Sheen as the US President, the West Wing portrays life among the staffers of the White House. It took home a record-breaking nine awards last night, including best drama series. Previous multi-award winners, Hill Street Blues and ER, have only managed eight awards.

Channel 4 has owned terrestrial rights to the series for 18 months, but chief executive Michael Jackson has always maintained that mainstream British audiences would not tune in to a show about US politics.

From the UK, the BBCs animated natural history series, Walking With Dinosaurs, took three Emmys including best animated programme of more than 60 minutes. It also took technical honours in special effects and sound editing.

Comedian Eddie Izzard won two Emmys - writing and performance - for a video version of his last stage show, and actress Vanessa Redgrave was honoured for her supporting role in the TV movie, If These Walls Could Talk.

Best comedy series went to Will and Grace, while Michael J Fox, who recently quit his role in Spin City due to illness, won the best comedy actor award. He received a standing ovation from the audience.

fields.headline: Eddie Izzard
fields.trailText: Eddie Izzard is the flavour of the month in LA after scooping two Emmys on Sunday. Check out what's given him such success - online.
fields.body:
1. So Eddie Izzard scooped two awards at last night's Emmy television awards for the video version of his last stage show, Eddie Izzard: Dress to Kill. (No, not that Dressed to Kill.)

2. But alas, Izzard wasn't there to pick up his awards - too busy working, according to some.

3. But take heart, Izzard did see off competition from US chat show heavyweights The Late Show With David Letterman and Late Night With Conan O'Brien to win the coveted awards - which were for best variety special performance and writing, if you must know.

4. No doubt it was filming his next movie, All the Queen's Men (a second world war action comedy), in a former army camp in Austria with co-stars Matt Le Blanc and James Cosmo that kept him away from LA. This movie has already sparked a row with Jewish groups, apparently, over its lighthearted portrayal of the Nazi regime.

5. And it wasn't all fun and laughter at the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences awards, either. The Emmys are struggling to keep up with the times, and failing, says the Washington Post. And many actors wore golden ribbons to the ceremony to show support for the entertainment industry's longest ever strike.

6. Still wondering who won what? It's all here. Don't know, and don't care? Join the naysayers.

7. But for those of us still enamoured with life on planet celeb, there's plenty of ground to cover here - impress your friends with Emmys trivia, check out what everyone was wearing and watch some of the nominated shows.

8. According to his official Emmys biog, Eddie is "Britain's hottest comic". Even more reason then, to make sure you gen up on Eddie trivia for all those "isn't Eddie Izzard great - he just won two Emmy's, you know" conversations that are bound to come up over the water cooler this week. Just to get you started, did you know Izzard is Eddie's real last name. And it must be true, because his official website says so.

9. And should you need further insight into the man, the make-up and his latest movie, it turns out Eddie's been talking to the Daily Telegraph.

10. And if you already know more about Eddie than you care to mention, there are three must-dos today congratulate Eddie on his win here, bookmark another devoted fan's site here, and celebrate with fellow Izzardites in a chatroom.

fields.headline: Tesco mulls magazine distribution compromise
fields.trailText: The distribution row between Tesco and the magazine industry has eased after the PPA said the supermarket group had agreed to consider a compromise.
fields.body:
The distribution row between Tesco and the magazine industry has eased after the Periodical Publishers' Association said the supermarket group had agreed to consider a compromise.

Tesco's plan to take magazine deliveries from just one national distributor, the wholesaler WH Smith News, stunned magazine publishers when it was announced earlier this year. Magazines are currently distributed via a regional franchise network.

Tesco has now agreed to consider a compromise put forward by the PPA and based on the existing distribution system. The PPA said its proposals focus on "improving the consumer offer, reducing waste, simplifying the supply chain and increasing magazine sales, whilst at the same time ensuring the competition exists for the provision of these services".

Ian Locks, chief executive of the PPA, said: "We are delighted Tesco has indicated its wish to work with the industry to build on the existing wholesaler supply chain to create improvements which would include a sales-based replenishment system leading to reduced waste."

The PPA objects to changes proposed by Tesco. It argues that once Tesco and other major chains are stripped out of the franchises, distributors will find it uneconomic to deliver magazines to smaller retailers.

A recent report suggested such a move by Tesco would ultimately result in the closure of up to 12,000 newsagents and the loss of 15,000 jobs.

Tesco and WH Smith sell almost 25 per cent of all periodicals, and the wholesale division supplies more than 40% of the market. The PPA says this would rise to more than 50%.

The distribution deal covers only magazines, but the Newspaper Publishers' Association has expressed concern about the consequences of rural newsagents being forced out of business.

fields.headline: Tesco moots distribution compromise
fields.trailText: The PPA has announced that Tesco has agreed to consider a compromise in the long-running distribution dispute.
fields.body:
The long-running distribution row between Tesco and the magazine industry could soon be resolved after the Periodical Publishers' Association said the supermarket group had agreed to consider a compromise.

Tesco's plan to take magazine deliveries from just one national distributor, the wholesaler WH Smith News, stunned magazine publishers when it was announced earlier this year. The supermarket chain said it was frustrated by the reluctance of the magazine industry to change what it described as an "archaic, creaky and monopolistic" distribution system, whereby magazines are distributed via a regional franchise network. Under the current system, retailers have no choice about which distributor they use.

A recent report suggested such a move by Tesco could ultimately result in the closure of up to 12,000 newsagents and the loss of 15,000 jobs.

The distribution deal only covers magazines, but the Newspaper Publishers' Association had expressed concern about the consequences of rural newsagents being forced out of business.

fields.headline: Sir Julian Critchley
fields.standfirst: The rebel Conservative MP who gently satirised his own party, along with all the other foibles of political life at Westminster
fields.trailText: The rebel Conservative MP who gently satirised his own party, along with all the other foibles of political life at Westminster.
fields.body:
Sir Julian Critchley, who has died of cancer aged 69, was a long-standing Conservative back bench MP who never obtained political office or exercised much formal influence. But he did win much acclaim, and had a public reputation that was far greater than was accorded to most ministers, because of his writing; it was witty and urbane, gently satirising Westminster from an avowed liberal standpoint. He maintained this gift even after he had been physically disabled by the recurrence of teenage polio.

His early political life, at Shrewsbury school and at Pembroke College, Oxford, partnered that of Michael Heseltine. They were close friends and Critchley was the best man at Heseltine's wedding. Even in those days, Critchley showed clear traces of robust independence and a commitment to Tory liberalism.

For much of his political life, he was at odds with the Whips' Office, sometimes for his views and sometimes for the cavalier way he approached the serious business of Westminster politics. Critchley was once rebuked for modelling a suit for Town, a mildly trendy men's magazine in the early 1960s. The objection was absurd and Critchley was disposed to laugh off such incidents. This calculated indifference of his, while understandable, was a trait he might well have corrected; but he was not deferential by nature.

He had little affection for Thatcherite politics or its leading practitioners. During the John Major years, he was happily reconciled to mainstream Conservatism, believing that Major as prime minister should resist any drift to the right, and avowing that Richard Ryder was the best chief whip he had known (not a difficult accolade to award).

On key votes Critchley would travel from his home in Ludlow to Westminster to be "nodded through", so that he could support such major measures as value added tax on domestic fuel. These loyal journeys were undertaken in great pain, and the gesture of support was much admired.

Critchley entered parliament in the 1959 general election as MP for Rochester and Chatham. He was then aged 28, but having captured this marginal seat he lost it again at the election in 1964. He was returned for Aldershot in the 1970 election and held the seat until 1997, when he did not seek re-election.

The broken Westminster service between 1964 and 1970 was crucial to Critchley's political career. He was a liberal Tory, supporting one-nation social policies, membership of the European Community, and a defence policy based on Nato and a nuclear strategy. He would have been a natural and able young ally for Edward Heath, campaigning for him against the Conservative right, which was increasingly hostile to the Rome Treaty and current levels of public spending. No one can say how Critchley would have handled his opportunities had he remained in Westminster between 1964 and 1970.

He had a lively mind and was a competent parliamentarian who knew the value of the short speech - and the short article, for, according to his colleagues, nobody could write quicker and better for the Guardian. Apart from Europe, his interests were primarily defence, on which he inspired a Bow Group pamphlet, and the politics of the media. He despised the trivia and, as he saw it, the bogus morality of the tabloids.

He was always vulnerable because of his irreverent humour, which could lead to incautious and overt disrespect. If he had been able to reign back this, and with application surely he could, then opposition service during the parliaments of the 1960s could have ensured office in the 1970-74 Heath administration. This was not to be. Soon, he was politically marginalised by the triumph of Margaret Thatcher. He doubted her policies and even more the self-righteous way in which they were promoted.

Critchley then developed the alternative career that delighted the wide audience that enjoyed his witty political comment. He did not come to politics when he used his pen at university. He wrote sparingly during the 1959 parliament, but after his defeat he widened his journalistic experience and, in 1970, became editor of Town magazine, part of Heseltine's Haymarket Press; it did not prosper under Critchley's guidance. But this did not deter him, and over the years he developed a skill in portraying politics, particularly those of the Conservative party. His victims more often smiled than squirmed. He contributed to most national papers and appeared on radio and television.

His new career had its hazards. The combination of his views and casual approach to politics sorely tested some Conservative activists in his Aldershot constituency. Incautiously, he wrote an anonymous, disparaging and vastly amusing article in the Observer about Mrs Thatcher. Predictably the authorship became public, and a force nine storm followed. Critchley survived, but he always needed a praetorian guard of local party friends to ensure his hold on the association.

His autobiography, A Bag of Boiled Sweets, published in 1994, was a success, revealing his ability to write beyond the world of politics and detailing his boyhood successes in the boxing ring. His most ambitious political book was Heseltine: The Unauthorised Biography. Critchley was immensely proud of his Shropshire heritage, which he related most evocatively in his autobiography. In the early 1990s, he retired to Ludlow, almost immobilised by ill-health. He was knighted at the behest of John Major in 1995.

He had been twice married, with two daughters by his first wife, whom he divorced in 1965, and a son and a daughter by his second. He had great charm, was a bon viveur, and a delightful conversational companion. These qualities continued to shine through his worsening illness.

webTitle: Millionaire in ratings scrap with Big Brother

fields.headline: Millionaire in ratings scrap with Big Brother
fields.trailText: Two of televisions most-hyped shows went head to head this weekend but while Big Brother continues to inflate Channel 4s share, the exocet missile effect of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? proved less beneficial to ITV.
fields.body:
Two of televisions most-hyped shows went head to head this weekend but while Big Brother continues to inflate Channel 4s share, the exocet missile effect of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? proved less beneficial to ITV.

Millionaire, ruefully likened by the BBC to a warhead, underperformed by its own admittedly high standards on Thursday night against BBC1s popular Vets in Practice. Both came away honourably  sick animals pulled in 7.0m, a 30% share of the total audience, while Millionaire snared 10.6m viewers, a 46% share.

By Friday, the picture changed. Millionaire, broadcast an hour later after the Bill, dropped to 9.3m, a 41 % share, while Channel 4 sandwiched its US comedy staples with Mels eviction from Big Brother. At 8.30pm, Big Brother pulled 5.5m viewers, a 26% share, beating BBC1 and 2s combined audience for Police Dog Academy and the Proms. More impressively, the post-eviction interview got 4.8m, a 35% share, after 11pm.

Proving that Parky viewers march to their own drum, the Yorkshire interviewer returned with 7.9m at 9.30pm, a 37% share. His audience gradually built through to Martin Scorseses scary Cape Fear at 10.30pm which was too much for most viewers, who went to bed or switched over to Eurotrash on Channel 4.

Saturday morning brought bad news for BBC1. As the corporation unveiled its new presenter line-up for flagship kids' show Live and Kicking, which replaces FBI later this month, ITVs far hipper equivalent, SMTV Live, showed Katy Hill et al the challenge ahead by recording a 38% share of the viewing audience compared with FBIs 16%.

In primetime, the patriotism of the Last Night of the Proms failed to impress the majority of viewers, raising just 4.4m viewers, a 27% share. ITVs Millionaire (46%) gave Lily Live a good run-in, which the topical show held reasonably well with 6.6m, a 30% share.

Channel 4 and BBC2 meanwhile ran neck and neck with their compilation shows. 1977 night on BBC2 ran from 16% to 13% for Saturday Night Fever, while Channel 4s 100 Greatest TV Moments From Hell averaged 17% of the audience.

Sunday night saw Millionaire record its best performance of the weekend for ITV on traditionally its strongest night of the week. A 52% share of the audience (12.8m viewers) tuned in, leaving 7.8m (35%) for Where Theres Smoke, a new two-part drama which concludes tonight.

Earlier in a strong day for ITV, the Italian Grand Prix rated a 39% share and Coronation Street took 65% with 15m viewers. ITV recorded an overall share of 25.5% on Sunday, streets ahead of everyone else and over 10% more than the previous Sunday. If only it were always that simple.

fields.headline: Fingerprint technology on the way
fields.standfirst: Amid mounting concerns over security on the internet, new technologies are being developed which could revolutionise policing the web, writes Mark Tran
fields.trailText: Amid mounting concerns over security on the internet, new technologies are being developed which could revolutionise policing the web, writes Mark Tran.
fields.body:
Internet bank Egg recently foiled Britain's first alleged attempted online bank robbery amid warnings that "virtual bank raids" will be on the rise as internet banking becomes more popular.

Using software developed in tandem with the police, three people were arrested following a six-month investigation and were last month released on bail pending further enquiries.

Egg's brush with cybercriminals illustrates the dilemma facing consumers and businesses alike as they conduct more and more transactions online. Today consumers buy anything from books to medication over the internet. Businesses are setting up electronic exchanges to buy and sell products from each other.

In the US alone last year, online sales, according to the Boston Consulting Group, exceeded $36bn (£24bn) and a recent report by the Gartner Group estimates that worldwide B2B ecommerce will exceed $7,000bn by 2004. As online transactions grow, security becomes an ever more urgent issue.

For the most part, security comes in the form of passwords, an archaic practice that can quickly degenerate into password hell. IT departments spend an inordinate amount of time helping out employees who have forgotten them. Yet users are warned not to simplify too much because of the security risks.

Such risks are real enough, given the regular reports of security breaches of computer systems in both government and commerce (though people tend to forget how easy it is to pinch credit card numbers from discarded carbon copies and they have no qualms about giving credit card information over the phone).

The scope for mischief is likely to grow with America, Britain and Ireland circumspectly passing laws making digital signatures legally binding. As the problem of online security looms larger, several US companies are pushing biometrics as the answer.

In biometrics, identification is based on physical characteristics such as voice, irises, hands, fingers or fingerprints. Familiar from police identity parades and fingerprinting, biometrics has taken a hi-tech twist with the internet.

In the US, the International Biometric Industry Association speaks for what many think could tie up internet security concerns, with companies vying for position in what they believe to be a growing market.

Veridicom, a US biometrics company, for example, is busy spreading the gospel in Europe after having seen its fingerprint system adopted by NEC in some laptop models. In order to get access to a computer, a user places a fingerprint on a laptop, that has to correspond with a pre-recorded print.

"This is a very hot and growing market," says Naseem Zafar, vice-president of marketing of Veridicom, during a whirlwind European tour. Mr Zafar claims that procurement costs will drop from $175 or $150 per item to a mere $6 with the use of biometric technology, cutting out waste and duplication.

Ibia says sales of biometric technology will reach $100m this year, rising to $600m by 2003. Though new, the field is already crowded. There are at least six American companies specialising in fingerprint identification. Others have gone down the route of irises (as seen in Mission: Impossible), faces, hands and signature recognition.

The biometric industry does not claim to have invented the "silver bullet" that will solve security concerns, but argues that a multilayered system using biometrics in conjunction with other devices such as smart cards or digital certificates - which verify particular personal computers as the origin of electronic transactions - offers the best protection in the internet age.

But the use of biometrics does raise privacy issues. Critics worry that their use increases the power of organisations over individuals and warn of "function creep", or the use of biometric data for purposes not originally intended.

Simon Davies, a visiting fellow at the University of Essex, points out that uses of the social security number in the US, the social insurance number in Canada and the tax file number in Australia were gradually extended to include taxation, unemployment support, pensioner benefits and in some cases health and higher education.

There is also the possibility that biometrics will fail to live up to expectations. "Many systems do not live up to expectations because they prove unable to cope with the enormous variations among populations, or fail to take into account the practicalities of human behaviour, and the needs of people," Davies says.

Despite concerns over the biometrics field, it is conceivable that people may value convenience and security over privacy. As more and more people conduct transactions such as banking and shopping via the internet over different platforms, including TV, mobile phones and the computer, they will want be sure that they are not getting ripped off by cybercriminals.

In which case, biometrics will become commonplace, alongside smart cards, and perhaps password hell will be relegated to the technological graveyard.

Privacy International

webTitle: Blair launches fresh drive to get Britain online

fields.headline: Blair launches fresh drive to get Britain online
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today launched a £1bn drive to get all government services online by 2005.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today launched a £1bn drive to get all government services online by 2005.

The prime minister also said that £15m would be allocated to help businesses benefit from the internet and announced the first raft of 600 online centres to give hi-tech access to poorer communities.

Mr Blair, speaking in Loughborough, Leicestershire, said that the UK Online initiatives were designed to get business, people and government hooked up to the internet. "My argument is simple. There is no new economy. There is one economy, all of it being transformed by information technology.

"What is happening is no dot.com fad that will come and go - it is a profound economic revolution. Business and government must now be in a constant process of adapting to change.

"The key to success is knowledge - and the key to government is investment in education and skills."

Mr Blair also disclosed details of the first annual report produced by the government's "e-envoy", Alex Allan.

The prime minister said Britain now had the best off-peak rates for connection to the internet in the world. He said the UK peak access prices had fallen by 30% to 40% since last year and he expected the country to go "shooting up the league table".

Mr Blair said that 90% of workers were now employed in businesses connected to the internet and that a third of the UK population was now online, with the country boasting Europe's largest e-commerce market with £2bn spending last year.

He said a new campaign would be launched to make Britain the best place in the world for e-commerce, with universal access to the internet and all government services on the net.

Mr Blair added: "I am determined that by 2005 at the latest all government services will be online, so we are today announcing that our recent spending review earmarked £1bn for investment in electronic service delivery over the next three years."

He said that from next year unemployed people would be able to search job vacancies from home or in a Job Centre kiosk, place job adverts online or register for VAT online.

"The whole shape of our economy will be changed by this new technology - that's why UK Online is so vital. If we live up to the challenge of the knowledge economy, we can reverse the decades of decline we suffered in the 20th century and become one of the world's most successful economies in the 21st century."

webTitle: Duchess of York in US ad campaign

fields.headline: Fergie leads US campaign against heart disease
fields.trailText: The Duchess of York has taken on what could be her biggest challenge yet - persuading Americans to adopt a healthier lifestyle.
fields.body:
The Duchess of York has taken on what could be her biggest challenge yet - persuading Americans to adopt a healthier lifestyle.

The duchess has agreed to spearhead a new campaign for the American Heart Association. Already famous in the US for her work with WeightWatchers, she will promote the association's key messages on good health and heart disease prevention. One of the key aims of the campaign is to alert people to the early signs of a heart attack or stroke.

"It is terrible but a fact of life that so many people suffer from heart disease," she said. "However, for the majority, we can all make the choice to have a healthier heart through diet, exercise and by not smoking."

The campaign will target women and will focus on the risk factors they can address. These include obesity, smoking, physical inactivity and high cholesterol. The duchess has already recorded a series of public service announcements to help educate Americans about the warning signs of a heart attack.

The duchess made her first commercial in 1997, for the Ocean Spray brand of fruit juice. Since then she has become famous for her work with WeightWatchers in the US, but has always refused to appear in advertising that would appear in the UK.

fields.headline: Bodies of 58 Chinese immigrants identified
fields.trailText: Detectives have identified all of the 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in the back of a lorry at Dover, police said today.
fields.body:
Detectives have identified all of the 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in the back of a lorry at Dover, police said today.

Nearly three months after the deaths of the 54 young men and four young women, a team of investigators from Kent police have determined their identities. They will not be named until Detective Superintendent Dennis McGookin, who led the investigation, returns from China.

Det Supt McGookin flew to China last Monday with two other senior detectives to meet families in the Fujian province believed to be relatives of the deceased.

They took DNA samples from the dead with them and compared these with blood taken from people thought to be relatives.

Before the mission to China, police had only been able to formally identify four of the Chinese immigrants through investigations in Britain.

The police spokesman said: "We are pleased with how successful the trip has been. The Chinese police and government have been very cooperative and a lot of people have come forward in China. People were desperate to find out whether their loved ones were involved."

Chinese authorities introduced the British detectives to the families and explaining their mission.

Det Supt McGookin and his team are due to fly back to Britain in the next couple of days. The names of the deceased are expected to be released after his return, when he has reviewed the investigation into the deaths.

Customs officers discovered the 58 bodies - and two survivors - in a sealed lorry container at the port in Kent on June 18.

An inquest heard the closure of an air vent on the side of the metal refrigeration container during a ferry crossing from Zeebrugge in Belgium to Dover caused them to suffocate through a lack of oxygen and carbon dioxide build-up.

Lorry driver Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, Netherlands, has been charged with 58 counts of manslaughter and with people-smuggling offences. Chef You Yi, 38, and 29-year-old female interpreter Ying Guo, of South Woodford, Essex, are jointly charged with conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry into the UK.

All three are in custody awaiting trial. Nine people are also in custody in Holland charged with people smuggling.

Nearly three months after the deaths of the 54 young men and four young women, a team of investigators from Kent police have determined their identities. They will not be named until Detective Superintendent Dennis McGookin, who led the investigation, returns from China. Det Supt McGookin flew to China last Monday with two other senior detectives to meet families in the Fujian province believed to be relatives of the deceased. They took DNA samples from the dead with them and compared these with blood taken from people thought to be relatives. Before the mission to China, police had only been able to formally identify four of the Chinese immigrants through investigations in Britain. The police spokesman said: "We are pleased with how successful the trip has been. The Chinese police and government have been very cooperative and a lot of people have come forward in China. People were desperate to find out whether their loved ones were involved." Chinese authorities introduced the British detectives to the families and explaining their mission. Det Supt McGookin and his team are due to fly back to Britain in the next couple of days. The names of the deceased are expected to be released after his return, when he has reviewed the investigation into the deaths. Customs officers discovered the 58 bodies - and two survivors - in a sealed lorry container at the port in Kent on June 18. An inquest heard the closure of an air vent on the side of the metal refrigeration container during a ferry crossing from Zeebrugge in Belgium to Dover caused them to suffocate through a lack of oxygen and carbon dioxide build-up. Lorry driver Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, Netherlands, has been charged with 58 counts of manslaughter and with people-smuggling offences. Chef You Yi, 38, and 29-year-old female interpreter Ying Guo, of South Woodford, Essex, are jointly charged with conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry into the UK. All three are in custody awaiting trial. Nine people are also in custody in Holland charged with people smuggling.

webTitle: Mark Butcher helps Surrey to the brink of the title

fields.headline: Mark Butcher helps Surrey to the brink of the title
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we get the lowdown from behind the scenes on one of the county performances of the week. Today we talk to Surrey and England opener Mark Butcher, whose 191 against Durham took his side to the verge of their second-successive County Championship
fields.trailText: Mark Butcher and Ian Ward put on 359 for Surrey's first wicket against Durham last week, paving the way for a crushing victory by an innings and 68 runs. The pair batted throughout a truncated first day and recorded Surrey's fourth-highest opening stand before Ward was dismissed for a 329-ball 144. Butcher then added 54 with Nadeem Shahid and was bowled by Steve Harmison for 191 from 344 balls. The win ensured maximum bonus points and left Surrey needing just one point in this week's match against Lancashire at Old Trafford to retain the Championship. Mark Butcher takes up the story.
fields.body:
Mark Butcher and Ian Ward put on 359 for Surrey's first wicket against Durham last week, paving the way for a crushing victory by an innings and 68 runs. The pair batted throughout a truncated first day and recorded Surrey's fourth-highest opening stand before Ward was dismissed for a 329-ball 144. Butcher then added 54 with Nadeem Shahid and was bowled by Steve Harmison for 191 from 344 balls. The win ensured maximum bonus points and left Surrey needing just one point in this week's match against Lancashire at Old Trafford to retain the Championship. Mark Butcher takes up the story.

"When Adam Hollioake looked at the pitch and asked me what I wanted to do if we won the toss I just said 'bat' and walked off! It was the only thing on my mind.

"We did win the toss and it was rather gloomy out there to start with. The ball swung a bit but we were off for the light after three or four overs and came back around 15 before lunch.

"Steve Harmison found hitting the pitch a bit difficult - at one stage the scoreboard was [Ian] Ward 8, Butcher 9, Extras 31! Actually it was rather worrying that he might suddenly come up with a jaffa and take you by surprise. We were aware he's not terrible and it can be unnerving just waiting for that straight one. I was concentrating hard - pretty focussed for such an important game. We just wanted to make the most of batting first and get at least 400 for maximum bonus points.

"I like batting with Ward. We move between the wickets well together and that can get us off to a flying start; sometimes it's even better than hitting boundaries. When the ball's moving around, ones or twos to fine leg are important. In the middle we were saying to each other that we mustn't hand over the responsibility to the others. It's been a tough season for batsmen and we were both well set. It was up to us.

"We were scoring at the same rate, but we weren't racing. There were little periods when one or the other would go ahead, but we were concentrating on getting points. I got to 100 one ball before he did in the last session of the day, turning the offspinner [Nicky Phillips] to square for a single.

"Harmison aside, the rest of the Durham bowlers tried to keep it tight and swing it with the new ball. We had to get over that and make them work very hard. A message came out before lunch on the second day saying we were something like 80 short of the record first-class opening partnership for Surrey. Unluckily Ward was out soon after. Records are nice to have afterwards but they don't really occur to you when you're batting. A 400 opening partnership would have been fantastic - we had both set our minds on getting those five points.

"Nadeem Shahid came in - he's great to bat with. He can hit it in a way that is magic to watch, though he's not as quick between the wickets as Ward! Harmison bowled a good spell after lunch on the second day with the new ball: quick and straight. He nipped one back which went between my bat and pad and hit the top of middle stump.

"We only need one point from the match against Lancashire which is fantastic, though it's important for us to win the game after such a good two-thirds of the season. An away win against Lancashire would be a great feather in our cap.

"The success we've achieved over the last two years has come with the same personnel, but we're now playing a lot tougher cricket. We're doing the basics better and are making sure we don't let people back into games. By making fewer basic errors, individuals such as Saqlain [Mushtaq], [Ian] Salisbury, [Martin] Bicknell and [Alistair] Brown can come through.

"If we get the point we'll celebrate, but I don't want to tempt fate. Manchester United are at home to Anderlecht on Wednesday so there'll be quite a crowd within yelling distance of the hotel and lots going on.

"It's been a fantastic summer in the Tests - I've been watching closely. In the past we've been so one-eyed, getting passionate about who's playing, but now people are realising the benefits of winning, whoever's playing. Success gives a good product and the press writes favourably about the game.

"I look back - a couple of decent scores in South Africa and I might have been there. I hadn't found the key to my form in South Africa so it's good for others to come in and help England. I saw Nasser recently and said how well Trescothick's done this summer.

"I hope I'll be in with a shout next summer. I haven't made my plans for the winter yet. I'm quite looking forward to having a quiet one - a bit of football; an English winter. I might be doing a bit of work for Sky and some writing here or there. And the A tour squad hasn't been announced yet..."

Mark Butcher was talking to Matthew Hancock. To read last week's My Day in the Sun, in which Hampshire's Will Kendall shows that even if your team-mates aren't scoring any runs, it doesn't mean you can't, click here

fields.headline: CIA recruits de Pear to head international operations
fields.trailText: The media agency CIA has hired Ron de Pear, former client services director of MindShare, as chairman of its international unit.
fields.body:
The media agency CIA has hired Ron de Pear, former client services director of MindShare, as chairman of its international unit.

De Pear replaces Mainardo de Nardis, who is stepping down after seven years to devote more time to his role as CIA's European chief executive. De Pear, who left MindShare in April to "pursue other interests", joins in mid-September. He will have a place on CIA's European board.

De Nardis said: "We are delighted that Ron is joining CIA. He brings with him an enormous amount of international agency experience, which will help us to develop even further our broad range of media communications expertise. He is highly respected for his management style and will be a great asset to both CIA International and to the group."

De Pear spent over 20 years at J Walter Thompson and MindShare, and was the first media executive to be appointed to the board of JWT. He was made managing partner of MindShare Worldwide when it launched two years ago and was responsible for overseeing international clients including Kellog, Ford, Warner Lambert and Kodak.

fields.headline: Minister opens up immigration debate
fields.trailText: Britain may have to change its laws on immigration if it is to compete in the international marketplace, says a Home Office minister.
fields.body:
Britain may have to change its laws on immigration if it is to compete in the international marketplace, says a Home Office minister.

A demographic time bomb and a shortage of skilled workers in key areas such as IT mean that Britain should consider changing rules allowing people to settle and work in Britain, Home Office minister Barbara Roche said today.

Her comments, made on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, come in advance of a speech later today in which she is expected to call for an open debate on the issue.

"Every country, particularly the EU countries, is looking to see how we can attract the best and the brightest," she said. "We need to make sure that our immigration policy works for us."

She insisted that the issue was entirely separate from that of asylum, which concerned only those fleeing persecution abroad - and dismissed as "absolute and complete nonsense" reports that she was envisaging 100,000 extra immigrants a year under changed rules.

The most likely way forward would be for Britain to adopt a version of the US green card system, which allows migrants and their families the right to settle without awarding them full citizenship.

However the immigration minister stressed that the government has no firm policy plans on the subject at present.

She also called for people to realise that Britain is often not the first choice of potential migrants. "We do live in a global economy, where skilled people are at a premium and it is not always a buyer's market," she noted.

fields.headline: 365 Corporation dials up mobile phone deal
fields.trailText: Internet and telecoms content provider 365 Corporation has responded to its demotion from the TechMark 100 index by snapping up a mobile phone services company.
fields.body:
Internet and telecoms content provider 365 Corporation has responded to its demotion from the TechMark 100 index by snapping up a mobile phone services company.

The £3m acquisition of Phones Express will bolster 365's business division, which sits alongside its network of sports websites. The company left the TechMark 100 index last week after improved first quarter revenues failed to boost a flat share price.

Dan Thompson, 365 chief executive, said: "Phones Express brings us the expertise, infrastructure and distribution to significantly accelerate the execution of our plans in both the business and consumer markets."

Analysts said the Phones Express acquisition was in line with 365's strategy of having a broad portfolio of businesses, with its mobile phone services division set to show strong growth for the rest of the year.

Shares in 365 rose a modest 0.25p in early trading.

webTitle: Commercial lager louts damage world heritage site

fields.headline: Commercial lager louts damage world heritage site
fields.trailText: A camera crew filming a beer commercial has damaged the most important shrine at the Peruvian Inca citadel of Machu Picchu.
fields.byline: Sheila Pulham in Machu Picchu, Peru
fields.body:
A camera crew filming a beer commercial has damaged the most important shrine at the Peruvian Inca citadel of Machu Picchu.

A corner of the granite intihuatana, or "hitching post of the sun", was smashed when a camera platform collapsed on top of it.

The irregular carved pillar, one of several erected by the Incas at major sites, holds special significance as it was the only intihuatana not to have been discovered and destroyed by the Spanish conquistadores.

The structure is thought to have been an astronomical device, possibly used to predict the solstices of the sun, and is reputed to imbue with energy those who approach it.

More than a dozen fragments of rock will be painstakingly reattached, but the changeable and intemperate climate means they could eventually fall off again.

"The damage can probably be repaired but [the intihuatana] will never be quite the same again," said archaeologist Luis Barreda Murillo.

The accident happened during filming of a commercial for Cusqueña beer, which is produced in the Cusco region where Machu Picchu is situated.

Exhausted trekkers, arriving at the ruins after a four-day mountain hike along the Inca trail, watched thirstily as a chilled bottle of the lager and a glass were placed on the intihuatana.

Half a dozen members of the crew held up boards to reflect the bright sunshine, and the hapless cameraman was hoisted into the air to film from above.

He was slightly injured when the overloaded gantry collapsed on the rock.

The commercial was intended as part of a series showcasing the beauty of the Cusco region's historical legacy.

Carlos de la Flor, the managing director of the Cervesur company that makes the beer, says his firm was not to blame for the accident but will do whatever it can to help repair the damaged stone.

The Walter Thompson agency running the advertising campaign has not commented publicly on the incident.

Historians immediately called for a ban on commercial filming at Machu Picchu, South America's most spectacular archaeological site.

The area has been designated a Unesco world heritage site and tourists are strictly policed: backpacks and food are forbidden, and whistle-blowing guards prevent visitors from walking on the walls.

However, there are currently no limits on the commercial exploitation of the ruins, perched dramatically between two Andean peaks above the Urubamba river.

Unesco, alarmed by the rapidly expanding tourist infrastructure at Machu Picchu, has threatened before to designate the area an endangered site.

An unsightly hostel and latrines have been built on the Inca trail, and a planned cable car will increase the tourist crowds still further.

The latest incident will have done little to convince the organisation that the Peruvian authorities take their stated commitment to protect the park seriously.

Built in the 15th century by the Inca emperor Pachacuti, Machu Picchu was abandoned before the 1532 arrival in Peru of the Spanish forces led by Francisco Pizarro.

The forgotten settlement therefore avoided the ravages of the conquistadores and was found to be exceptionally well preserved when it was excavated after being rediscovered in 1911 by the US explorer Hiram Bingham.

webTitle: Stars take strike battle to Emmys

fields.headline: Stars take strike battle to Emmys
fields.trailText: The wearing of golden ribbons at last night's Emmys television awards ceremony in Los Angeles was the latest move by leading actors to try to shame advertisers into settling the longest-running strike ever to hit the entertainment industry.
fields.body:
The wearing of golden ribbons at last night's Emmys television awards ceremony in Los Angeles was the latest move by leading actors to try to shame advertisers into settling the longest-running strike ever to hit the entertainment industry.

This week a new attempt is to be made to settle the actors' strike that is seen as a harbinger of a conflict that could shut down the entire film and television industry next year.

Everyone supporting the strike wore gold ribbons as a sign of solidarity with the 135,000 strikers.

The demonstration came on the eve of a fresh round of talks in a bid to end the strike which was called in April by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Arts in protest at proposals to end the system of residual payments for performing in commercials.

The unions claim that the changes would leave members significantly worse off. Advertisers say that because of the increasing share that cable takes of advertising, they can no longer afford to pay actors at the current rates. The new talks are to be held in New York on Wednesday.

The strike is estimated to be costing the acting profession around $2m (£ 1.4 m) a day.

A member of the Frasier cast, John Mahoney, said: "The actors who do commercials are as much a part of the union as any major star. We're all in this together. Scabs can go to hell."

There is growing anger in the acting profession at the failure to resolve the dispute and fears that it could drag on for months as neither side has given any indication of budging.

Other actors, including Kevin Bacon, Richard Dreyfuss, Harry Belafonte, Olympia Dukakis and Philip Seymour Hoffman showed their support at a rally in New York last week.

Fears of a total shutdown are already echoing through Los Angeles where an estimated 250,000 people are directly involved in television and film production and countless others work in services that depend on a thriving entertainment industry.

There is growing anger in the acting profession at the failure to resolve the dispute and fears that it could drag on for months as neither side has given any indication of budging. Other actors, including Kevin Bacon, Richard Dreyfuss, Harry Belafonte, Olympia Dukakis and Philip Seymour Hoffman showed their support at a rally in New York last week. Fears of a total shutdown are already echoing through Los Angeles where an estimated 250,000 people are directly involved in television and film production and countless others work in services that depend on a thriving entertainment industry.

fields.headline: Obituary: Curt Siodmak
fields.standfirst: Screenwriter, and occasional director, of Hollywood horror genre classics
fields.trailText: Screenwriter, and occasional director, of Hollywood horror genre classics
fields.body:
A highlight of the 1998 Berlin Film Festival was the 75-film retrospective celebrating the Siodmak Brothers, Robert (who died in 1973) and his younger brother by exactly two years, Curt, who has died aged 98. To the surprise of the audiences, the gnomish Curt had travelled from his home in California and was happy to introduce the movies and meet viewers.

Some 25 of the films had his credit, the rest being devoted to Robert Siodmak, who had enjoyed a more elevated career, as is the fortune of directors rather than writers. Curt had contributed to even more films - over 70 in all - than had Robert, mainly as a writer of horror, science fiction and adventure movies.

Curt Siodmak occasionally directed and several of his short stories had been turned into feature films. One of his books, Donovan's Brain, had the unusual distinction of being filmed a number of times between 1943 and 1962.

Curt Siodmak was born in Germany, where his parents had returned from America. His father was a banker and Robert at first followed that profession, freeing Curt to become a journalist. Then in the mid-1920s he contributed to several screenplays for silent German movies, and the die was cast.

The turning point for both brothers came with a remarkable and influential documentary, People On Sunday (1929), which is a minor masterpiece and boasts credits that were rarely equalled in cinema history. Curt Siodmak worked with Billy Wilder on the screenplay, Eugen Schufften and Fred Zinnemann filmed it and the co-directors were Edgar G Ulmer and Robert Siodmak. All enjoyed long and successful careers.

Curt went on to write several more German films, but the Siodmak brothers, who were Jewish, decided to work abroad from the mid-1930s, first in France where Curt wrote La Crise Est Finie (1935), directed by his brother. Curt then moved on to England (Robert stayed in Paris until 1939), co-writing Girls Will Be Boys and It's A Bet, I Give My Heart and The Tunnel. He also worked on the famously uncompleted version of I Claudius (1937), starring Charles Laughton and directed by Josef von Sternberg. After Non Stop New York (1937) for Michael Balcon, he moved to the US and began his career as writer and director.

His first credit was on Her Jungle Love, a romantic adventure with Dorothy Lamour. Two films, both inspired by H G Wells, The Invisible Man Returns (1939) and Invisible Agent (1942) followed, and the remarkable horror movie The Wolf Man (1941), starring Lon Chaney Jr, which helped establish his career. He gained further credibility with the publication in 1942 of the brilliant horror/fantasy novel Donovan's Brain. This was filmed in 1943 as The Lady And The Monster, with Erich von Stroheim; it fared better under its original title in 1953, later became a TV movie, and then another feature made in Britain in 1962, as Over My Dead Body.

Among his other novels Heuser's Memory, published in 1968, was filmed in 1970, and two more of his books, Skyport (1959) and City In The Sky (1974), partly inspired the film adaptation of Ian Fleming's Moonraker in 1978. Other short stories were expanded into screenplays: The Devil's Brood became House Of Frankenstein in 1944 and Girl In Ice became Devil's Messenger in 1962.

Although primarily a writer, Curt Siodmak had a short, mundane career as a director with adventures such as Bride Of The Gorilla (1951), Curucu, Beast Of The Amazon (1956) and No 13 Demon Street (1957) among others. Unlike his brother, he never made the transition into A features and almost all his work was in genre movies.

But the low budget horror films he wrote proved occasionally memorable, standing up well today. The Beast With Five Fingers (1946), starring Peter Lorre and directed by Robert Florey remains wonderfully atmospheric and scary. I Walked With A Zombie (1943) was an elegant and sensitive work, largely the result of director Jacques Tourneur, for whom Siodmak also provided the story for the semi-documentary thriller, Berlin Express (1947).

Curt wrote Son Of Dracula (1943) for his brother to direct, plus The Climax (1944), Frisco Sal (1965) and Tarzan's Magic Fountain (1948). He later wrote the screenplay for the SF picture Riders To The Stars (1954), for Richard Carlson, an actor turned director: they worked together on several films.

Curt's other credits include a German-made adaptation of a Conan Doyle story, Sherlock Holmes And The Deadly Necklace (1962), directed by Terence Fisher and starring Christopher Lee. During the 1960s, as television increasingly led to the demise of small budget movies, Curt Siodmak ended his directorial career with a Swiss-Czech production, Ski Fever (1966). He also looked abroad for work, but only a TV movie in Germany, Die Heiligenschein (1977) was available.

He had remained on the sidelines of mainstream cinema, working in several countries with fine co-writers, actors and directors. Of the six young hopefuls who had made that documentary about ordinary people on a Sunday in Berlin, Curt Siodmak had the least distinguished career.

But his quirky, inventive talent displayed innate professionalism; the whole history of the movies would have been much poorer without such mavericks and journeymen, the backbone of popular cinema.

He is survived by his wife of 75 years, Henrietta; a son, and two granddaughters.

webTitle: Emily Bell on Media Guardian's website

fields.headline: A star is born
fields.standfirst: Media Guardian has launched its website. Its executive editor  Emily Bell outlines the potential - and reveals why she got a worried call from the paper's astrologer
fields.trailText: Media Guardian has launched its website. Its executive editor, Emily Bell outlines the potential - and reveals why she got a worried call from the paper's astrologer.
fields.body:
The phone call had a sense of urgency about it: "PLEASE tell me you're not planning to do anything on September 4?" I was perplexed. "Well," I said, "it's the day we have provisionally booked for launching the new media website and according to my medical notes I could well be giving birth. But apart from that my diary's empty."

If the alarm over the fourth had been raised by the finance director or the editor or any one of a host of senior executives, I would have been more sanguine about it, but the fact that it was our corporate astrologer Maggie Hyde made it more troubling.

The problem, it seems, is that Pluto is in opposition to Jupiter. Which apparently in astrological terms is the equivalent of a spectacularly bad hair day.

In the event, the launch of Media Guardian.co.uk went ahead - last Wednesday, September 6, which was an altogether more auspicious day. A slight modification in plan which was as much to do with the general inadvisability of launching any technical operation on a Monday as a misalignment of the stars. Notwithstanding the inevitable cracks about Uranus being in the wrong place, one would expect plenty of dire warnings about launching websites into a climate which has turned rather chilly on internet-related enterprises. But nobody would argue that the internet will do anything other than expand in usage or that its economic benefits over putting ink on paper stil make the right developments a "no brainer", particularly for already vigorous publishing brands.

The launch of Media Guardian.co.uk , which has 12 web-based journalists working alongside the Guardian's existing team.is a significant milestone for the paper and for the media industry at large. For the first time in the UK we will have a dedicated media site which, over the coming months, will build a presence in all areas of the industry. Its aim is to extend and augment the Guardian's already excellent coverage of the media sector through daily live news, analysis, gossip and services.

Since plans for the site began to come together a couple of months ago, the most frequently asked question to coin a nerdism, has been whether there is a market for such a free-ranging beast, and whether it isn't madly over-ambitious to try and service the interests and needs of everyone from media studies students to advertising account managers and merchant bankers.

In fact it is this kind of publishing brand extension which the internet is uniquely suited to - addressing smaller communities in greater depth than would ever be possible through the pages of a national newspaper. The media community - which by some estimates extends to almost a million people - is no longer necessarily divided along the kind of linear boundaries it was when the various branches of the trade press were in their infancy. Telecom companies now have content managers, newspaper operations have audio-visual strategists, broadcasters have interactive experts and advertising agencies need to know about all of them.

What will be the most important element in the success of Media Guardian.co.uk will be how its community views it - which is why in the early months we are keen to hear your views on what is good, and not so good, about the prototype.

E ven in the few weeks of preparation we have had for the initial testing of the site, it also became clear that the flow of news - both serious and slightly scurrilous - would give us ample opportunity to break stories of interest to an industry which is increasingly reliant on quick access to real-time information. Whether it is a Big Brother eviction or a big money takeover, a question of press and privacy or the merits of National Cleavage Week, the website gives us the breadth and flexibility to react to anything and everything. On an almost daily basis we found ourselves saying, "if we had a website we could put that on it". Unsettlingly for those of us more used to the restrictions of a piece of paper, the problem with the internet is controlling the tidal wave of possibilities.

If the question for Media Guardian.co.uk is "is there a market in the gap?" then the answer has to be yes. Helped as we are by the Guardian's pioneering attitude towards the internet and the unique structure of the Guardian's trust-backed ownership, Media Guardian.co.uk has the best possible start. Even Pluto has stopped molesting Jupiter to ease the minds of even the most superstitious.

Sadly I missed the fun of the launch, having taken the easier option and booked into the labour ward.

fields.headline: Media Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Latest news from trade title Media week.
fields.trailText: A round-up the latest launches, appointments, account wins and mergers from the trade press. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC faces fresh controversy over plans to launch a masthead TV project off the back of a celebrity magazine codenamed Project G.

The magazine is to be twinned with a 20-minute branded show-business slot on BBC1's Saturday morning programme Live & Kicking. The masthead slot is to launch on October 7.

BBJ Media Services is being tipped to pick up the £8m easyJet media buying account following a three-way pitch against Zenith and BJK&E.

The Interpublic Group is said to be planning to merge UK media agencies Western International Media and Initiative Media - one of the last remaining country mergers between the two agencies.

The merger has been mooted since Initiative lost the Peugeot Citron account in July (the main obstacle was the fact that Western holds the Vauxhall account).

Denise Gardiner has left Starcom Motive to head the Media Planning Groupês new research group.

Redwood Publishing is to produce an on-screen magazine for TiVo, called Inside TiVo.

Quantum New Media managing director Paul Longhurst has called for greater accountability in the online sector.

Booth Lockett Makin has appointed MediaCom TMB commercial director Paul van Barthold as media director. He fills the gap left by Ian Clarke when he became director of advertising at News Group Newspapers.

webTitle: Tesco and PPA in talks to end distribution disagreement

fields.headline: PPA nears distribution agreement with Tesco
fields.trailText: The PPA has moved closer to an agreement with Tesco over magazine distribution. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The PPA has moved closer to an agreement with Tesco over the retailer's controversial proposed changes in magazine distribution.

The two parties have agreed to discuss a blueprint agreement drawn up by the PPA, based on the current regional structure. In the meantime, Tesco will delay the implementation of its proposed national distribution system.

Gruner & Jahr, the magazine publisher that stopped supplying Tesco stores in protest against the plans, has been invited to resume supplies.

fields.headline: Murdoch stages comeback with Future Network
fields.trailText: Future Network, the magazine and internet publisher, has countered mounting losses by securing the services of Elisabeth Murdoch as non-executive director.
fields.body:
Future Network, the magazine and internet publisher, has countered mounting losses by securing the services of Elisabeth Murdoch as non-executive director.

The daughter of super-tycoon Ruper Murdoch has made her media comeback only five months after resigning as managing director of BSkyB's Sky Networks operation. No details were released of her payment terms.

Greg Ingham, chief executive of Future Network, said: "I think she brings a welter of experience to our media business. As soon as she left Sky we wanted her on the board as soon as possible.

"There is a lot of common ground in the way we think and she has an extremely sharp mind which will bring smart ideas to the company. She has context and contacts."

The good news for Future Network was tempered by its interim results, with pre-tax losses for the six months to June of £13.4m, up from £6.3m. Mr Ingham said the company will invest £33m this year, with its e-commerce magazine, Business 2.0, launching in Italy and France.

Future has also won a three-year licence to publish Sony's Official Playstation II magazine, to coincide with the much-hyped games console's November launch.

"Magazines remain the core part of our business," said Mr Ingham. "Our top-line growth overall has been amazing, however, and the games market will receive a significant boost with the return of Playstation."

Analysts are ambivalent about Future, with some saying the fall in popularity of computer games may last longer than expected, and that competition in the consumer magazine market was as strong as ever. Nonetheless, the company is on the buy list of many analysts, thanks to its diverse portfolio and growth in the US market.

Future's shares were unchanged at 727.5p in early trading.
