fields.headline: Is it what TV was made for?
fields.standfirst: Who wants it? Amy Vickers reports on the difficulties of delivering the TV internet to a mass audience
fields.trailText: Who wants it? Amy Vickers reports on the difficulties of delivering the TV internet to a mass audience
fields.body:
Back in the days when TVs were for watching and PCs were for surfing, things seemed so much simpler. Boundaries were well defined and even though some pundits enjoyed upsetting the apple cart by throwing in that fear-of-death word: "convergence", we always knew that whatever the future had in store for us, we could handle it. Only we didn't quite expect it to be so darned confusing.

If, like me, you've lost count of the number of different products providing internet access, prepare to get your thinking cap around the untamed world of the internet on your TV. Granted that this is not especially a new thing - NTL has been offering it for almost two years - but the ballpark is starting to get so much more complex.

ONdigital last week joined the party when it revealed details of ONnet, its TV internet offering that hits the market next week, while Bush Internet is gearing up to bolster sales in the pre-Christmas rush. As if that wasn't enough to satisfy latent demand, Granada is preparing to launch Powerchannel, its very own TV internet product, in just over a month's time.

All parties say there is a market for TV internet, but many a pundit has already put the dampener on the hype by questioning their sustainability and market positioning. The main gripes are 1) that the revenue model isn't strong enough to support heavily subsidised set-top boxes; 2) demand for internet on the TV is still unproved and 3) the products are aimed at a difficult market segment (ie people that never or rarely use the internet).

I may be vilified for saying this, but at the moment, TV internet services are nothing more than gimmicks or, at best, expensive experiments that make unfounded presumptions about revenue streams. The TV internet providers may be able to sell tons of ad space across their default portals, or sell anchor tenancies to third parties (such as retailers) and take commission on sales, but they can't bank on users staying within the confines of their "walled gardens" and spending their cash.

It's one of the many quirks of the TV internet model - provide them with a free rein but hope they'll not wander off too far - and why the likes of BSkyB are loath to go down this route. Of course, the other quirk is that the providers may not be able to sign up enough users in the first place to justify taking advertisers' money.

No one has yet made a success of offering the internet via TV to a mass audience. NTL may have been one of the first into the UK market, but strangely the company stopped pushing its TV internet service a long time ago.

Quiz NTL about figures and you'll get the response "sorry, don't release them", which, if glossed rather cynically, could suggest the service has not been a rip-roaring success. Talk to Sega Dreamcast, another company with a box that provides TV internet, and you'll hear much of the same. Further afield, Microsoft has had three years to make an impact on the US market with WebTV, but has struggled to pass the 1m mark, and this in a country with 100m households.

The logical conclusion is that the average consumer not only doesn't want to sit directly in front of their precious TV but, and most surveys support this, most people who don't already have internet access (two-thirds of UK households) are quite happy with their lot and see no reason to get connected.

Given this fact, it seems incomprehensible that the TV internet providers are not pitching their services at the higher end of the scale - at early adopters and those people with internet access already. Surely that's a more viable market segment, and one that likes to spend money on new gadgets?

Of course, the reason why these services aren't aimed at existing users is that they are frustrating to use when you're accustomed to being able to get everything you want from a website. All of the providers have opted out of the costly option of pre-installing RealPlayer (around £700,000), and because there is no facility to download software onto the boxes, this is not likely to change in the near future. What this means is that all the cool broadcasting stuff, increasingly becoming the mainstay of the internet, will just not work on TV internet services. Forgive me if I'm missing something, but wasn't that what the TV was designed for?

One aspect of TV internet that often tends to be overlooked is that surfing the internet is, by and large, a very solitary personal experience. If you've ever tried it with someone hovering over your shoulder grabbing the mouse, you'll know what I mean.

With mobile internet technology becoming mainstream, broadband just around the corner and cable and satellite operators offering interactive services as part of their digital packages, it does seem that the market for stand-alone TV internet products is somewhat limited. To say it's a gamble is a huge understatement, but without companies taking these type of risks where would we be today?

A few years from now, we will know conclusively whether consumers will buy into this dream, but until then there's going to be a lot of money spent finding out.

If, like me, you've lost count of the number of different products providing internet access, prepare to get your thinking cap around the untamed world of the internet on your TV. Granted that this is not especially a new thing - NTL has been offering it for almost two years - but the ballpark is starting to get so much more complex. ONdigital last week joined the party when it revealed details of ONnet, its TV internet offering that hits the market next week, while Bush Internet is gearing up to bolster sales in the pre-Christmas rush. As if that wasn't enough to satisfy latent demand, Granada is preparing to launch Powerchannel, its very own TV internet product, in just over a month's time. All parties say there is a market for TV internet, but many a pundit has already put the dampener on the hype by questioning their sustainability and market positioning. The main gripes are 1) that the revenue model isn't strong enough to support heavily subsidised set-top boxes; 2) demand for internet on the TV is still unproved and 3) the products are aimed at a difficult market segment (ie people that never or rarely use the internet). I may be vilified for saying this, but at the moment, TV internet services are nothing more than gimmicks or, at best, expensive experiments that make unfounded presumptions about revenue streams. The TV internet providers may be able to sell tons of ad space across their default portals, or sell anchor tenancies to third parties (such as retailers) and take commission on sales, but they can't bank on users staying within the confines of their "walled gardens" and spending their cash. It's one of the many quirks of the TV internet model - provide them with a free rein but hope they'll not wander off too far - and why the likes of BSkyB are loath to go down this route. Of course, the other quirk is that the providers may not be able to sign up enough users in the first place to justify taking advertisers' money. No one has yet made a success of offering the internet via TV to a mass audience. NTL may have been one of the first into the UK market, but strangely the company stopped pushing its TV internet service a long time ago. Quiz NTL about figures and you'll get the response "sorry, don't release them", which, if glossed rather cynically, could suggest the service has not been a rip-roaring success. Talk to Sega Dreamcast, another company with a box that provides TV internet, and you'll hear much of the same. Further afield, Microsoft has had three years to make an impact on the US market with WebTV, but has struggled to pass the 1m mark, and this in a country with 100m households. The logical conclusion is that the average consumer not only doesn't want to sit directly in front of their precious TV but, and most surveys support this, most people who don't already have internet access (two-thirds of UK households) are quite happy with their lot and see no reason to get connected. Given this fact, it seems incomprehensible that the TV internet providers are not pitching their services at the higher end of the scale - at early adopters and those people with internet access already. Surely that's a more viable market segment, and one that likes to spend money on new gadgets? Of course, the reason why these services aren't aimed at existing users is that they are frustrating to use when you're accustomed to being able to get everything you want from a website. All of the providers have opted out of the costly option of pre-installing RealPlayer (around £700,000), and because there is no facility to download software onto the boxes, this is not likely to change in the near future. What this means is that all the cool broadcasting stuff, increasingly becoming the mainstay of the internet, will just not work on TV internet services. Forgive me if I'm missing something, but wasn't that what the TV was designed for? One aspect of TV internet that often tends to be overlooked is that surfing the internet is, by and large, a very solitary personal experience. If you've ever tried it with someone hovering over your shoulder grabbing the mouse, you'll know what I mean. With mobile internet technology becoming mainstream, broadband just around the corner and cable and satellite operators offering interactive services as part of their digital packages, it does seem that the market for stand-alone TV internet products is somewhat limited. To say it's a gamble is a huge understatement, but without companies taking these type of risks where would we be today? A few years from now, we will know conclusively whether consumers will buy into this dream, but until then there's going to be a lot of money spent finding out.

fields.headline: Newly discovered DH Lawrence artwork on display
fields.trailText: Lately I saw a sight most quaint;
fields.body:
Lately I saw a sight most quaint;

London's lily-white policemen faint

In virgin outrage as they viewed

The nudity of a Lawrence nude.

Oh what a pity, Oh don't you agree

That fig-trees aren't found

in the land of the free

As this ditty illustrates, DH Lawrence took a dim view of his compatriots' prudery. Not only was his most successful novel, Lady Chatterley's Lover, banned here for 30 years after his death, but his risque paintings could not be shown either.

Today a previously unknown Lawrence screen silk will be unveiled at Nottingham University, his alma mater, as the centrepiece of a DH Lawrence research centre.

For years the writer, who based much of The Rainbow around his time at the university, was persona non grata after running away with his professor's wife, Frieda, whom he later married.

In 1929, the occasion for the ditty, police stepped in when the then home secretary objected to Lawrence's depiction of the Holy Family that included a naked blonde being fondled from behind, and another canvas of nuns ogling a naked peasant Adonis. Lawrence had to send them back to his home in New Mexico to stop them being destroyed.

The new work lay undocumented for 40 years after the death of Frieda in 1956. Lawrence himself died in 1930.

John Worthen, professor of DH Lawrence studies at the university, said the screen silk was quite unlike the rest of his work - "like a lino cut, but done on silk". Because of damage due to the altitude and dryness of New Mexico, the work had taken four years to restore.

webTitle: Warner Music to sell digital downloads

fields.headline: Warner Music to sell digital downloads
fields.trailText: Warner Music Group will begin to sell digital downloads of its artists' material from November, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Warner Music Group, the last of the five major record companies to enter the commercial download market, will in November begin to sell digital downloads of its artists' material.

The record label will today announce plans to initially sell digital downloads of 100 songs, before expanding its digital offering to more than 1,000 albums and singles next year.

Warner will partner traditional and online retailers, such as Wal-Mart.com and Amazon.com, to distribute music content.

The company is not expected to unveil a role for AOL, the internet operation currently merging with its parent Time Warner, in the early stages of its new net strategy. AOL is, however, expected be involved in the distribution and promotion of Warner's digital music.

Warner Music's artist list includes Fleetwood Mac, REM, Neil Young, Tori Amos, Phil Collins and Madonna.

Warner is the last of the big five record companies to unveil its digital strategy. Bertelsmann unit BMG Entertainment will have its service up and running by the end of the month. And Sony Music Entertainment and Seagram's Universal Music Group are working together on a service that is expected to launch in the next few months.

It is thought that, like the other record companies, Warner will choose not to offer songs for sale in the MP3 format.

Separately, EMI, the music group being merged into AOL/Time Warner, has offered assurances that it will not abuse its position as the world's leading music group should its $20bn (£14bn) tie-up with Warner Music receive regulatory approval.

European regulators are concerned that the company will dominate the market for digital downloads if it is allowed to merge with AOL/Time Warner. Some reports have suggested AOL/Time Warner may yet ditch EMI if its merger is called into question.

fields.headline: Murdoch returns with Future Network role
fields.trailText: Elisabeth Murdoch has staged her media comeback only five months after resigning as managing director of BSkyB's Sky Networks operation.
fields.body:
Elisabeth Murdoch has staged her media comeback only five months after resigning as managing director of BSkyB's Sky Networks operation.

The daughter of super-tycoon Ruper Murdoch will join the board of consumer magazines and websites publisher Future Network as non-executive director. No details were release of her payment terms.

Greg Ingham, chief executive of Future Network, said: "I think she brings a welter of experience to our media business. As soon as she left Sky we wanted her on the board as soon as possible."

fields.headline: What media feeding frenzy?
fields.standfirst: Pearson's purchase of TalkBack generated considerable speculation about a media feeding frenzy that never materialised, writes Jason Deans.
fields.trailText: The sale of TalkBack Productions to Pearson in June for £62m prompted speculation of a financial feeding frenzy, with bigger media fish gobbling up tasty little independent TV producers.
fields.body:
The sale of TalkBack Productions to Pearson in June for £62m prompted speculation of a financial feeding frenzy, with bigger media fish gobbling up tasty little independent TV producers.

Lumbering media behemoths hungry for content would get their hands on the creativity and talent locked up in the independent TV production sector, indie producers would gain oodles of cash, and everyone would be happy.

Since then Zenith Entertainment has been put up for sale for around £30m and the Television Corporation has exercised its option to buy the remaining 50% of Mentorn Barraclough Carey for between £5m and £22m, depending on profits.

Otherwise there has not been the anticipated stampede to put the for-sale signs up across Soho. This is partly because there is only a select band of indies big enough - with the right type of programming, talent relationships and rights archive - to attract the attention of would-be buyers.

And not every company in the indie sector wants to sell-up.

Then there is the question of timing, and TalkBack is believed to have got this just right. "TalkBack set the benchmark," says one senior indie sector source. "It played a blinder. Nobody else will get that sort of money for a bit."

But indie producers are looking beyond their traditional low-margin business of relying on production fees from broadcasters to new ways of bringing in funding that will secure their cashflow and allow them to expand.

After the TalkBack deal, observers are looking to see what Hat Trick Productions and Tiger Aspect Productions in particular do next. They both have a similar industry profile to TalkBack and similar strengths in comedy and entertainment. But neither is looking to follow the TalkBack route of selling up lock, stock and barrel, according to senior executives.

Hat Trick joint managing director Denise O'Donoghue reveals that it "went a long way down the road" towards an agreed takeover by a larger entity, but has decided to remain independent.

Tiger Aspect chairman Peter Bennett-Jones says the company "has no intention of doing a TalkBack", but adds that it is interested in finding "a minority partner or supply deal".

O'Donoghue says Hat Trick is now more likely to be a buyer than a seller and looking to more than double its turnover in the next three years.

The company is focusing its expansion efforts on Hat Trick KPE Interactive (HKI) - the joint venture set up with US interactive media incubator KPE to develop broadband content. She says HKI will be looking to raise £10-£20m in the autumn from "venture capitalists and strategic partners".

Bennett-Jones says the key to any Tiger Aspect deal would be to strike the right balance between retaining its independence and distinctive style and gaining access to things that would help it expand: either money, intellectual property, technology, means of international expansion or guaranteed output deals.

Tiger Aspect is developing a similar digital entertainment content venture, Totalcomedy.com, in partnership with talent agency PBJ Management (which Bennett-Jones founded).

Zenith is an unusual case, as chief executive Steve Matthews admits freely. He was brought in by the companyÕs venture capital backers in early 1998 with a brief to prepare it for sale within three years.

In addition to a production roster including children's shows Byker Grove and SMTV/CD UK, Zenith has full or partial rights in 1,000 hours of programming and owns new media outfit Workhouse and children's book publisher Two-Can.

As consolidation gathered pace, "people began knocking on our door", Matthews says.

Zenith was "virtually at the point of signing" a deal with United News & Media when Clive Hollick in July sold most of his TV assets to Granada Media. Now the company is back on the market, with Granada, Carlton and Endemol likely to be among its suitors, and a deal expected to be sealed by the end of October.

"We'd like to be bought by a company that shares our views about growth and what we can achieve," Matthews says.

He believes the indie sector as a whole is flavour of the moment with investors for the simple reason that with the growth of multi-channel TV and the web there are more channels and platforms to feed and the value of content is rocketing.

Matthews also points out that indies make a lot of the "strongest programmes" broadcast on British TV channels. "What big companies are realising is that buying independents is a neat way of adding value to their balance sheet, as well as content and well-managed creative teams."

fields.headline: Media stories from today's papers
fields.trailText: Top Stories
fields.body:
Top Stories

The Times

A Sheffield family has been revealed as an insider dealing crime syndicate by a special government report. The Cleggs amassed £50m through secret share dealing linked to Wace, a publicly quoted print group, and its subsidiaries.

Haymarket Publishing, the magazine group owned by retired Tory MP Michael Heseltine, has posted a sharp slump in net profits. The £200m company blamed the reduction to profits of £5.6m on the launch of PR Week in the US.

Financial Times

Four people, including two former London Stock Exchange employees, will face criminal proceedings today, charged with offences related to insider dealing. It's a further embarrassment for the exchange, which has been rocked by opposition to its proposed merger with the Deutsche Borse.

A report by market researcher Gartner Group claims that customers will lose out if they buy mobile phones built with interim technology. Their phones will soon become dated, with the advent of third generation mobile phone services providing a much more stable, long-term technological platform.

The man who photographed Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara is suing a UK advertising firm for using his images. Alberto Diaz "Korda" is taking Lowe Lintas to court for allegedly using a photo of Che in an advert for Smirnoff vodka without seeking permission.

The majority of early investors in Lastminute.com have assured the online booking agency that they do not intend to sell their shares when the six-month lock in ends today.

The Independent

The London Stock Exchange and the Financial Services Authority will continue to investigate events surrounding a possible takeover bid for the internet group Scoot.com. There is concern over Scoot's disclosures to the stock market, when lawyers representing the firm told the High Court it was in takeover talks. Scoot then denied it was set to be acquired, but £20m was made in dealing Scoot shares as the share price rocketed and then fell.

Mobile phone giant Vodafone could cut its debt nearly in half with the £8bn sale of Infostrada, the Italian fixed line telecoms operator.

FTV Group, an advertising firm which shows commercials on petrol station forecourts, is planning a £10m AIM flotation.

The Wall Street Journal Europe

Media giant Walt Disney is planning to launch a new type of internet advertising campaign called "The Big Impression" on its websites. The ads are a third bigger than the average banner ad.

Internet giant America Online and media conglomerate Time Warner have offered remedies to appease European Commission competition fears over their multi-billion pound merger. British music group EMI has yet to submit a reply over objections to its £12bn link-up with Time Warner.

The Daily Express

The contestants for Channel 5's Big Brother-style Jailbreak show include a gay Sandhurst graduate, a glamour model and a grandmother. The 10 contestants were "arrested" yesterday and taken to a purpose-built prison in Hertfordshire where they will spend three weeks trying to escape.

Gratuitous tabloid story of the day

The Daily Star claims that Big Brother favourite Craig will have to demolish the extension to his cottage when he gets out of the Channel Four house. Craig's local council in Newport, Wales, look set to order the demolition of the £20,000 extension on planning permission grounds. Of course, the council has yet to reach its decision.

webTitle: UK troops will stay in Sierra Leone, says government

fields.headline: UK troops will stay in Sierra Leone, says government
fields.trailText: The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, insisted today that British troops "still had a job to do" in Sierra Leone and would not be withdrawing.
fields.body:
The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, insisted today that British troops "still had a job to do" in Sierra Leone and would not be withdrawing.

His comments followed yesterday's daring swoop by paratroopers on a jungle hideaway to free six members of the Royal Irish Regiment, who had been held by the rebel West Side Boys.

One British soldier and 25 rebels were killed during a 90-minute firefight and several more troops were injured.

Today Mr Hoon revealed that those soldiers released would now be questioned about why they were in the jungle in the first place.

"It is important we understand why the hostages were taken and take steps to make sure it doesn't happen again," he told the BBC. "When the soldiers come back [to Britain] we will hope to establish what they were doing there. We have a partial picture, but we want to know why."

Mr Hoon said that the government had no plans to immediately withdraw British troops from Sierra Leone, but added that the army's work there was nearly done.

British soldiers have been in the troubled west African country to train the Sierra Leonean government's troops.

Mr Hoon said: "There is no question of us withdrawing our troops at this time. We have approved three support training missions, two of which have been concluded and one of which is almost under way."

The defence secretary conceded that Britain's involvement in Sierra Leone could be over in just six weeks, the estimated time of the final training mission. He insisted that security will now be stepped up.

Yesterday's dawn raid on the rebel base followed threats by the West Side Boys to kill their hostages and their Sierra Leonean liaison officer if aircraft were spotted over their base in the Occra Hills, 30 miles west of the capital Freetown.

But military chiefs gambled on a surprise attack by dropping troops from the air after deciding the swamps and rough ground surrounding the rebel camp would slow down the 150-strong force from 1 Para. They flew in at dawn yesterday in five helicopters - two Lynxes and three Chinooks - which provided extra firepower.

Within 20 minutes, the seven hostages were on board a helicopter. They were whisked to safety on the Royal Fleet Auxiliary ship Sir Percivale at Freetown.

A total of 25 rebels were killed during the 90-minute battle, including three women. Eighteen rebels were captured, including their leader, self-styled "Brigadier" Foday Kallay.

Meanwhile, the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith today called for British troops to be pulled out of Sierra Leone. "We either now take the decision to withdraw British troops - which I would favour - and tell the UN to get on with the job they were told to do in the first place, or else we decide, if we put British troops in, they have got to be properly protected.

Eighteen rebels were captured, including their leader, self-styled "Brigadier" Foday Kallay. Meanwhile, the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith today called for British troops to be pulled out of Sierra Leone. "We either now take the decision to withdraw British troops - which I would favour - and tell the UN to get on with the job they were told to do in the first place, or else we decide, if we put British troops in, they have got to be properly protected.

fields.headline: VNU in £16m web recruitment venture
fields.trailText: Publishing firm VNU has teamed up with Randstad Holding, which claims to be the world's third largest recruitment firm, and put £16m behind a new recruitment portal called newmonday.com.
fields.body:
Publishing firm VNU has teamed up with Randstad Holding, which claims to be the world's third largest recruitment firm, and put £16m behind a new recruitment portal called newmonday.com.

Described as a full career management and recruitment service, newmonday.com has launched country-specific sites in the UK, the Netherlands, France and Belgium and plans to have services up and running in Italy, Spain and Germany by the end of the year. The business is being run as a 50:50 joint venture between the two companies.

In a crowded online recruitment market, newmonday.com says it is attempting to add a human touch by offering a call centre of recruitment consultants to back up jobs on the site. It is also targeting a specific demographic: well-educated professionals wishing to develop their careers. The site is tied into specialist content from VNUNet, the IT news and analysis portal run by VNU.

Ruud Bakker, chief operating officer of newmonday.com, said: "The European market for online recruitment services is growing and maturing at a fast rate in order to satisfy the changing employment landscape. We intend to position newmonday.com as an online standard for the industry."

fields.body:
Granada Television controller of comedy Andy Harries is expected to add the company's drama production brief to his responsibilities this week.

Harries, whose recent credits including Cold Feet and The Royle Family, is understood to be close to finalising with senior Granada executives details of what his new role would be.

He declined to comment, but a senior Granada insider said there were "benefits to be had from putting the comedy and drama departments together".

The controller of drama job became vacant this week, when Simon Lewis and his deputy Sue Hogg ended weeks of speculation by confirming they were moving to the BBC to become executive drama producers with their own output guarantee.

webTitle: Too rich for the oil companies' liking

fields.headline: Too rich for the oil companies' liking
fields.standfirst: Prices may be up, but even the oil producers aren't entirely happy, as Terry Macalister reports
fields.trailText: Prices may be up, but even the oil producers aren't entirely happy, as Terry Macalister reports.
fields.body:
It's hard to believe, but the global oil corporations that are making money hand over fist at the moment actually dislike sky-high crude prices.

Shell recently announced sheepishly that it had made £26m a day over the first six months of the year, but then called on OPEC to increase production to bring down the price of crude.

Why? Because what they really want is highish crude prices: ones that are sustainable in the long term and which do not trigger a backlash from politicians worried about inflation or global recession and consumers fed up with paying a fortune to fill up their cars

When oil prices are very high, oil groups fear exactly what has happened over the past week: oil depots around the country being brought to a standstill by angry hauliers.

The truckers are blaming government for levying too much tax but the oil companies inevitably get some of the flak for alleged profiteering too and have their operations disrupted.

Sir John Browne, chief executive of BP, recently unveiled a 200% increase in first-half profits, but went on to express his sympathy for the "Dump the Pump" campaign by motorists arguing that government should reduce its tax take.

Nevertheless, oil companies are also fearful that politicians could levy windfall taxes on them or just tighten the fiscal regime covering the development of oil fields in the North Sea.

In fact, the margins for oil companies on the forecourt are slim due to the intense competition from supermarkets that partly use petrol as a loss leader.

Shell recently shutdown 120 service stations in Britain on the grounds that they do not make enough money, which might seem odd given it made overall group profits of nearly £4.5bn in the half year.

But major UK-based oil corporations like Shell and BP - two of the world's big three - make their money on the "upstream" side, bringing the black stuff out of the ground and selling it on to their own or others' refineries for processing into petrol for cars, aviation fuel or whatever.

The oil companies themselves have little control over the price of oil. They will see their share price rocket ahead in times like today but fall heavily when the crude price drops as it has done cyclically ever since oil first became used as a fuel in a widespread way earlier last century.

Oil companies do not like this volatility in their stock either.

webTitle: Blair holds firm as fuel protests grow

fields.headline: Blair holds firm as fuel protests grow
fields.trailText: Fuel protests continued to spread across the UK today, as Tony Blair ruled out any government concessions on fuel prices, with Opec's pledge to increase production by 800,000 barrels a day, or 3%, promising only slight prospects of relief.
fields.body:
Fuel protests continued to spread across the UK today, as Tony Blair ruled out any government concessions on fuel prices, with Opec's pledge to increase production by 800,000 barrels a day, or 3%, promising only slight prospects of relief.

The prime minister said: "The sensible way, indeed the only right way, is to put Opec under pressure, not to let it off the hook by caving in to pressure."

Petrol companies admitted that more than 100 filling stations in the north-west alone had run out of supplies by this morning because of fuel dept blockades, with dozens more expected to run short during the day. Some service stations in Yorkshire were also reported to have run out of unleaded fuel.

Blockades resumed at oil terminals in Jarrow, Milford Haven, Stanlow, Pembroke, Manchester and Bristol, with fresh protests breaking out in Southampton and Leeds. Further action was also expected at Immingham, at the mouth of the river Humber.

Craig Eley, a Gateshead-based haulage boss, said he hoped drivers would organise similar protests at fuel terminals in Sunderland and Middlesbrough today following slow-rolling demonstrations by truckers and farmers on the A1 in Northumbria and the main A55 coast road in north Wales yesterday.

Police in Dorset said a convoy of lorries had started a go-slow protest in the county at 6.20am, and added that up to 60 vehicles were expected to bring traffic chaos later.

Anger was also spreading north of the border, with lorry drivers slowing traffic on one of the main routes into Edinburgh at about 7am, causing major delays on the A720 bypass.

Liverpool taxi drivers are expected to organise similar protests during the evening rush hour today in a gesture of solidarity, hitting the two tunnels which link the city to the Wirral under the river Mersey.

Fishermen in Plymouth are set to join in the protests for the first time tonight, linking up with farmers and hauliers to prevent fuel leaving a depot in the Cattedown area. Leader David Pessell said today he did not know the size of the maritime contingent, but added: "The fishermen will be there."

Demonstrators say that the blockades will continue until the government takes action to reduce the price of fuel. TUC general secretary John Monks told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme: "I wouldn't rule out the government taking action to reduce fuel duty, but the major factor is not moving our taxation up and down every time the fuel price changes, but getting the fuel price down."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU union, joined the calls on the Today programme: "The French government obviously is now helping French industry, and British industry could do with a shot in the arm at this time, not a shot in the head."

But Tony Blair today remained firm, addressing an audience in Loughborough. While he expressed sympathy for those caught financially, he said protests could only have one outcome.

"We cannot and will not alter government policy on petrol through blockades and pickets," he said. "That's not the way to make policy in Britain and as far as I'm concerned it never will be."

Earlier in the day, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers asked: "What people need to answer is if they want to see a cut in fuel duty, 2p off a litre is £1 billion off public spending - where are these cuts going to occur?

"The actual percentage of tax being put on petrol today is lower than it was when we took office in May 1997. It was 78% then and is down to 76% now," he said.

"If you look at taxation in the round and take into account business and social costs, then the motorist in the UK is not being discriminated against."

Mr Byers insisted that there was no danger of fuel supplies drying up, saying that shortages at the pumps were due to panic buying, not to the effect of demonstrations. He confirmed that the government had contingency measures in place to deal with prospective shortages.

He also stressed he expected the police to take action ensure that the blockages did not stop fuel supplies from flowing. "There is a very important point of principle here. In Britain, questions of taxation are decided in the Budget. They are not decided by blockades in the streets."

So far relations between protesters and the authorities nationwide have so far remained largely respectful. At the Texaco plant in Pembroke, police allowed truckers onto the site to use showers and toilets, while they drank cups of tea with demonstrators.

David Kern, chief economist at NatWest stockbrokers, said yesterday's Opec gesture would make little difference in the short-term but help prices stabilise over time. It was "better than nothing", he said.

With 200 forecourts now shut in north-west England, Roy Holloway, director of the Petrol Retailers' Association, said: "It is not critical by any means but it is getting worse. If these actions continue into the early part of next week there will be severe difficulties."

On the continent, meanwhile, it was announced that all blockades at France's refineries and depots had been lifted after a deal between the government and unions. Stranded holidaymakers may still have to wait several days before filling stations are re-stocked.

webTitle: French oil blockades end but protests spread

fields.headline: French oil blockades end but protests spread
fields.standfirst:
Now Germans, Italians and Belgians start tax campaigns

The issues explained: Petrol price rises
fields.trailText: Road hauliers and farmers yesterday lifted the last of their blockades from outside France's oil refineries and fuel depots, ending a week-long protest that had brought large parts of the country to a standstill.
fields.byline: Jon Henley in Paris and Tony Paterson in Berlin
fields.body:
Road hauliers and farmers yesterday lifted the last of their blockades from outside France's oil refineries and fuel depots, ending a week-long protest that had brought large parts of the country to a standstill.

But while French fuel tankers, exempted from a customary weekend ban, raced to resupply the 85% of France's petrol stations that had run dry, German truckers were moving to fill the breach, threatening nationwide motorway and road blockades yesterday after Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's coalition rejected calls for the abolition of its controversial ecological fuel tax.

Bernward Franzky, director of the road hauliers association in Lower Saxony, warned: "Whole autobahns risk being brought to a standstill. The situation is getting out of control."

Germany's lorry drivers began disrupting traffic at the weekend.

On Saturday 120 lorries sealed off the north German town of Hildesheim for several hours.

On Friday 40 truck drivers drove into the town of Uelzen in the same region and blocked off the centre during a visit by German transport minister Reinhard Klimmt.

Even in France where the dispute was winding down, oil companies warned it would be several days before the situation returned to normal.

The French interior ministry said the final seven blockades, manned by militant farmers and road hauliers who were still unhappy with the 15% fuel tax cut they had wrested from the government, had been dismantled by midday.

Motorists immediately besieged the restocked stations, forming bumper-to-bumper queues and waiting as long as three hours to be served.

The hauliers, who wanted a 20% cut in state diesel taxes to compensate the soaring price of crude oil, reluctantly accepted the government's offer after the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, under pressure from his Green party coalition partners, told them it was final.

Negotiators from the second biggest French hauliers' group, Unostra, followed those from its sister organisation FNTR on Saturday in recommending its members lift the 160 blockades around the country.

The farmers union FNSEU, which won a 30% reduction in state fuel taxes, quickly followed suit.

The German lorry drivers have demanded reductions in VAT on fuel, car tax and ecological fuel tax to compensate for the rise in fuel prices.

However, German finance minister Hans Eichel ruled out scrapping the ecology tax, one of the chief policy initiatives of Chancellor Schroeder's coalition of Social Democrats and Greens introduced last year.

The risk of protests also appeared to be growing elsewhere in Europe. Italian fishermen occupied quays around the country and warned the government they would blockade ports if it refused to reduce duties on the fuel they use.

In Belgium, several thousand hauliers, taxi drivers and tour bus operators took to the streets of Brussels demanding lower fuel prices.

webTitle: Fuel crisis looms as pickets hit depots

fields.headline: Fuel crisis looms as pickets hit depots
fields.standfirst:
Queues at pumps as campaigners for lower prices block refineries
The issues explained: Petrol price rises
fields.trailText: Britain last night was facing a fuel shortage as hauliers and farmers escalated their picketing at refineries and distribution depots, halting deliveries in many parts of the country.
fields.body:
Britain last night was facing a fuel shortage as hauliers and farmers escalated their picketing at refineries and distribution depots, halting deliveries in many parts of the country.

Police reported tailbacks on the A1 in Northumberland and the A55 in north Wales, with slow moving convoys of tractors and trucks causing chaos.

Campaigners said 80 rolling roadblocks would start around England and Wales early today to complement a nationwide picket of depots.

Yesterday long queues formed at petrol stations in several areas as supplies dwindled. Amid reports of panic buying, some retailers said outlets had sold a week's supply of fuel at the weekend.

More than 100 filling stations in north-west England and north Wales ran dry by last night, and Liverpool airport was said to be running out of fuel.

Action that started at Shell's Stanlow refinery at Ellesmere Port, Cheshire, quickly spread to refineries in Wales and Humberside, with key distribution depots in the West Midlands, Bristol and Greater Manchester also hit.

Welsh farmers are planning to dump 16 tonnes of straw outside Stanlow today to prevent tankers from leaving. They said their action was spurred by a threat from Shell to sack 60 drivers if they did not cross a picketline. The company denied making such a threat.

Although ministers sought to play down the impact of the French-style action - while across the Channel blockades were being lifted - the Petrol Retailers' Association said fuel shortages were not yet critical. But Roy Holloway, its director, added:"If these actions continue for a few more days there will be severe difficulties."

He told the BBC that tax on petrol had significantly increased since Labour came to power. Taking 2p a litre off the pump price would lose the Treasury £2bn a year. "Broadly speaking in the last year the government has had £3bn from the oil industry in increased taxation which was over and above the budget estimate."

But the Scottish secretary, John Reid, speaking for the government, said there could be no "quick fix". Cutting billions off taxation made no economic sense, he told GMTV.

He did not think protests would match those across the Channel. People in Britain "do not react to the French way of doing things, which cause massive disruptions and inconvenience to fellow citizens".

Archie Norman, shadow transport secretary, said it was clear the protests would not fade away. They reflected "genuine, widespread and heartfelt disgust" over the effects of tax increases.

Yesterday hauliers blocked the Conoco oil terminal and smaller terminals at Immingham on the Humber, a big supplier to Yorkshire. Today local roads, including the M180, are likely to be sealed off. Protesters also closed the largest inland oil terminal at Kingsbury, West Midlands.

There were continued actions at Avonmouth, near Bristol, where Texaco and Fina have depots, and at a depot at Cardiff docks.

The Texaco depot in Pembroke, west Wales, and an Elf refinery at Milford Haven were also blockaded. After talks with management at the depots, pickets agreed to let out fuel supplies for essential services, such as ambulances. But the lorry drivers' spokesman, Phillip Rees, warned: "They will have to show us the paper first, and we will send a lorry to follow the tankers."

Damone Page, campaigner in Pembroke for the Less Tax on Fuel group, said they were prepared for a long struggle: "We want a 20% cut in fuel taxation."

Protesters claim to have halted 200 tanker movements at the Manchester fuels terminal at Trafford Park.

Roy Masterson, a hauliers' spokesman, said: "We will not be competitive in Europe or anywhere else if we have the highest transport costs in the world."

fields.headline: Protests grow despite Opec offer
fields.standfirst: The issues explained: Petrol price rises
fields.trailText: Protests against petrol prices intensified yesterday as oil-producing countries promised to pump more crude in an effort to stem runaway world energy costs which have sparked fears of a global recession.
fields.body:
Protests against petrol prices intensified yesterday as oil-producing countries promised to pump more crude in an effort to stem runaway world energy costs which have sparked fears of a global recession.

After a week of intense diplomatic pressure from US and European policymakers, ministers from the 11-nation oil cartel, Opec, announced yesterday that they would add an extra 800,000 barrels a day, or 3%, to world production.

"Opec cares very much about stability in the oil market with fair and reasonable prices for consumers and is trying very hard to bring this about," said the Opec president, Ali Rodriguez of Venezuela, after their meeting in Vienna.

The announcement came as oil refinery picketing and "rolling road blocks" across the UK intensified with petrol companies admitting that up to 100 petrol stations, mainly in north-west England, had run dry.

Protests continued at Shell's giant refinery at Stanlow, Cheshire, and at Milford Haven in Wales - and the A1 near Alnwick was targeted by hauliers and farmers with a slow moving convoy blocking lanes.

Campaigners warned that 80 rolling roadblocks would start around England and Wales early today to complement a nationwide picket of depots. Welsh farmers are planning to dump 16 tonnes of straw outside the Shell plant at Stanlow today to prevent tankers leaving the refinery.

And last night there were increasingly confrontational scenes at the Immingham refinery complex at the mouth of the River Humber.

Blockades in France were scaled down yesterday but in Germany protests at the pro-green fuel tax saw the first blockades there.

The world's top consumer of oil, the US, called the Opec agreement "a step in the right direction". In the UK, the Scottish secretary, John Reid, welcomed the news.

However, energy analysts warned that while the deal - which was more generous than expected - should prevent oil prices from rising further, it was unlikely to reduce them significantly in the short term. Last week, oil prices hit a post Gulf war high of $34.50 a barrel.

Lawrence Eagles, from City firm GNI Securities, doubted the Opec decision would bring down prices to less than $30 - and warned that planned closures of European refineries for maintenance would keep up petrol prices by reducing supplies.

Opec has blamed heavy duties imposed by western finance ministries for the high petrol prices. "We think this is enough but we want consumer nations to work to reduce taxes," said Qatar oil minister, Abdullah bin Hamad Al Attiyah.

Yesterday's production increase is effective from October 1 and Opec also announced that it will review output again at an extraordinary meeting on November 12.

Mr Eagles said the announcement of the November meeting was a sign that the cartel was serious about tackling the oil shortage.

But most analysts believe it will be some months before prices ease back down to the $20-$25 a barrel comfort zone sought by politicians in the US and Europe.

webTitle: Real Lives: Adoption vetting procedures investigated in BBC1 programme Love is Not Enough

fields.headline: No soft adoption
fields.standfirst: Couples who wish to adopt are forced to go through a vetting procedure so intrusive that it can provoke feelings of rage and despondency. Does it really have to be like this?  Peter Lennon  reports
fields.trailText: Couples who wish to adopt are forced to go through a vetting procedure so intrusive that it can provoke feelings of rage and despondency. Does it really have to be like this? Peter Lennon reports
fields.body:
'It's like being burgled," Mark said. "You go back to your home and your house has a slightly nasty sort of feeling." Mark and his wife Sarah were not describing the aftereffects of having a BBC film crew in their home on and off for two years; they were referring to the agonising process couples go through when they want to adopt. The intimacy of the procedure particularly infuriated Mark and Sarah, prosperous company directors in Sevenoaks, because they had been vetted by the same Kent social services department a few years earlier when they applied to keep a Romanian baby, Joshua, now aged seven, whom they had brought into the country illegally.

A six part BBC Bristol series, Love is Not Enough: the Journey to Adoption, records the process in intimate detail. It is a sensitive and scrupulous record of the feelings and attitudes of everyone involved - prospective parents, children, foster parents, social workers and adoption panels. But Mark and Sarah mask their rage in front of the cameras: no one, they claim, dares to antagonise the social workers or adoption panels who will decide their future. But now that their adoption application has been accepted - they will fly to China to collect the baby girl this month - the couple feel free to lay into Kent council.

They claim it would be easy for dishonest people to hoodwink the social worker carrying out the vetting, and admit that while they did not lie to their social worker they tended to "withhold truths". They expressed admiration and liking for their social worker, Joanna: "No fault lies at her door," Sarah said. "She is told what to ask. But although she was the best, I'd never say to her, 'God, I have a terrible hangover.' All the time you are scared of political correctness."

"They want to know about your sex life, your money in the bank," Mark said. "You actually have to give a huge amount of a very private part of yourself, with the state sitting in judgment on the most important thing you ever want to do in your life. It goes on for months. Visits can be from one to three times a week, and can last up to three hours."

"Of course these checks need to be in place," Mark conceded. "But none of these checks would, for example, stop abusive natural parents. We are discriminated against. We are the unlucky ones who can't have their own kids and they are punishing us for it." Behind this outburst lies the maelstrom of emotions that churns through the adoption process and the desperate need that adoption couples have to be recognised as parents, as capable of giving unconditional love as any birth parent.

A spokesperson for Kent social services agreed that some people do complain about the intrusiveness of the vetting, but said it was a vital part of the process. However, adoption agencies tend to be insensitive to the emotional attachment that an adopting mother can establish with a child she has not yet met. Sarah had only seen a photograph of their Chinese baby: "I never believed that you could bond with a photograph," she said. "But now I carry that photograph with me everywhere."

"Sarah is there already," Mark said. "She has pretty much given birth. Her pregnancy has been from the time she sent the papers to getting the photograph. She is probably the only woman in the country who is 10 months pregnant - probably 11-and-a-half by the time we get there."

There are roughly 4,000 children eligible for adoption each year in the UK. But adoption panels have difficult choices to make. North Tyneside children's services was presented with a puzzle. Al and his wife Paula, both in their 30s, applied to adopt not one, but three to five children. The application was unusual as the couple had only been married for a short time and there was no medical reason to suppose that they could not have children. But they belong to an evangelical sect and believe that God has called on them to take care of some of Britain's abandoned children.

In the series we see members of their Christian group visit their home and, eyes downcast in humility, entreat the Lord to grant Al and Paula their wish. But then there was a phone call announcing that their application had been deferred. The adoption panel was worried that the couple might belong to a sect. "We were gobsmacked," Al said. "We had never heard of deferment."

Their social worker, Carolyn McKelvie, said: "When they first came to adopt they were keen to adopt a huge number of children - six or seven. There were reservations that they might want to be caretakers rather than parents. From the panel's perspective we needed to explore in more depth. But there was a feeling coming across that everything, references and so on, seemed to come from a very narrow area." We won't know until programme four whether Paula and Al were successful.

McKelvie admitted that the vetting procedure could be intrusive. "I offer no apology for that. We are very upfront from the beginning about the necessity for this. We are placing a child for life and we must find out about a couple's past. But the panels are realistic about how people actually live, and someone having a hangover wouldn't disturb us."

Even successful adoptions can threaten to unravel under pressure. Mark and Sarah's attempt to bring their Chinese child to Britain appeared to founder when a letter arrived from Joshua's birth mother in Romania, asking them to adopt her new baby. This threw Sarah into such emotional turmoil that the council sent back the social worker to reassess their commitment to the Chinese baby. Again the couple were infuriated by the re-examination.

A spokesperson for Kent social services pointed out that any "change of circumstances" must be reported to the Department of Health. The fraught situation was resolved when Mark decided to send the birth mother £150 a month to help bring up the new baby.

But for all the apparent will in this country to adopt, the councils are let down more often than the prospective parents. The failure rate in babies adopted is one in 10; for older children of seven to 12 it can be as high as 50%. "If you put out an ad," said Moira Gibbs, the new president of the association of directors of social services, "out of every 100 applications, you might get between five and 10 [suitable couples]. Most of them fall in the first phase when they learn about it in detail."

"If you want to criticise us it would be about crimes of optimism over experience," she said. "Very few people are turned down at the panel stage. People usually discover when they start the process that this is not for them. People think that adoption is just like bringing up your own children. But there is a third party in the equation - the natural parents. Because children have not only had a genetic endowment from their natural family which is not yours, but older children bring with them a whole history that you can't cut off."

Mark and Sarah make sure that Joshua maintains a clear link to his past, and will do their best to see that his new sister learns about her roots. This could be difficult: like all Chinese children officially offered for adoption, she had been abandoned. But they are determined to trace the two young bicycle repairmen who found her by a lake so that the child's origins won't be a complete blank.

 Love is Not Enough: the Journey to Adoption will go out on BBC1 from September 19 at 10pm. For those interested in adoption, the BBC will have a free helpline: 0800 888809.

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: • For all those workers facing long months of five-day weeks - with the next bank holiday not rolling in until Christmas - a glimmer of respite is in the offing. The government is considering a proposal to add another bank holiday to the UK's current miserly total of eight per year (compared with 14 in Spain and Germany, and 16 - which sounds about right - in Italy). After all, an extra day off on New Year's Eve once in a millennium does not a satisfied workforce make. Plans are underway, though, to schedule a national holiday at the start of June, with talk of combining it with the spring bank holiday to reward workers with a bonus long weekend away from the office. Just a couple of teeny complaints from WPM: the one-off day of rest is set to be timed to coincide with the Queen's Golden Jubilee... in 2002.
fields.body:
 For all those workers facing long months of five-day weeks - with the next bank holiday not rolling in until Christmas - a glimmer of respite is in the offing. The government is considering a proposal to add another bank holiday to the UK's current miserly total of eight per year (compared with 14 in Spain and Germany, and 16 - which sounds about right - in Italy). After all, an extra day off on New Year's Eve once in a millennium does not a satisfied workforce make. Plans are underway, though, to schedule a national holiday at the start of June, with talk of combining it with the spring bank holiday to reward workers with a bonus long weekend away from the office. Just a couple of teeny complaints from WPM: the one-off day of rest is set to be timed to coincide with the Queen's Golden Jubilee... in 2002.

 Still, it won't come a moment too soon for the nation's smokers, who by then will be desperate to add to the list of days when they'll be able to savour a cigarette between the hours of nine and five with impunity. Guidelines published last week by the health and safety commission recommend an almost total ban on lighting up in the office, although the proposals have yet to be accepted by the government. Three million workers would be able to breathe more easily - but could they stand the champing of jaws as bereft smokers turn en masse to the comforts of nicotine gum and pen lids?

 Be content, though, that your workplace worries are confined to such trivial matters as fresh air. The plight of the dot.com executive, as exposed in a survey by KPMG Consulting, is more desperate. Long thought of (well, since WPM heard of dot.coms, at least) as dynamic, technologically tuned-in, 21st century workers, it now seems that they are the most boring of bosses. They rarely socialise, travel economy class, feel that casual dress is "inappropriate" and expect to be working into their 70s. Feet on the ground, indeed - although, if forced to choose an alternative career (and why would they?), the most popular options were pilot or formula one racing driver.

 News reaches WPM that the NHS is set to advertise all its vacancies - rather less glamorous than motor racing, but totalling around 100,000 a year - online from spring 2001. Announcing the scheme, health minister Lord Hunt said, "Staff working in even the smallest rural trust or GP's surgery will be able to see at a glance all available posts throughout the NHS, encouraging them to apply for posts or promotion which previously they might not have known existed." WPM previously didn't know that NHS staff with a) time to flick through the net during working hours, or b) the salary to fund an online search through thousands of vacancies at home, existed.

 It's reassuring to know that personnel officers, there to look after a company's most valued assets (that's you, dear workers), are just a phone call away. At least, they're a phone call, a series of automated messages, a sequence of "Press 1 for queries about holiday pay" and a "please hold" away, before you finally reach the human element of human resources. Pub and leisure chain Scottish and Newcastle announced last week that it is to open a call centre to deal with queries from its 42,000 staff. Such as, what is company policy on using office phones for long calls?

 This week, WPM's favourite website is www.adminapolis.com, and not just because it believes secretaries to be "industry stalwarts" (flattery always works with us). No, it's because it promises to take care of such mundane matters as booking flights and temps, planning events, weeding out computer viruses, calling cabs and couriers, and translating documents. In other words, it would like to do the administrator's job for him/her. Which is nice.

 Joy as everyone's favourite lesbian former nun and Big Brother resident, Anna, is revealed to be an office manager (for a London skateboard company, of all things). Extra joy, as her official BB biography reveals one of her dislikes is "going to work".

webTitle: After 16 long days, free in 20 minutes

fields.headline: After 16 long days, free in 20 minutes
fields.standfirst:
Timing was crucial with the West Side Boys ready to kill at the first beat of a helicopter rotor
Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Speed was the crucial factor. The generals and strategists who had planned the rescue mission in minute detail knew full well that if the British troops failed to overpower the rebels swiftly and brutally, the lives of the hostages would almost certainly be lost. The first glimpse of a helicopter could have caused the notoriously volatile West Side Boys to start executing hostages.
fields.byline: Chris Mcgreal  in Freetown,  Steven Morris and  Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Speed was the crucial factor. The generals and strategists who had planned the rescue mission in minute detail knew full well that if the British troops failed to overpower the rebels swiftly and brutally, the lives of the hostages would almost certainly be lost. The first glimpse of a helicopter could have caused the notoriously volatile West Side Boys to start executing hostages.

Within 20 minutes of the mission starting, the hostages were in a helicopter being whisked back to the safety of a British ship anchored off Freetown. Their colleagues - including members of the renowned Parachute Regiment, backed up by the SAS - spent another 70 minutes in sporadic but fierce exchanges.

When the battle was over, 25 West Side Boys were dead and 18, including their leader, were captured. One British paratrooper was dead, one was seriously injured and 11 had less severe wounds.

Despite the deaths, military chiefs hailed the mission a success, but critics believe that it throws up more questions than it answers - wider questions about the precise nature of the British troops in Sierra Leone and, more specifically, exactly what the captured troops were doing in a rebel-held area.

The problems facing the planners of the rescue were legion. One defence chief said it was the "most complex" mission carried out by British troops for years.

First there was the very difficult terrain. The West Side Boys were based in two camps on either side of the Rokel creek, a 300m-wide river boarded by mangrove swamps, jungle, mud flats and scrubland. They knew the area intimately and were experienced in jungle fighting. They have tended to be portrayed as a bunch of ill-organised youngsters often high on drink and drugs. Yet during the battle, they were well-armed and aggressive.

Wreaked havoc

They had set up an effective encampment, straddling both sides of the river. On the northern bank was their headquarters, where the hostages were held, guarded by some 50 or 60 men and women. Another 50 or so were stationed in the village of Magbeni, on the southern bank.

British intelligence believed that in the immediate area there were about 200 members of the group. It was impossible for the troops to target only the northern camp, as the southern was equipped with heavy machine guns which could have wreaked havoc on the invaders. A two-pronged helicopter attack with synchronised landings at both camps was considered the best option.

The operation began at first light, 6.16am local time. There was just enough light for the five helicopters - two Lynx attack machines and three Chinook troop carriers - which ferried members of the crack 1st Battalion The Parachute Regiment into the camps, but enough gloom to give them a degree of protection. In all, 150 British servicemen were involved. The SAS role remains unknown, but it is thought likely that they had been on the ground, supplying information about the rebels, and would almost certainly have joined in the attack.

It was crucial that the troops, backed by fire from the Lynx helicopters and using mortars, were able to disembark rapidly and get to the hostages.

The helicopters landed within 100 yards of the camps and immediately came under "sustained fire", at first from within the village and then from the edges of the jungle when the rebels retreated.

Within 20 minutes the hostages were being flown out to safety. Heavy but sporadic gun battles continued for the next hour and a half until British troops secured the area. By mid afternoon all the British troops - along with the three vehicles which had been stolen by the rebels when they took the hostages - had been airlifted out.

Twenty five West Side Boys, including three women, were killed. Eighteen, including their leader, "Brigadier" Foday Kallay, were captured.

The six members of the Royal Irish Regiment, together with five who were subsequently released and a Sierra Leonean official, were captured on August 25. Mystery still surrounds the circumstances. Two days later the West Side Boys issued demands, including the release from prison of a leader named "Bomb Blast".

After five days of negotiations the army announced that it had secured the release of the five junior members of the British group. The delicate process of negotiation continued. But at the same time plans were being laid to free the hostages forcibly if the talks failed. They had tracked the rebels down to the camps on the Rokel creek - and begun detailed reconnaissance.

By the start of last week Tony Blair and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, were directly involved, discussing the matter with General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of defence staff, at a cabinet committee meeting. Defence chiefs warned that the rebels' threats to kill the hostages had to be taken seriously - and had been reinforced with "mock executions". The army also feared the rebels might move or split up the hostages.

Last Tuesday, the MoD sent out soldiers from the elite Parachute Regiment to the region. Defence chiefs urged the press not to dramatise the move, realising that it could spook the West Side Boys. The paras, who had spent some time in Sierra Leone earlier in the summer, flew to Senegal, then began arriving in Freetown on Thursday evening. The Lynx helicopters were brought on Hercules planes and assembled on the spot, and the Chinooks moved from Dakar, capital of Senegal.

It was still hoped that an agreement could be reached. There were discussions with the rebels as late as yesterday, but Mr Kallay returned to his original demands for the release of comrades from prison and the resignation of the Sierra Leone government. He said that if his demands were not met he would take the Britons further inland, implicitly suggesting that they would be handed to the rebel Revolutionary United Front.

In the eyes of the British officers present, that amounted to a death threat.

There were other worrying signs. The West Side Boys launched an attack on a rival militia on Thursday, prompting a response that took the fighting close to where the British soldiers were held. British negotiators were also disturbed that Mr Kallay was seen wearing a British army uniform, and that a heavily-armed captured Land Rover was used in attacks on the rival militia.

A secondary aim was to capture Mr Kallay, though yesterday ministers insisted that destroying the West Side Boys as a whole was not intended. Besides, intelligence experts had concluded that the organisation was not a coherent whole but a number of independent groups who could not be blasted out of existence in one swoop. The government also wanted to send a "powerful" message that it was not acceptable for rebel forces to take British hostages.

Mr Blair was contacted again on Saturday afternoon at Chequers to be told further details, and the fact that the raid would start at first light on Sunday morning. He again gave the endorsement.

Either way, the officers in charge will find it hard to explain away allowing themselves to be taken hostage by a group of drunken youths.

webTitle: Regiment founded in war and ready for anything

fields.headline: Regiment founded in war and ready for anything
fields.standfirst:
The paras Skills honed in the jungle were crucial

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The troops from the 1st Battalion The Parachute Regiment chosen for yesterday's rescue mission comprised some of the fiercest, most highly-trained frontline soldiers in the British army.
fields.body:
The troops from the 1st Battalion The Parachute Regiment chosen for yesterday's rescue mission comprised some of the fiercest, most highly-trained frontline soldiers in the British army.

Since their formation in 1940 the paras have built a formidable reputation for penetrating enemy lines, often in the most inhospitable and perilous of conditions.

Their role has had to change with the times. It is unlikely that troops will ever be parachuted en masse into a battle zone, as happened during the second world war. However the skills the paras were renowned for - surviving and fighting effectively after being dropped in enemy territory - are still crucial.

Each battalion of the regiment comprises up to 550 soldiers. One battalion always takes the "airborne battle group" role and is ready for quick deployment anywhere in the world, living up to the paras' motto, Utrinque Paratus - ready for anything. Each battalion includes specialists in sniping, demolition and communications.

"Train hard, fight easy", is one of the regiment's catchphrases. The paras have their own training company, with officers expert in rooting out recruits who do not have the physical or mental hardness to survive battle conditions. The regiment is keen to dismiss the idea that would-be recruits have to be "superhuman" and "as hard as nails", but the training remains notoriously tough.

Skills such as fighting in the jungle are honed during training exercises in places like Belize. The troops in yesterday's rescue are bound to have been familiar with the very difficult and dangerous terrain they faced. A crucial skill would have been knowing exactly how their equipment would work in wet and humid conditions. They are also familiar with working in tandem with helicopter back up.

The possible role of the SAS in the rescue remains unclear. The government, as always, refused to confirm or deny whether they were involved, but it would be no great surprise if they were.

The illustrious history of the Parachute Regiment dates back to June 22 1940, when Winston Churchill sent a note to the War Office asking for a corps of 5,000 parachutists to be raised. By September the following year the 1st Parachute Brigade was formed, followed by 1st Airborne Division by the end of 1942.

The Parachute Regiment 6th Airborne Division spearheaded the glider-borne raid and capture of Pegasus bridge in Normandy in the dead of night on June 6, 1944. The raid was immortalised in the film The Longest Day.

Despite its proud history, the regiment's long-term future has been unclear in recent years. After the Falklands war there was a hiatus during which the regiment was not sent into major combat zones, to the frustration of its rank-and-file soldiers and officers.

But in the past year or so the paras have seen duty in Kosovo, a three-week mission to Sierra Leone in May this year - during which time they killed four Revolutionary United Front rebels in a battle - and yesterday's rescue.

webTitle: Office hours: Ian Boughton on why we need to abolish the statutory retirement age

fields.headline: Working over time
fields.standfirst: Ian Boughton on why we need to abolish the statutory retirement age
fields.trailText: Ian Boughton on why we need to abolish the statutory retirement age
fields.body:
Those dreams of a travelling retirement will probably never come true. For most of us, the cottage in Provence will never materialise; nor will the regular mid-week outing to a country pub. The idea of working late at the office takes on a whole new meaning, and last week's proposal from the Liberal Democrats to abolish the statutory retirement age takes on a whole new practicality, when we realise that some of us are going to have to carry on into our 80s.

We can't say we weren't warned - it was a couple of years ago that insurance company Eagle Star first floated the idea that working into our pensionable years may not be a question of choice. In Britain, it said, two-thirds of early retirees are "shocked" at how quickly their working lives come to an end, and do not have enough money to fulfil retirement ambitions - even the odd game of golf is out of reach.

In the United States the situation is even worse - when the Department of Labour monitored 100 25-year-olds to find out what state they would be in at retirement age, they discovered that a quarter of them would be dead, another quarter would be getting by with family help, and the majority would fall below the poverty line. Only four in 100 would be self-sufficient.

So it is not surprising that the Lib-Dem proposals are winning support among pressure groups - although some may be surprised to learn that, for once, the bosses are not so keen to see their staff working late.

"People are reaching retirement earlier than they had expected," confirms Eric Reid, chairman of the Association of Retired Persons Over Fifty. "The average retirement age is now 61, and the reason for that is people being forced out by employers - it is financially advantageous to offer early retirement over redundancy because the employer can pass the cost on to their pension fund."

But for the retiring worker, he adds, it's not such good news. "The person suffering the shock of being 'offered' early retirement at 61 nearly always accepts it - but gets no state benefit, and so can often experience a very difficult four or five years. We would welcome the idea that retirement might be taken at any period between 60 and 70, combined with a firm commitment that the state pension may also be taken earlier."

Britain is behind the game in this, says Reid. In France, an employer must pay a penalty to social security for the cost of forcing someone to retire early; the Germans are introducing a 4% contribution to a scheme to pay for early leavers. The Swedes, says the Council Against Age Discrimination in Employment, were far quicker to introduce a "flexible decade" of retirement, with the result that three-quarters of workers in their 60s are still actively supporting themselves.

Meanwhile, the Geneva Association Conference, an international group of insurers, has proposed that those in danger of being pushed into premature retirement should have the option to continue working part-time, with some state cushion to do so, but this, Reid suspects, is not out of altruism. "They want to keep people working because they can't provide suitable annuities," he says. "Retirement is all very well if people have had years to build up private pensions, but the increase in age-expectancy means that we are all now going to have to acquire fantastic sums to get any kind of reasonable income. So, for one reason or another, everyone is agreed that people should be allowed to keep working - except the employers."

Not all employers, protests Sam Mercer of the Employers' Forum on Age. "Our members are the employers who recognise demographic shifts in the workforce, and the value of older staff," he insists. "But even they see problems - how do you manage someone as they get older, and may become less able to do their job? What do you do if your appraisal system becomes more difficult for them?

"Our members have been looking at the implications of introducing flexible retirement, and our report is due on September 17. It will give some examples of how our members are handling it, and other employers will probably be able to learn from it."

Let's hope that British Airways is among them. Reports last week that the airline was planning to relax its rule that requires cabin staff to retire at the age of 55, were accompanied by the less welcome news that those staff could be rehired as "new entrants", meaning a cut in salary from around £30,000 to £8,000. BA is one of the founding members of the Employers' Forum on Age, but insists it cannot afford to employ over-55s on their current pay levels.

Reform cannot come too quickly for Age Concern, which has just finished its "debate of the age" project, a two-year programme involving 1,500 events, debates and surveys. Policy priorities for immediate action went to every government minister and member of parliament last year, and the final papers have recently been published.

There are chilling predictions of what might happen if no answer is found for those who are capable of work - and who want to work - but who are retired before their time. One typical suggestion is that those whose savings run out or whose pensions prove inadequate will become the new "under class", and may have to return to some form of communal living.
