webTitle: Prime minister's trust in defence chief key to sanctioning use of force

fields.headline: Prime minister's trust in defence chief key to sanctioning use of force
fields.standfirst:
New Labour and military united
Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: It was altogether appropriate that Tony Blair secretly authorised yesterday's mission on   the eve of a speech to the UN in which he urged the world community to be bolder in the use of military force to defend human rights.
fields.body:
It was altogether appropriate that Tony Blair secretly authorised yesterday's mission on the eve of a speech to the UN in which he urged the world community to be bolder in the use of military force to defend human rights.

Mr Blair could hardly claim credibility as a world leader demanding a more pro-active and militarily decisive UN, the theme of the UN summit and his own speech, if he was not willing to free kidnapped British troops acting as UN peacekeepers in a former British colony.

But the decision to sanction the use of troops also reflects Mr Blair's implicit trust in Sir Charles Guthrie, the Chief of the Defence Staff.

Sir Charles's plummy vowels and deep pride in the British military would once have been anathema to Labour. He might even have been labelled a force for conservatism. In fact, he is seen as utterly reliable by Mr Blair. If, sometimes, the prime minister seems to be surrounded by feuding children in his Cabinet, he can find a form of relief in his senior military adviser.

The relationship has benefited from a confluence of interest between New Labour and the military. Labour's ethical foreign policy, and defence of human rights, has required a mobile military arm willing to enforce peace-keeping.

This doctrine found its first expression in the Ministry of Defence's strategic defence review. Its key pillar - the need to restructure British forces to undertake multi-national peacekeeping operations - was accepted by Labour. It required greater mobility, different equipment, a new kind of military training and a new mandate. It also required a bigger budget - over which Blair has shown he is willing to countermand the Treasury.

It was in the Balkans crisis last year that the close Guthrie-Blair relationship of trust was truly formed. If the military top brass had any fears that New Labour would not match the Thatcherite steel in a military crisis, they were dispelled over Kosovo.

Subsequently Sir Charles has praised Mr Blair's leadership role during the conflict and his willingness to defend the lengthy bombing campaign. He was also impressed with Mr Blair's private willingness to commit up to 50,000 troops to the crisis.

Mr Blair had the vital "in" with President Clinton, so providing Sir Charles with insights into how the Clinton administration was moving. Notes of the private phone conversations during the war between Clinton and Blair were provided to Sir Charles and to key figures in Nato.

fields.headline: Edmonds warns of pensions 'liability'
fields.standfirst: Special report: welfare reform
fields.trailText: The government's pensions policy has become its "biggest electoral liability", the GMB union leader, John Edmonds, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The government's pensions policy has become its "biggest electoral liability", the GMB union leader, John Edmonds, warned yesterday.

He pledged that his union would vote for the restoration of the earnings link at the Labour party conference later this month in spite of recent leaks of possible concessions.

Speaking on the eve of the TUC conference in Glasgow, Mr Edmonds said the stain of this year's 75p increase to the basic state pension would "take a lot of wiping away", adding that suggestions of a £100 means tested weekly pension guarantee would not buy off the growing Labour movement revolt.

"If Gordon Brown stood on a platform the week after next and said he would restore the earnings link he would be cheered to the echo," the GMB general secretary said. "He would do an enormous amount for party morale and he would be honoured by a very large part of the public - it would be an extraordinarily popular measure." The chancellor, who is due to address the TUC tomorrow, is anxious to head off defeat at the conference, where the GMB, public services union Unison and the Rail Maritime and Transport union are expected to back calling for the restoration of the pensions-earning link, broken by the Thatcher government.

Mr Brown and the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, met Unison general secretary Rodney Bickerstaffe and other union leaders to discuss possible compromises, which could give a significant pre-election boost to the incomes of poorer pensioners in particular. The current basic pension of £67.50 a week would be around £95 if the link had been maintained and so ministers have argued that a £100 guarantee would be an improvement on restoration.

But Mr Bickerstaffe said last night that such a move would "simply enlarge the area of means testing when the whole point is to find a way of giving 11m pensioners a dignified old age without making them jump through hoops".

But Mr Bickerstaffe said last night that such a move would "simply enlarge the area of means testing when the whole point is to find a way of giving 11m pensioners a dignified old age without making them jump through hoops".

fields.headline: Hostages freed in jungle battle
fields.standfirst:
Para and 25 rebels killed as rescue mission turns into biggest British firefight since Gulf war

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: A British paratrooper was killed and 12 others wounded yesterday when a dawn raid on two jungle villages to rescue hostages in Sierra Leone turned into the biggest firefight involving British forces since the Gulf war.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Freetown  and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
A British paratrooper was killed and 12 others wounded yesterday when a dawn raid on two jungle villages to rescue hostages in Sierra Leone turned into the biggest firefight involving British forces since the Gulf war.

The scale of the casualties raised questions about Britain's involvement in the West African civil war, but ministers were adamant last night that there would be no pull-out.

The raid, led by the Parachute Regiment and the SAS and codenamed Operation Barras, rescued the six British soldiers and one Sierra Leoneon held hostage deep in the jungle since last month by the renegade faction the West Side Boys.

The battle of Rokel Creek lasted 90 minutes, at the end of which 25 members of the West Side Boys were dead and 18 captured, including their leader, the self-styled brigadier Foday Kallay.

A high proportion of the West Side Boys are child soldiers and women. It was confirmed last night that three women were among the dead.

The 150 British troops arrived by helicopter and boat before 6.30am at two villages in the Occra Hills, about 50 miles from the capital Freetown, taking advantage of the poor light and early hour to surprise the West Side Boys, who had threatened to execute the hostages if they heard a helicopter.

The paratroopers targeted two villages, Magbeni and Gberi Bana, either side of the wide Rokel Creek.

The hostages were being kept on the south bank, less than a mile east of Magbeni.

The army said it met considerable resistance from the West Side Boys and that there was a "significant exchange of fire" in which the paratrooper was killed. While the hostages were secured, two Chinook helicopters fought to keep the West Side Boys at bay. The helicopters then attacked the villages and pursued the fighters into the jungle.

The hostages were flown to a navy supply ship after 20 minutes but the fighting continued for an hour and a half. One of the Britons was said to be seriously injured.

The British commander, General Sir Charles Guthrie, said: "The West Side Boys were not a pushover. They fought very hard."

He added: "This kind of operation is never without risk. We are not playing some stupid arcade game."

Explaining the background to the decision to go in, the British commander in Sierra Leone, Brigadier Gordon Hughes, said: "We had lost contact with the West Side Boys for a number of days. When contact was resumed [on Saturday] their unreasonable demands indicated that the captives were at extreme risk."

Tony Blair agreed in principle to the rescue on Wednesday and gave a final go-ahead to Sir Charles on Saturday. Speaking from Chequers, the prime minister said: "The operation was authorised once it became clear to us that the negotiations for their release were not being carried out in good faith and the lives of the hostages were in danger."

The ministry of defence said the West Side Boys had begun carrying out mock executions.

Mr Blair added: "I think we can be proud of the armed forces, there really are no finer armed forces anywhere in the world."

The Conservatives called for all British troops to be withdrawn because of the high risk involved in the civil war and because the British contingent, only 300-strong, was too small. The remaining West Side Boys, numbering more than 400, will now target British forces, regarding it as a blood feud.

The foreign office minister, Peter Hain, brushed aside Tory demands: "This is precisely the moment it is important to hold your nerve. If the West Side Boys had got away with this, it could have opened the floodgates to further hostage-taking.

"I'm surprised and saddened at this irresponsible demand which breaks the traditional all-party support for operations by our forces.

"Britain would not be respected if we were diverted from our policy when there are difficulties, nor would we be respected if we deserted our friends in difficulty.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, rejected suggestions that the army had underestimated the West Side Boys. He said: "These are not drug-crazed individuals. They have fought a very determined fight and clearly are very capable."

The six rescued British soldiers, from the Royal Irish Regiment, were flown to HMS Sir Percivale off Freetown. They were said to be physically and mentally exhausted.

They were being debriefed by the army last night on how they had been taken hostage by an indisciplined gang. Five others who had been released earlier by the hostages were unable to offer an explanation, saying they had only been following their officer.

Their capture, on August 25, was regarded by the MoD as a national humiliation. The successful rescue operation has helped restore British credibility in Sierra Leone.

The hostages had been held in mud and bamboo huts in a mosquito-infested swamp area. Their commanding officer, Colonel Simon Fordham, said they were unharmed, but had been held under "very poor conditions".

He added: "They did their best to look after themselves as best they could. They looked remarkably well considering the ordeal they have been under."

Those rescued phoned their families. A spokesman for the families said later that their joy at the release was overshadowed by news of the death of one Briton.

An MoD statement attempted to put the fatality in context: "Casualties are regrettable but are at the low end of the scale for such a difficult and complex operation."

fields.headline: Andrew Meldrum @ Harare
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: It is 5am. Equipped with a Thermos, an apple, my cellphone and a wad of cash, I drive out on to the streets of Harare in search of diesel for my car. Following a tip from a trusted friend I go to a nearby service station and, sure enough, I spy a queue of more than 60 cars, buses and trucks. Where there's smoke, there's fire and I think I have found a place that will sell the precious liquid.
fields.body:
It is 5am. Equipped with a Thermos, an apple, my cellphone and a wad of cash, I drive out on to the streets of Harare in search of diesel for my car. Following a tip from a trusted friend I go to a nearby service station and, sure enough, I spy a queue of more than 60 cars, buses and trucks. Where there's smoke, there's fire and I think I have found a place that will sell the precious liquid.

I position my vehicle in the queue and settle in for the long wait. As dawn breaks, I take a stroll and see people sleeping in their vehicles, some drinking tea from flasks and many others huddled in groups discussing the situation. The fuel queues that snake throughout Harare are lively centres of political discussions.

Zimbabwe's racial and class divisions break down as everyone finds common cause in blaming the government for the fuel shortage. Black truck drivers, white housewives and Asian shop owners shake their heads in disgust at the dire straits of the Zimbabwean economy. One woman blames the war in the Congo. A man says it is corruption. Everyone agrees that things will not get better until Robert Mugabe leaves power.

After reaching that conclusion they get back to the pressing matter of getting diesel. How long is the queue? How much fuel did the station get yesterday? Will they let us fill up? Or will they only sell us a quarter of a tank?

Zimbabwe has been suffering a shortage of petroleum-based fuels since December last year because President Mugabe's government has run out of the foreign exchange needed to import adequate supplies. Zimbabweans have watched with interest as France threatens to grind to a halt because of the week-long blockade on its petroleum fuels. "The news makes it seem like they have it bad in France," said the manager of a factory which makes rubber hoses. "They say businesses cannot make deliveries. Well, we have had those problems all year. Imagine trying to keep a factory going when you cannot get regular supplies and you cannot make regular deliveries. It is a nightmare. But we carry on."

Everyone in Zimbabwe has been struggling to cope with a drastic fuel shortage for the entire year. It is estimated Zimbabwe has been operating on less than 50% of its normal consumption for 10 months. In September the situation became even more desperate, especially for diesel. Tankers bringing fuel from Kuwait arrived at the Mozambican port of Beira, landlocked Zimbabwe's nearest outlet to the sea, but they refused to offload their cargo because they had not been paid. The state-owned National Oil Company of Zimbabwe has defaulted on so many payments that Zimbabwe has lost all international lines of credit and must now pay cash up front for all deliveries of fuel.

By 7am the sun is up and the heat of the day begins to rise. Tempers also become heated when a vehicle tries to wedge in at the front of the queue. People who slept in their vehicles all night jump out and shout at the driver. He glumly drives to the back of the queue which is now more than 150 vehicles.

Police are now patrolling the area to prevent any violence. The shortage of fuel is so desperate that there have been shootings and brawls in queues. For a week now, police have been called out to maintain order.

The queue begins to move and we all rush back to our cars and trucks. I read the paper and every few minutes start my car to move forward. Some are so short of fuel they push their cars along the queue. The sun is now high and scorching but I don't mind because I am now in sight of the pumps. I can't believe my luck when I pull up and get a full tank.

It is after 11am when I drive home. I am tired and hot and the morning is shot, but I am elated with my score. I have a full tank, but the nagging thought is that the Zimbabwean economy is running on empty.

fields.headline: UK 'will not be deflected'
fields.standfirst:
Hostile acts will not stop British efforts, says minister
Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The British government is braced for keeping forces in Sierra Leone for years in spite of setbacks such as yesterday's firefight that resulted in British casualties.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, and Chris McGreal  in Freetown
fields.body:
The British government is braced for keeping forces in Sierra Leone for years in spite of setbacks such as yesterday's firefight that resulted in British casualties.

The bloody operation to rescue hostages was not seen by ministers yesterday as a reason to bring the small contingent of soldiers home. "We will not be deflected. We always expected there were going to be incidents like this," one said.

The intervention in May was a moral one. But the hostage-taking and the subsequent bloodletting raises legitimate questions about British involvement. Did Britain blunder by pulling out the bulk of its forces too soon in June? Is the contingent it left behind too small for the job it is being asked to do? And why is Britain not operating under the UN flag, as other countries are doing?

Two weeks ago ministers and officials from the foreign, defence, overseas development and other departments met in Whitehall to discuss involvement in Sierra Leone against the background of the 11 British soldiers having been taken hostage.

The meeting had been scheduled before the hostage-taking and was born out of wider concerns: some officials privately questioned whether ministers had a credible strategy in place that would allow Britain eventually to pull out of the country with honour.

British policy is being driven by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who was deeply affected by the sight of thousands of limbless victims of the rebel Revolutionary United Front on a visit to Freetown in June.

All options, no matter how extreme, were discussed at the meeting. Some were raised and dismissed almost immediately, such as a huge offensive of Nato-style proportions to wrest control of the diamond-producing areas from the RUF, denying them their prime source of income. In the end ministers opted to stick basically with the strategy they have been working on since pulling out the bulk of forces in June.

The strategy is to have a contingent of about 300, and to train the Sierra Leone army (SLA) to a standard at which it will be capable of defending Freetown and making inroads into the rebel heartlands, the diamond-producing areas that fund the war.

It is a daunting task - but no less daunting is the other half of the strategy: hoping that the chaotic UN peacekeeping force can get its act together sufficiently to bolster the SLA when it eventually goes into action.

It was UN fear that the RUF was about to capture Freetown again in May that led to British intervention. As it turned out, the fear was misplaced. But the presence of British troops did temporarily instil confidence in the SLA and the UN peackeeping force.

The British commander who led the intervention in May, Brigadier David Richards, set about welding the various pro-government military factions into a single army. That included the West Side Boys, who initially fought hard and with results under what was euphemistically described as the "guidance" of a British officer.

The British helped provide a perception of strength. Their Harriers, flying low over RUF territory, provided a frightening form of intimidation for many of the rebels. The image of strength permeated pro-government forces even though they were poorly trained and ill-equipped, raising morale and shaking the RUF's confidence. Even the UN started to look as if it was in Sierra Leone to do more than enjoy the beaches.

But when the British withdrew most of their forces in mid-June, the strategy started to fall apart. Pro-government fighters suffered a number of setbacks, and even turned their guns on each other on occasions. The UN decided it was not going to be so robust after all.

More UN troops are on the way but it is not numbers that matter but quality, and the ability to work together. There is a serious lack of both, as the Guardian revealed on Saturday in a leaked report from the Indian commander, General Vijay Jetley, who accused the Nigerian army of wanting to control the UN force as a cover for diamond smuggling. The Nigerian military yesterday called for the removal of Gen Jetley, describing him as "incompetent, lacking in courage" and as having lost control of UN forces.

The UN needs support, so why is the British force not operating under the UN flag? It is mainly because British forces are small, and it was not thought worth putting such a minor force under UN control. Also, the UN force was originally conceived as being mainly African, and British troops only joined in May.

fields.headline: Broken renegades on the run
fields.standfirst:
West Side Boys' Leaders are held and face trial

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: When it came to the use of force to rescue the six British soldiers and one Sierra Leonean officer held hostage by the West Side Boys, the SAS and Parachute Regiment could simply have plucked out the captives and left.
fields.body:
When it came to the use of force to rescue the six British soldiers and one Sierra Leonean officer held hostage by the West Side Boys, the SAS and Parachute Regiment could simply have plucked out the captives and left.

But the West Side Boys, a group of several hundred renegade soldiers and escaped convicts, not only would have been free to continue murdering, raping and terrorising ordinary Sierra Leoneans, but would have remained a taunting reminder of the UN's continued failings in Africa, and with it the shortcomings of British policy.

"Brigadier" Foday Kallay, the 24-year-old leader of the West Side Boys, was more fortunate yesterday than many of the men, women and children he led. He was captured in the raid, but 25 of his group were killed, according to the British military.

The army yesterday said nothing about the circumstances of the capture - whether he fought fearlessly alongside those of his troops who stood their ground, or tried to flee with the others. He has escaped with his life, for now, but the Sierra Leone government says it will put him on trial for abducting the British soldiers. There are also grounds to try him for murder, rape, extortion and robbery.

And that is just in recent weeks. Two years ago the West Side Boys took part in the wholesale killing and mutilation of civilians when they fought alongside the rebel Revolutionary United Front during a raid on Freetown.

Mr Kallay could face the death penalty, along with two other leaders of the West Side Boys who are already in prison - "Brigadier" Bomb Blast and "Brigadier" 55 - whose freedom was one of the conditions for setting free the British hostages.

The government has good reason to want to see them in the dock, apart from the moral issue of holding them accountable for their crimes. They will neatly offset protests from international human rights groups of a double standard in Sierra Leone justice.

The RUF's founder, Foday Sankoh, is facing the prospect of trial before both an international tribunal and a local court for his varied abuses. Human rights groups have demanded that others, not only the RUF, be held accountable for the atrocities that have brutalised Sierra Leone.

Yesterday's raid is likely to spell the end of the West Side Boys as Sierra Leoneans have suffered them. Their leadership is broken; their fighters have sustained the kind of attack they never imagined. Some are prisoners, others are on the run. The UN says it will pursue them and shoot any who refuse to disarm.

But that does not mean that the drugged up young men and women who followed Mr Kallay will not continue to create misery. Some will attach themselves to other militia groups. Last night, a group was reportedly heading toward RUF lines.

Perhaps they will switch sides again. No doubt a few will apply to join the new army being trained by the British, on the grounds that they have combat experience.

webTitle: Message in a bottle flushes out secret of folk charm to ward off witches

fields.headline: Message in a bottle flushes out secret of folk charm to ward off witches
fields.trailText: Chemical analysis of a sealed 17th century bottle found in the foundations of a Surrey house has revealed not a secret Jacobean wine stash but a revolting folk charm against witches.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy , arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Chemical analysis of a sealed 17th century bottle found in the foundations of a Surrey house has revealed not a secret Jacobean wine stash but a revolting folk charm against witches.

It is made of human urine, pubic hairs, an eyelash and a handful of bent pins. The witch bottle, as such charms were known, still contained almost half a pint of 300-year-old urine.

Witch bottles were made by people who believed their illness or misfortune, the death of family members or livestock, meant they had been cursed.

The bottles were intended to turn the curse back on the witch. Although the urine was that of the victim, it was believed there was such a strong link between the curser and the cursed that the charm would work on the witch, for as long as the bottle remained sealed.

Alan Massey, a retired organic chemist from Loughborough University who carried out the analysis, said: "In this case the curse was intended to make the unfortunate object of it feel as if they were weeing with a bladder full of bent pins."

His work, published in the journal Current Archaeology, has proved the folk belief that such bottles did contain human urine. Although more than 200 witch bottles, dating mainly from the late 16th to the early 18th centuries, have been found, almost all were broken or empty.

This witch bottle was found sealed with all its contents intact despite being buried more than 300 years ago in the foundations of a house which was demolished in the 18th century near the ramparts of the castle in Reigate.

It was discovered by the archaeologist David Williams, who jumped to the obvious conclusion about a sealed wine bottle. "I managed to get a local vineyard interested and they arranged to open the bottle, test the contents and possibly organise a tasting," he said.

"When the cork was pulled there was a rather alarming hiss of escaping gas. They could find no trace of alcohol - or indeed anything organic. I then poured the contents through a strainer, and out fell all these pins and other bits and pieces."

The bottle went to Mr Massey, who was already testing finds for Brian Hoggard, a postgraduate student from Worcester University, who is completing a thesis on witch bottles.

He has traced hundreds of reports of bottles found in the ruins of hovels and mansions. The earliest finds date from the late 16th century in Nottinghamshire and the most recent from a mid 19th century cottage in Pershore, Worcestershire. "It was believed that they would cause such agony that the witch would come to your door and beg to be released from the curse," he said.

He also analysed the nine brass pins and proved that they had been bent as a single bunch. Bending the pins was a symbolic killing, as well as intended to torture the witch.

Mr Hoggard found it impossible to trace the occupants of the long-demolished house in local records, never mind discovering whether they suffered any exceptional bad luck.

Mr Massey believes it may be possible to DNA test the human hairs which were floating in the liquid, to get a profile of the maker of the witch bottle. "The bottle was already old when it was buried. The man who blew it was probably alive in the 1665 plague and the Great Fire of London."

webTitle: Pressure builds on Falconer as dome roof needs patching

fields.headline: Pressure builds on Falconer as dome roof needs patching
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Twelve holes have been found in the roof of the Millennium Dome as the minister responsible for the fiasco last night again faced renewed calls for his resignation.
fields.body:
Twelve holes have been found in the roof of the Millennium Dome as the minister responsible for the fiasco last night again faced renewed calls for his resignation.

Lord Falconer looked increasingly beleaguered as Downing Street refused to be drawn on whether Tony Blair and his family, who still have not visited the attraction, would ever make their way to Greenwich.

Peter Mandelson, the Labour minister initially responsible for the dome, yesterday declined to take the blame for the project's failure.

Speaking on BBC TV's Breakfast with Frost he said: "If there have been mistakes more recently or this year then they should certainly be an inquiry into those. They should be examined and they should be brought out."

He later qualified his remarks, which could have been interpreted as a poor defence of Lord Falconer, by saying if there had been any mistakes, they were made by managers.

Mr Mandelson said since 1998 he had been just a bystander and blamed the lower than expected visitors on media fury against the project.

He also qualified Labour's responsibility by asserting the decisions on design, location and conception had all been made by the previous Conservative government.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, again called for Lord Falconer's head after saying he should have been aware the dome's costs were "out of control" as long as as nine months ago when he was shown a report by Deloitte & Touche, the auditors hired by the millennium commission to monitor finances.

He said copies of the reports would have been passed to the minister, a close friend of Mr Blair, so he could not pretend that he did not know.

"These reports and figures must be published," Mr Ainsworth said. "It is the public's money which has been thrown at this disastrous failure. They have the right to know why."

The auditors have produced a number of reports for the commission - which last week bailed out the dome with an extra £47m of national lottery money to bring its running total to £839m - the latest of which apparently backed up the critical evaluation by PricewaterhouseCoopers which led to the appointment of troubleshooter David James.

The millennium commission has refused to publicise the reports until after a national audit office report is published next month. But it is thought that Deloitte & Touche put the original likely attendance at the dome at only 8m, 4m less than the number the dome claimed it would attract.

The New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome, has always maintained that it needed 10m to break even.

Yesterday an NMEC spokesman confirmed that six "dinner plate-sized holes" in the Teflon-coated roof of the dome had been patched but denied reports that it had cost up to £14m. "That's nonsense. The roof is under guarantee so the repairs have all come under that."

He said the holes, which include a larger one over the entrance itself, were caused by cranes puncturing the tent while the contents were being put in place.

"These sort of accidents happen," he said. "They are really small beer. Birdair, the American company responsible for putting it up, have made the repairs. "There are a handful of other holes as well but these are having no effect on the dome. They're very small so we're just leaving them for the moment."

He added that the punctures should be seen in context. "The dome is the biggest roof in the world.

"It is a 25-acre surface and these holes would be like pinpricks when you compare them to the scale of a normal house."

The spokesman confirmed that Birdair have given a 25-year guarantee on the roof, five years less than the assurances first given by Mr Mandelson, who insisted the dome would last for more than 30 years and could possibly survive for half a century.

Despite Lord Rogers's revolutionary design, the roof has never lived up to his vision of a pristine shallow orb. Design problems with the Teflon coating meant it attracted dirt and even in the early days visitors complained about how grubby it looked.

fields.headline: Tory dissident Critchley dies
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Sir Julian Critchley, the veteran Tory dissident renowned for his biting wit, has died at 69 after a long battle against cancer. The former Aldershot MP passed away peacefully surrounded by his family, his son Joshua said yesterday.
fields.body:
Sir Julian Critchley, the veteran Tory dissident renowned for his biting wit, has died at 69 after a long battle against cancer. The former Aldershot MP passed away peacefully surrounded by his family, his son Joshua said yesterday.

Sir Julian enjoyed a long and lively career at Westminster, where he gained a reputation as a rebel for fearless attacks on his superiors and for his outspoken views on Europe, which finally led to him being expelled by his party. The Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, yesterday paid tribute to a character whom he said would be sorely missed, describing him as "a colourful MP over many years, whose wit brought sparkle to the Commons".

When Lady Thatcher was prime minister, Sir Julian was one of her greatest backbench critics, calling her a "great she-elephant" and coining the verb "to handbag" to describe her method of dealing with opponents. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said: "Julian was a great friend and mentor to me. He had an acute understanding that politics is a serious business, but the politicians to worry about are the ones that take themselves too seriously."

webTitle: Unions urge action on pay greed

fields.headline: Unions urge action on pay greed
fields.standfirst: TUC in Glasgow
fields.trailText: The TUC yesterday demanded that the government acts to end the scandal of boardroom greed and to close the widening gap between company directors' pay and the salaries of their employees.
fields.body:
The TUC yesterday demanded that the government acts to end the scandal of boardroom greed and to close the widening gap between company directors' pay and the salaries of their employees.

Labelling company boardrooms "Britain's closed shops", unions warned that they would urge fund managers and other shareholders to vote against excessive top pay packages or, ultimately, boycott company products.

TUC research shows that last year the highest paid directors of the top 1,000 companies earned 20.7 times the average salary of their employees, compared with 15.7 times in 1994. Over the five years directors' average pay, excluding lucrative share options and bonuses, rose by 72% from £239,000 to £410,000, while their employees received an average 18% increase, from £17,332 to £20,485.

"Government, public concern, and attempts at self-regulation seem to have made no impact," the TUC said. "A key reason is that a closed 'you scratch my back and I will scratch yours' circle of non-executive directors continues to dominate remuneration committees." It accused companies of breaching their agreed codes of conduct and adopting a "one rule for us and one rule for them" attitude towards employees.

Unions joined forces with shareholders earlier this year in trying to block the £10m "performance" bonus for Chris Gent, the chief executive of Vodafone, after the takeover of German mobile phone group Mannesmann. They also con demned the £1m pay-off for the sacked British Airways chief, Bob Ayling.

Today the GMB union will launch a campaign against boardroom greed by parading Luc the Pig at the conference in Glasgow - a reference to Luc Vandevaelde, the Belgium chairman of Marks & Spencer given a £2m "golden hello" and to an earlier campaign against Cedric Brown, then chief executive of British Gas.

The TUC condemned companies for awarding bonuses and share options to directors when profits barely rose above the rate of inflation. John Monks, TUC general secretary, said unions "are looking at ways of hitting companies where they are most vulnerable in relation to shareholders and markets". A long-standing government review of company law, including measures to force more shareholder votes at annual meetings, has been shelved until after the general election.

The TUC wants union representatives to sit on remuneration committees, the creation of a wider pool of non-executive directors, and for basic pay increases on the board to reflect those of other staff.

Early termination packages, it said, should be based on those offered to other employees, while shareholders should vote on a company's remuneration report at annual general meetings and elect the remuneration committee chairman each year.

12,000 heating and ventilation engineers have won a pay rise of 27.3% over three years in a deal negotiated by the MSF union which gives a basic rate of £10 an hour.

webTitle: Blair and Brown feud claim '100% wrong'

fields.headline: Blair and Brown feud claim '100% wrong'
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was interviewed for a new book which claims he repeatedly feuded with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, over the single currency, health spending, the planned sacking of the governor of the Bank of England and his reluctance to cooperate with cabinet colleagues.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was interviewed for a new book which claims he repeatedly feuded with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, over the single currency, health spending, the planned sacking of the governor of the Bank of England and his reluctance to cooperate with cabinet colleagues.

Downing Street claimed the book, written by Andrew Rawnsley and serialised in the Observer yesterday, was 100% wrong. It was dismissed by a Treasury spokesman as malicious and unsubstantiated gossip.

The spokesman said it was "laughable" to suggest Mr Brown had earlier this year threatened to resign in protest over a speech by the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, implying Britain had to join the euro if manufacturing was not to be left defenceless. However, the personal involvement of the prime minister in the Rawnsley book makes it more difficult to dismiss all its claims as the figment of the author's imagination.

Mr Rawnsley's account came as the Mail on Sunday serialised an unauthorised biography of the cabinet minister, Mo Mowlam.

The book, by Julia Langdon, claims Ms Mowlam felt humiliated by the way in which she was sidelined by Blair and other Downing Street officials in the Northern Ireland peace talks. The extracts claims that Bill Clinton, the US president, was warmer to her than Mr Blair. She apparently told Mr Clinton: "Don't you know I am the new tea lady around here?"

Both books confirm that Ms Mowlam turned down Mr Blair's offer to become health secretary after he told her she had to be shifted from Northern Ireland.

On being told by Mr Blair that she had to leave Northern Ireland, Ms Mowlam first asked to be made foreign secretary, but when Mr Blair insisted there was no vacancy, she asked to be appointed defence secretary.

The books claim Ms Mowlam had contempt for Mr Mandelson and distrusted his personal assurances to her by phone in the summer of 1998 that he was not seeking to take over her job. Mr Mandelson is said to have described her as terminally undisciplined.

The Langdon book also alleges that Ms Mowlam's messy sex life led to an alarmed John Smith, then Labour leader, refusing to promote her to a senior job. It also details claims that in the early 90s, Ms Mowlam fell out with Mr Brown, blighting her chances of promotion.

It suggests Mr Brown believed Ms Mowlam was briefing the press that he was gay.

The Rawnsley book - the fullest account yet of Labour's decision to rule out membership of the single currency in this parliament - alleges that Mr Brown failed to brief Mr Blair properly of his plans.

In stead the chancellor gave the prime minister only a short account at a time when Mr Blair was distracted by reports that Clare Short, the international development secretary, might face charges over an altercation with a police officer over security checks at the Labour conference.

The book claims Mr Brown's decision to shift the policy through an interview in the Times was agreed with Alastair Campbell, the press secretary.

Once the first edition of the Times appeared, an amazed Mr Mandelson rang Mr Blair at Chequers and asked him if he had agreed the policy change. Mr Blair apparently said: "I don't know."

The prime minister then tried to contact Mr Campbell but his press secretary failed to answer his calls.

In desperation, Mr Blair then rang the chancellor's press secretary, Charlie Whelan, and asked him to reverse the policy. Mr Whelan, who had been briefing the media from the Red Lion pub near the Commons, said it was too late.

The book also claims Mr Brown shouted at Mr Blair over his decision to announce plans for a huge increase in the health budget. Mr Brown told Blair: "You have stolen my fucking budget."

It also claims that Mr Brown wanted to sack the Bank fof England governor, Eddie George, as soon as he came to power and the governor had to be reassured by Mr Blair personally.

The Rawnsley book also suggests that Mr Brown had contempt for Mr Blair's knowledge of economics. He is quoted as saying: "Tony wants to tax less, spend more and borrow less. Our job is to make it add up for him".

webTitle: Army intelligence officers face questioning in Finucane inquiry

fields.headline: Army intelligence officers face questioning in Finucane inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Police investigating the murder of the Belfast solicitor Patrick Finucane 11 years ago are planning to arrest and interview under caution more than two dozen former members of the force research unit, a shadowy intelligence outfit which ran army agents.
fields.body:
Police investigating the murder of the Belfast solicitor Patrick Finucane 11 years ago are planning to arrest and interview under caution more than two dozen former members of the force research unit, a shadowy intelligence outfit which ran army agents.

Detectives involved in the Stevens inquiry, also probing allegations of security force collusion in terrorist murders, planned the move after the army granted its request for thousands of secret documents last month.

Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan police commissioner, is heading his third inquiry into events linked to the Ulster Defence Association's shooting of Patrick Finucane in front of his family in his north Belfast home in February 1989. Commander Hugh Orde is leading a team of 20 Met detectives on a day to day basis.

Among those Sir John's inquiry is expected to interview is Brigadier John Gordon Kerr, commander of the FRU when an earlier Stevens investigation discovered the UDA intelligence officer Brian Nelson was an army agent. Kerr is now British military attache in Beijing.

Meanwhile Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday called for fresh examination of several of the IRA's arms bunkers. Ulster Unionists, facing a difficult by-election test in south Antrim next week, said any inspections were no substitute for decommissioning.

webTitle: Lord with too much silver: please help

fields.headline: Lord with too much silver: please help
fields.standfirst: Stately home owner offers sandwiches to stair polishers
fields.trailText: There's many an aristocrat been forced to sell the family silver; not quite so many who try to have it polished for free.
fields.body:
There's many an aristocrat been forced to sell the family silver; not quite so many who try to have it polished for free.

But Lord Palmer, owner of one of Scotland's finest stately homes, is looking for volunteers to buff up his priceless silver plated staircase because he says he cannot afford a cleaner.

Lord Palmer, 48, inherited Manderston House in Berwickshire in 1978. The 108-room building has the world's only silver plated staircase, which in Edwardian days took three servants three weeks to bring to a shine.

For most of the past two decades, a retired couple took on the task of polishing the stairs, but since they quit three years ago, Lord Palmer has found it difficult to find volunteers.

"One always dreaded the day when they left," he said. "They did a wonderful job and I was grateful they lasted so long.

"We did have a new set of volunteers who came and did it once, and they thoroughly enjoyed it, but they found it a bit too much."

The lord, whose family was part of the Huntley and Palmer biscuit empire, admits he is enormously rich "on paper" because of the value of Manderston but says he is struggling to survive on dwindling income from farming and tourism and cannot afford to pay someone to polish.

"It is soul destroying to run two businesses, both of which are running out of money. The fact is I simply cannot afford to employ anyone to do the job. If anybody would like to volunteer it would be marvellous."

Manderston was built in the 1790s and was eventually bought by Lord Palmer's great-great-grandfather Sir William Miller, who made his fortune trading herrings with the Russians.

The estate and his fortune all passed to his second son, Sir James Miller, in 1887, who ordered a lavish rebuilding of the country house in 1903.

Asked how much he could spend on the refurbishment, the architect John Kinross was told: "It simply doesn't matter."

These generous terms allowed Mr Kinross to design the silver staircase, topped with a solid brass rail, which Lord Palmer admits is "priceless" in its own right.

When Lord Palmer moved to the estate in the 1970s, where he lives with his wife, Lady Cornelia, and three children, the staircase had not been cleaned since the first world war.

"It really doesn't take very long and I would provide wine and sandwiches for any new volunteers," he said.

"If it was eight or nine friends it would be quite a jolly thing to do."

webTitle: Post workers get shirty after being told to smarten up

fields.headline: Post workers get shirty after being told to smarten up
fields.trailText: Post Office managers have spent £20,000 as part of an attempt to get postal workers to tuck in their pale blue shirts.
fields.body:
Post Office managers have spent £20,000 as part of an attempt to get postal workers to tuck in their pale blue shirts.

Senior executives fear that the flying tails offend the public, and that they send out the wrong signal for the Royal Mail as a professional business. Delivery staff are to be told by supervisors to put back their shirt tails into their trousers.

The public corporation decided to enforce a dress code after a survey discovered that householders and companies favour the more formal look.

Consultants Taylor Nelson Sofres sent a set of 10 photographs, five showing shirts in, five showing them left out, to 200 customers who were each interviewed for 15 minutes.

The £20,000 exercise found that more than 90% of those interviewed preferred delivery men and women with their shirts in, though the majority was slightly larger when long-sleeved shirts were worn rather the short sleeved variety.

Responses yesterday from workers at London's giant Mount Pleasant sorting office were largely unprintable. But one female employee, who had her shirt out, said: "It's a lot cooler. [Our chiefs] should try working, instead of sitting in an office and dreaming up things like this."

The style attack comes as the Post Office faces the threat of increased competition from private couriers under Whitehall and European plans to curtail its monopoly on letters and packages where the charges is £1 or less.

The Communications Workers Union leader, Derek Hodgson, who tucks his tails in, accused managers of wasting time and money trying to stamp out loose shirts. "Some Royal Mail managers seem to be suffering a priority recognition crisis. This shirt business doesn't tie in with the real challenges the Post Office faces."

Style author Stephen Bayley suggested that finding the 1m letters which were lost each week should have been given priority. He commented: "It would have been far better to spend £20,000 on researching whether the Royal Mail should or should not collect and deliver letters accurately and efficiently. But since that's substance rather than style, it's out of touch with contemporary thinking."

A Royal Mail spokesman said: "The research was conducted as part of discussions between Royal Mail and the CWU over the introduction of new uniforms.

"The research shows that customers expect postmen and women, in whom they have a great deal of trust, should have a smart appearance."

webTitle: Analysis: Labour will win the next election

fields.headline: Hedging the bet
fields.standfirst:
Pollsters are agreed that Labour will win the next election. But they are keen to emphasise that it's difficult to predict by how much
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Pollsters are agreed that Labour will win the next election. But they are keen to emphasise that it's difficult to predict by how much
fields.body:
American political scientists have just held their annual get-together and the consensus was strong: using five different measures (including that old standby, the state of the polls on Labor Day, September 4, the unofficial start of the campaigning season), Al Gore comes out ahead in November's presidential poll.

Here, having burnt their fingers in 1992, elections experts are circumspect. Tony Blair will win the general election everyone expects will take place next May. But at a Political Studies Association conference last weekend at Edinburgh University, they sought to hedge the bet. The question becomes: what could possibly happen between now and next May to upset the apple cart?

History, as the Financial Services Authority insists we are reminded before we buy a policy, is no guide to the future. But landslide victories do not always last. The great Liberal triumph of 1906 dissipated at subsequent elections. Similarly, Clement Attlee's triumph in 1945 turned to ashes in 1950. Apply the 1945-50 rate of attrition to Tony Blair and next May he will win 382 seats (38 down on 1997). Apply the 1906-10 rate of attrition and he will still be winning some 375 seats, with handsome majorities over all parties in both cases.

Except that - number-crunchers are quick to point out - is not quite the right way of putting it. Labour did not, as conventional wisdom has it, win a landslide in 1997 - it was a Tory collapse. Labour took only some 850,000 more votes in May 1997 than in 1992. More to the point, the Tories took 1,260,000 votes fewer in 1997 than in 1992. The Liberal Democrats also lost, recording 330,000 fewer votes in 1997 but in the "right" seats. By luck and judgment they amassed votes in seats where they were in head-to-head contests with Tories.

Put in these terms, the critical seats next election are the 152 won by Labour from the Tories, constituencies encompassing some 10.5m electors. Among these are two key groups - voters who switched their allegiance from Tory to Labour and ex-Tories who simply could not bring themselves to vote in 1997. This sounds like Philip Gould territory. There are some data on which of Labour's 1997 voters are remaining loyal, in the sense of telling pollsters they intend to vote Labour again next time. More up Mr Gould's street is working out what is pushing "defectors" - of whom there seem, interestingly, to be more among foremen and supervisors than either the salariat or the working class and more in Scotland than Greater London. The defection pattern is mixed geographically: Labour is losing relatively more in the south and midlands than other regions. The only consistent predictor of tendency to defect seems to be housing tenure - which implies that Labour's "heartland" among council tenants is as secure as ever. Worryingly for pro-Europeans, anti sentiments are strong among defectors: according to one survey, 25% of defectors from Labour want to leave the European Union altogether. Even half of Labour loyalists would vote against membership of the euro.

But no one is saying Europe is going to be an issue that determines votes at the general election, however people may vote in a one-off referendum - but it is going to be tricky for Labour to negotiate these shoals. (Surveys last month confirmed that, unprompted, the largest number of people said health was the most important issue facing Britain today.) Pro-Europeans cosily imagine that when debate gets going, sentiment will turn as people learn more. It could go the other way. According to one study, the more the media go on about Europe, the firmer anti views will become, and the more the Tories will benefit.

The same study turns out to be complimentary to journalists. During election periods, thanks to media attention to issues, voters do learn considerably more about what is at stake. Their voting intentions and their attitudes become more consistent the closer we get to actual elections. One conclusion is that polls taken in between elections are less reliable, because people are paying less attention to issues and not really thinking much about their electoral preferences.

But we must not exaggerate. Some 35% of the public do not regularly read a national daily newspaper, according to the latest data collected by Mori. (It included the Daily Record, Scotsman and Herald and the Sunday papers.) And remember, people do not read newspapers for political news - they read them for television and radio listings (this was the top category in a 1996 Mori study for the City University), for lifestyle, health information and entertainment.

So will the media do anything during the next six months or so to affect the outcome? There is little evidence that the bias of newspapers has any causal weight.

So if the Sun (18% of all regular newspaper readers) changed its tune and went with Hague, would voters follow? The answer is complicated by the "don't knows". Readers of a sample of papers who won't vote and the don't knows constitute 26% of Sun readers. What could Wapping possibly do to encourage them? A Murdoch campaign for civic participation would be interesting to witness.

Which leaves the pollsters unwilling to say it out loud but conclusive. Nothing is going to happen during the next six months to dislodge Labour's considerable lead.

webTitle: Roy Hattersley: A civil war among ministers?

fields.headline: A civil war among ministers?
fields.standfirst:
The cabinet should spend more time fighting about real issues

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The cabinet should spend more time fighting about real issues
fields.body:
According to Peter Mandelson, speaking to the party faithful last Saturday, the name New Labour defines the distinguishing feature of the government - a restless quest for new ideas and unflagging enthusiasm for reform. Unfortunately, Sunday's papers suggested that it bears a different trademark. The headlines announced that the party's high command is engaged in unremitting civil war. Blair snubs Mowlam. Mowlam smears Brown. Brown defies Blair. And Mr Mandelson himself pops in and out of the political undergrowth like a guerrilla striking a swift blow before he disappears back into the landscape.

I do not doubt the stories' truth. Mo Mowlam, announcing that she checked the facts of Julia Langdon's biography, confirmed them. Other governments have behaved in just the same way. John Major, not realising that his comments were recorded, called four members of his own cabinet "bastards" and suggested that one of his backbenchers should be accompanied by "men in white coats". The problem for Mr Blair is that he and his colleagues were expected to behave differently. New Labour was above such things.

That is why, at least to a degree, Mr Mandelson is right. The organisation that he helped to found, after the real Labour party died with John Smith, is defined by image and attitude not ideology. So we must expect that the arguments that divide its members are more concerned with presentation than philosophy. The cabinet in which I served was deeply split over economic and industrial policy - the application for an IMF loan and the imposition of wages policy on the trade unions. We argued about those issues fiercely (and sometimes bitterly). That left us neither time nor energy to worry about the PM treating a colleague like a tea lady or the propriety of the chancellor speaking to the press without notifying Number 10.

No doubt Mr Blair would argue - with a degree of justification - that it is better for the cabinet to be split by personal animosities than by doctrinal disputes. But the notion that ministers do not like each other is deeply damaging to the favourable image by which the party's leaders set such store. The damning question asked about Labour in the 70s and the Tories 20 years later was: "If they cannot agree amongst themselves, how can they run the country?" It will be repeated time after time because of the personal antagonisms that have been revealed this week.

Ironically, those revelations are, at least in part, the results of Tony Blair's determination to avoid even the suggestion of a split. Cabinet meetings now last for less than an hour. One senior minister complained that circulating papers for discussion with colleagues is regarded as disloyalty; everything has to be decided in "one-to-one" meetings with the prime minister. The devil finds work for idle tongues. Politicians who are prevented from arguing about serious subjects will find solace in trivia.

All governments try to hide disagreements. But at least disputes about how to reduce poverty, improve education and end discrimination can be justified by the claim that they are prompted by beliefs too deeply held to be suppressed. The discovery that the chancellor's press secretary was told to moderate the Treasury's antagonism to early entry into the euro and answered: "Sorry Tony, it's too late," suggests a government that is not wholly in control of events. Since only half a dozen people were present when the impertinence was uttered, it also makes plain that New Labour's obsession with media management is out of control. Members of the government (and their servants) are managing the media against each other.

The revelations of the last two days will make little difference to Mr Blair's prospects of a second term. And the PM is entitled to recall that the last Labour government, which I boast spent its time disputing policy options, lost the general election of 1979. So, if re-election is all that matters, yesterday's revelations are no more than an irritant. Winning is important. But it is not, or should not be, all that a party is about. Almost every new fact that we learn about this government confirms that everything is subordinate to that single aim.

It is not only Mr Blair who holds that view. Last Friday the prime minister made a speech about comprehensive education that most Labour party members must have recognised as ignorant nonsense. Commentators were unanimous in the view that it was intended to restore his radical reputation. Yet there has been no protest either against the caricature of our secondary schools or in favour of education speeches being made out of interest in education rather than concern for image. The moral of this week is that New Labour argues about too little not too much - and usually about the wrong subject.

fields.headline: Over an oil barrel
fields.trailText: Why is the west nervous about oil prices?
fields.body:
Why is the west nervous about oil prices?

President Clinton told the oil producers' cartel Opec last week that they risked killing off the world boom which is driving demand for oil if they did not increase output to reduce prices. Recessions have followed oil price shocks three times in recent economic history: in 1973, 1979 and 1990. The cartel's most powerful member, Saudi Arabia, is well aware that the current boom in prices could easily backfire if western economies crash which is why it persuaded fellow Opec members to open the taps. However, analysts think this is unlikely to get prices down below $30 a barrel.

Why is that?

World demand for oil is very high because most big economies are enjoying healthy growth. The world economy expanded at its fastest pace in 10 years during the first quarter of 2000, at a time when Opec was reducing oil supplies after prices crashed as low as $10 a barrel during 1999. Strong demand and restricted supply resulted in prices peaking at a post-Gulf war high of $34.50 last week, despite three increases in production from Opec so far this year. This weekend's output increase will take some of the steam out of the market, but probably not enough to get prices down to $25 a barrel, which is the level the west would prefer.

Will high oil prices cause the world economy to crash this time?

There are two schools of thought on this. Some analysts believe western economies are less oil-dependent than they were because advances in information and communications technology are the drivers of growth rather than energy-dependent industry, particularly in the US. It is true that economies such as the US and Britain which are dominated by the service sector rather than manufacturing need less oil to grow than they used to. The Economist estimates that rich economies use only about half as much oil for every dollar of GDP than they did in the early 1970s. That could be why investors until recently have been quite relaxed about oil prices.

And the other view?

That higher oil prices lead to recession, sure as night follows day. The leading Cassandra in this school of thought is Professor Andrew Oswald from the University of Warwick. He believes that rising energy prices are the best predictor of a slump and is scornful about the claims of the new-economy school, arguing that the recovery in the world economy since the crisis in Asia three years ago owes much to the lower oil prices which prevailed then. He thinks it will take about 18 months for the tripling of oil prices seen since the start of 2000 begin to filter through into higher unemployment.

Are there any signs of a slowdown?

Not yet in Britain. However, the west's leading economic think-tank, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, estimates that each sustained $10 increase in oil prices shaves 0.25% off growth in the west and adds 0.5% to inflation. The reaction of central banks to rising inflation will probably be critical in determining the outcomes for growth.

What have they done?

In the US and Britain, central bankers have not acted despite rising fuel costs pushing up inflation in the manufacturing sector. The more hyperactive European Central Bank has pushed up borrowing costs, even though inflation in the eurozone in well below US levels. The key question for the bankers will be whether workers will demand higher wage increases to compensate for increased fuel costs. One recent estimate was that the average British family's petrol bill has increased by £400 since the beginning of the year. In the 1970s the boom was killed by wage earners demanding increases to compensate for rising prices, leading to a wage price spiral. Inflation is lower now than it was then and there is no evidence that outside the energy sector price pressures are getting out of hand. If central banks do not have to stamp down quite so firmly on the brakes this time then the west could continue to grow. However, the optimists who in the past predicted that the world economy would escape unscathed from an oil price shock have tended to be wrong.

He believes that rising energy prices are the best predictor of a slump and is scornful about the claims of the new-economy school, arguing that the recovery in the world economy since the crisis in Asia three years ago owes much to the lower oil prices which prevailed then. He thinks it will take about 18 months for the tripling of oil prices seen since the start of 2000 begin to filter through into higher unemployment. Are there any signs of a slowdown? Not yet in Britain. However, the west's leading economic think-tank, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, estimates that each sustained $10 increase in oil prices shaves 0.25% off growth in the west and adds 0.5% to inflation. The reaction of central banks to rising inflation will probably be critical in determining the outcomes for growth. What have they done? In the US and Britain, central bankers have not acted despite rising fuel costs pushing up inflation in the manufacturing sector. The more hyperactive European Central Bank has pushed up borrowing costs, even though inflation in the eurozone in well below US levels. The key question for the bankers will be whether workers will demand higher wage increases to compensate for increased fuel costs. One recent estimate was that the average British family's petrol bill has increased by £400 since the beginning of the year. In the 1970s the boom was killed by wage earners demanding increases to compensate for rising prices, leading to a wage price spiral. Inflation is lower now than it was then and there is no evidence that outside the energy sector price pressures are getting out of hand. If central banks do not have to stamp down quite so firmly on the brakes this time then the west could continue to grow. However, the optimists who in the past predicted that the world economy would escape unscathed from an oil price shock have tended to be wrong.

webTitle: Allow more tigers out of their cages

fields.headline: Allow more tigers out of their cages
fields.trailText: Have the gates to the developed world clanged shut for good? The obstacles to new countries joining East Asian tigers such as Taiwan and South Korea have piled up.The path to development has never looked so steep.
fields.body:
Have the gates to the developed world clanged shut for good? The obstacles to new countries joining East Asian tigers such as Taiwan and South Korea have piled up.The path to development has never looked so steep.

Fifty years ago, Korea was poorer than Sudan. Its main export was wigs made with human hair. Today it is an industrial leader, shrugging off a financial crisis in 1998. Taiwan has achieved the unique feat of combining high-speed growth with one of the fairest distributions of income in the world.

At least until the onset of the Asian financial crisis, the World Bank attempted to claim the tigers as success stories for free market economics. In fact, countries such as Malaysia, Korea and Taiwan proved adept at combining a high level of state intervention in allocating credit, nurturing new industries and acquiring new technology, with the strengths of market forces in encouraging competition and efficiency. Above all, the East Asian "miracles" have been built on a clear industrial policy aimed at developing locally owned industries, if necessary through protection and laws which give them privileges compared to foreign investors.

But are these lessons still relevant? "Doing a Korea" is becoming increasingly difficult. The speed and scale of technological innovation is accelerating, making it harder for poor countries to reach the "technological frontier" as Korea did in the 1970s thanks to massive state support for its nascent hi-tech industries. These days it costs billions to develop a new product, and firms have only a few years (sometimes only months) to recoup the investment. The costs of failure are huge.

It is harder for developing countries to acquire and adapt the latest technology as international patent law has become more restrictive. Protectionism may be out of favour in trade, but it is alive and well in the knowledge economy.

Most worryingly, the international system governing trade and investment is closing down the ability of poor-country governments to follow the kind of policies that lay behind the East Asian miracle. Countries which have opened up to international capital markets find themselves at the mercy of that elusive entity "market confidence". Any step away from the Washington free market consensus can trigger a mood-swing among investors and a run on the currency. As one Brazilian economist observed: "Here the people get to vote every four years, the markets every four seconds."

Structural adjustment programmes, often imposed on countries by the IMF and World Bank, have opened up economies to foreign trade and investment, reducing the levels of protection for local industries. These days, the World Trade Organisation covers much more than trade, since barriers to trade can comprise almost anything a government does inside its own borders, such as subsidies, investment laws or tax regimes. For WTO officials, the fact that governments are prohibited from reversing free market reforms bar exceptional circumstances prevents states falling prey to vested interests. It can just as easily prevent them from doing what is best for their people.

Pessimists conclude that the rich countries have pulled up the ladder behind them, using the global trading system to keep poor countries in their place as providers of raw materials and cheap labour. Optimists point out that the WTO still leaves plenty of options open, such as funding research, or setting up science parks for fledgling companies. The real dangers are twofold. The first is that, if developing country governments swallow the story that only deregulation and market forces are permitted, they will fail to exploit the room for manoeuvre that still exists.

The second is what happens next at the WTO. Once the US elections are over, the rich countries will return to the negotiating table abandoned at Seattle. They want agreements on areas that could severely reduce the remaining space for national development policies - for example, barring governments from favouring local companies in their procurement policies or setting even tighter rules against different treatment for foreign over national investors.

Campaigners, north and south, should be making the case for an international system that protects and encourages, rather than undermines, national development strategies.

Duncan Green is a policy analyst at Cafod, the Catholic aid agency

webTitle: Game effort to revive fortunes of Scots emblem

fields.headline: Game effort to revive fortunes of Scots emblem
fields.trailText: On a day's stalking through the ancient pine forest of the Strathspey estate, Frank Law's journey would once have been brightened by the sight of dozens of capercaillies brooding in the trees or feeding on blaeberries.
fields.body:
On a day's stalking through the ancient pine forest of the Strathspey estate, Frank Law's journey would once have been brightened by the sight of dozens of capercaillies brooding in the trees or feeding on blaeberries.

But now the game manager rarely spots Britain's largest game bird.

Over the last few decades the decline of the capercaillie has been dramatic. As recently as the 1970s, there were around 20,000 capercaillies flying through Scotland's pine woodlands. Today there are only 1,000 left in the bird's habitat, east of the Great Glen.

"It's not so long ago that capercaillies were considered a pest," says Mr Law. "Then, by the start of the 80s, they became a much rarer sight. Even before the scientists came along, we knew there was a problem."

The problem now is critical. Conservationists are currently losing the battle: the capercaillie is declining at a rate of 16% per year. If that is trend continues, the bird will disappear from Scotland's woodlands in about 10 years.

"It is on the verge of disappearing from Scotland," says Kenny Kortland, the RSPB's capercaillie project officer.

One of the greatest threats to the distinctive bird - the male has black and deep green plumage relieved only by a scarlet patch around the eye - is recent change to Scotland's climate. Colder and wetter Aprils mean blaeberry, the ca percaillie's favourite food, does not grow at the time when the female bird needs it most. The lack of proper nutrients results in weaker chicks and the chicks have been then hampered by wet and cold summers.

Deaths of capercaillie adults, however, remain one of the biggest threats.

Since the 1960s, Scotland's deer population has exploded. The sight of a stag roaming through the glens may be a shortbread tin image of Scotland but they cause major damage to woodlands. Estate owners, however, are generally reluctant to keep deer numbers down.

It is a matter of economics: the more deer for shooting, the more valuable the estate. But the deer population means forests are stripped and new trees are not given the opportunity to grow.

To get round this, estate owners resort to erecting mile after mile of fences around woods. These fences are the greatest man made threat to the capercaillie.

"The capers fly relatively low, and they get up a fair bit of speed, and they smack right into them," said Mr Kortland.

About 8% of adults die on the fences and one quarter of chicks die on them. The forestry commission has helped to remove 120km of fencing in the past few years but it is not enough.

There are further worries about fragmentation of the habitat. Capercaillies need large areas. On the RSPB's Speyside estate of Abernethy, one of the greatest priorities is recreating the capercaillie's natural habitat. Trees are planted to allow the birds to fly freely, deer are culled so fencing is not needed, and blaeberries flourish.

"This is the ideal for the caper but we can't hope to recreate this across Scotland," says Mr Kortland. "What we have got to do, though, is persuade the estates of the benefits of looking after the caper.

"After all, it's near the top of the food chain. If we can't keep that there's not much hope for a lot of other things."

Scottish Ornithologists Club

fields.headline: In from the cold
fields.standfirst:
New Labour mends fences with the TUC

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Their membership is rising for the first time in two decades - and rising substantially, especially when job losses in manufacturing industry are taken into account. The prime minister has just agreed to welcome their general secretaries into his presence once every quarter. There are even expectations, so far unconfirmed, that the chancellor of the exchequer may choose this moment to announce a generous new deal for pensioners, rather than face the wrath of the unions this week and the Labour party conference at the end of the month. There are other signs too that the climate has changed - like the confirmation that proportional representation has been swept clean off the agenda in the recognition that the party and the unions simply will not stand for it.
fields.body:
Their membership is rising for the first time in two decades - and rising substantially, especially when job losses in manufacturing industry are taken into account. The prime minister has just agreed to welcome their general secretaries into his presence once every quarter. There are even expectations, so far unconfirmed, that the chancellor of the exchequer may choose this moment to announce a generous new deal for pensioners, rather than face the wrath of the unions this week and the Labour party conference at the end of the month. There are other signs too that the climate has changed - like the confirmation that proportional representation has been swept clean off the agenda in the recognition that the party and the unions simply will not stand for it.

Such is the cheering context which greets the TUC's arrival in Glasgow. In the build-up to the election and in the first months of office, Mr Blair seemed constantly eager to distance himself from the unions and even from the party he led. The calculation was obvious. As Conservative newspapers ransacked their files for pictures of Arthur Scargill on the warpath, or the wretched scenes from the winter of discontent which brought about Labour's defeat in 1979, he was thumping across the message that things were not going to be like that any more. There would be no going back under Labour to over-mighty union barons, deals done over beer and sandwiches and under duress, and so on, which had made the unions distrusted and feared.

His first TUC speech as prime minister seemed more than detached - almost hostile. The TUC would be listened to, but only on the basis that other lobbies were listened to - with no more warmth or comradeship, it appeared, than the CBI. Indeed, the unions often felt in those days, and with reason, that Mr Blair looked more at home with the CBI than he did with them. But now there has been a thaw. There are various reasons for that. First, the very reduction in union power has helped make the unions more popular. Some causes for which the unions have fought, though they seemed at the outset to be received with little enthusiasm by Mr Blair and his colleagues, have now proved their worth: even the Conservatives no longer dissent from the minimum wage. Concessions initially made with some apparent reluctance and amid a barrage of Conservative and employer complaint, like the right to union recognition, have in practice produced none of the disastrous consequences forecast. But the change goes further than that.

Mr Blair was never a conspicuous fan of the unions. Yet over recent months, and especially when low turnouts and lost elections showed heartlands disaffection, there has been a new appreciation that, however much the middle ground needs to be wooed, the unions and the grassroots party are still essential for success. There is also, no doubt, a powerful sense of how badly the party needs the unions' money. The unions will be hoping now to move the government further: toward, for instance, the resurrection of tripartite bargaining - government, employers and unions together - a process which has yet to be rehabilitated. But this week should underline the extent to which the terms of trade have already changed in the unions' favour. It was fashionable not long ago to forecast the drifting apart of Labour and the unions and to argue that this was a process which ought to be beneficial to both. That argument is fading, and may look even frailer by the end of this week.
