webTitle: Statehood delay dashes hopes of Arafat's people

fields.headline: Statehood delay dashes hopes of Arafat's people
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinian leaders put their people's dream of statehood on ice yesterday, at the same time keeping the peace process alive by postponing a declaration of independence that had been fixed for Wednesday.
fields.body:
Palestinian leaders put their people's dream of statehood on ice yesterday, at the same time keeping the peace process alive by postponing a declaration of independence that had been fixed for Wednesday.

The PLO's central committee said it would meet again on November 15 to discuss ways of putting Palestine on the map, short of declaring a state, such as drafting a constitution, and seeking entry to the United Nations.

Such pledges will not diminish the bitter disappointment felt by most Palestinians at the decision to defer statehood once again - seven years after the start of the peace process. But the move by Palestine's mini parliament does give negotiators some breathing room to try to reach a final settlement with Israel.

"We have to look at what is important to our people here on Palestinian land," said Mohammed Nashashibi, the Palestinian finance minister. "The date is not important for the people."

Mr Nashashibi said Palestinian officials would press Israel in negotiations, which are to resume today, for control of international borders and natural resources, especially water, and access to world markets.

The Palestinian decision was forced by Israeli opposition to a unilateral declaration, given teeth by the threat of its prime minister, Ehud Barak, to annex territory in the West Bank and Gaza where the Palestinians have had self-rule for six years. That threat - and the fear of a spiral of violence - also extinguished international support for a declaration on September 13.

Still, Mr Nashashibi insisted: "There is no such thing as half a state. We are on our way to full sovereignty, and there is no turning back. Peace is coming whether we like it or not."

But to Palestinians that means a state with East Jerusalem as its capital - a concession the Israelis are loath to grant, especially when it involves holy places.

The aspiration is made tangible in the statue of the unknown Palestinian soldier in Gaza's main square, whose assault rifle is pointed towards the holy city.

For ordinary Palestinians, the delay is a crushing blow. They have their own tricolour flag, which flies over Gaza and parts of the West Bank, their own cult of personality in the portraits of Yasser Arafat plastered almost everywhere, a form of parliament, a police force, and even a national airline - with three planes. But without agreed borders, they lack the very basics of statehood.

"Only when we declare a state can we get our rights. Israel is playing with us like a ball, and the world does not give a damn," said Tahsin al-Dera, in Palestine Square in Gaza.

Members of the central committee had said earlier that they would not put off independence indefinitely.

"We do not want to keep this delay open-ended because this will let Barak carry out all his plans, and we will be stuck in self-rule forever," said Salim Zanoun, the head of the CC, who had argued against the delay.

Prospects for a breakthrough in the next four weeks of secret talks now look increasingly dim, with the two sides deadlocked on the question of Jerusalem. Several members of the central committee said they had given up hope of an agreement until after President Clinton leaves office in January.

"I am waiting for the day that the administration of President Clinton and the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, will end," said Hani al-Hassan, secretary-general of Mr Arafat's Fatah faction of the PLO.

"So long as the president represents the Israeli point of view, how can we reach an agreement? It is clear he is not a neutral man."

Although Israel reacted favourably to the expected delay of a declaration of independence, the acting foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, was not optimistic. "I don't see that the chance [of a final peace being reached] is all that great," he told Army Radio.

fields.headline: Love and marriage
fields.trailText: Coronation Street | Other People's Children | The Sight | New Midsomer Murders | A Touch of Frost
fields.body:
The most striking thing about the wedding of Mike Baldwin and Linda Sykes in Coronation Street (ITV, Sun), not counting Rita's hat, Mike's second name turning out to be Vernon and the bunches of grapes on Linda's gown, was that it took place at all. Soap weddings mostly don't. A truism which The Vicar of Dibley exploited with joy at the wedding of Alive and Hugo: "Stop! Stop! The groom is married to me. Sorry! Wrong church!"

Mike and Linda's nuptials, sponsored as is currently fashionable by a chocolate bar, went swimmingly. For a while. But as Al Read said (and I'd like to dig that man up and shake his hand for his perspicacity), "There was enough said at our Edie's wedding." Home truths were not long coming. Mike's son kicked off. "Do you know the biggest joke in the world? Me and your lovely wife here have been having an affair behind your back." Mike's furrowed brow furrowed further. He had paid for this lad's education. Surely that should be: "I and your lovely wife here have been having an affair"?

The beauty of having a bit of brass and holding your wedding in Ye Olde Manchester Moated Grange is that you can have your row in a tasteful private suite instead of brawling in the street like normal people. Mike and Linda were not normal, as best man Roy Cropper pointed out in his memorable speech. Roy had been drafted in as a last-ditch replacement, as Mike's son, the original best man, was drinking his way through the minibar in the bridal suite. The violinist had long exhausted her limited repertoire. It was either Overhead The Moon Is Beaming again or it was Roy Cropper as best man. So it was Roy.

Now Roy, if you haven't met him, is like George Washington, apart from the wooden teeth, of course. He cannot tell a lie. If the Queen turned up in Weatherfield with no clothes on, Roy would mention it with the kindest intentions. A man without guile is a walking bomb, so Roy's reassuring words to Mike were calculated to shake the stoutest heart. "Just put your mind at rest. I've prepared a few reflections appropriate to the occasion."

Roy's Appropriate Reflections, which should be collected in book form, went like this. "I can't say I know Mike that well at all or, indeed, his good lady wife, but I do know that their romance hasn't always met with universal approval. Not only is there the obvious difference in their ages but also because, when their relationship began, he was the successful, well-to-do businessman and she was the lowly factory machinist."

Or, as they would put it in the Rovers, Baldwin's wed a bloodsucker in suspenders.

Sky One ran The Sight , a quirky Anglo-American entry with Andrew McCarthy as an amateur detective who could see ghosts. ITV scratched. They withdrew a new psychological thriller, Where There's Smoke, and entered instead a couple of hairy-hoofed old warhorses, New Midsomer Murders and A Touch of Frost .

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Book Of The Week | It's My Story: Death Row Rookies
fields.body:
Martin Bell reads excerpts from his memoirs in Book Of The Week (9.45am, Radio 4). The independent MP for Tatton ruefully admits that his famous electoral victory over Neil Hamilton brought the painful discovery that much of Westminster's power and influence had been stolen by the courts, Brussels, the media, or Downing St. He is out of tune with the times, liking little about modern politics, but regrets his promise to stand down at the end of this parliament.

A new weekly documentary series starts with the experiences of British law students spending a couple of months in the US to defend prisoners facing execution. It's My Story: Death Row Rookies (8.0pm, Radio 4) follows four of the youngsters as they discuss the evidence with the defendant, talk to witnesses, and even interview some of the jurors in the original trial. This is not a theoretical exercise: the defendant's life may depend on these last-minute investigations.

webTitle: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Bill Paxton in Impulse

(Graham Baker, 1984)

Who?
Texas native Paxton moved to LA when he was 18, where he ended up working as a set dresser for low-budget guru Roger Corman under the pseudonym Peter LeTrek. He wrote and directed the video for Fish Heads, by Barnes and Barnes - one of the weirdest songs ever - in 1982, and was a member of rock band Martini Ranch. His role as the abusive big brother who gets turned into a giant turd in Weird Science (1985) got him noticed (as you'd expect), but his small part in The Terminator (1994) brought him to the attention of James Cameron, who gave him the breakthrough role of the obnoxious Private Hudson in Aliens (1986). Other major roles were in Apollo 13 (1995), killer-wind flick Twister (1996) and A Simple Plan (1998). He's back in the blockbuster league for mountain-climbing thriller The Vertical Limit.

The role:
Eddie, the brother of Jennifer (Meg Tilly). He runs the family dairy farm with their father. When Jennifer returns home with boyfriend Stuart (Tim Matheson) in tow, she finds that everyone, Eddie included, is acting strangely.

Best line:
Jennifer and Stuart join Eddie for dinner at the family home. When Stuart praises the farm-fresh milk, Eddie says "Straight from the tit to the table."

Cringe factor:
He doesn't have much to do except brood in the farmyard, and he pulls that off fairly convincingly.

Other wannabes:
Hero Tim Matheson, who starred in Animal House (1978), continued acting. Meg Tilly hasn't made a film since 1995.

Critical judgement:
Leonard Maltin calls it a "plodding reverse variation on Invasion Of The Body Snatchers".

Also not starring in:

He was "punk leader" in The Terminator (1984) and appeared in 1981's Night Warning (aka Butcher, Baker, Nightmare Maker).

Impulse, Carlton Cinema, Wednesday Sept 13, 9pm.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Hobson's Choice | The Craft | The Omen | Afterglow
fields.body:
Hobson's Choice

(David Lean, 1954)

5pm, Carlton Cinema

Delightful screen version of Harold Brighouse's stage comedy, filmed in Salford. It's beautifully played, with Charles Laughton as the overbearing, boozy bootmaker tied up in knots by eldest daughter Brenda de Banzie and her dim but lovable husband, John Mills. Funny, and warm as a ferret up a trouser leg.

The Craft

(Andrew Fleming, 1996)

8pm, FilmFour

With its four teenage girls ganging up to challenge their outsider status at a posh LA college, the references come thick and fast in this funny supernatural tale - Heathers meets Witches Of Eastwick by way of Carrie. Robin Tunney is the new girl at school whose telekinetic powers bring her into the orbit of punkette Fairuza Balk, the scarred Neve Campbell, and Rachel True, a black victim of racism. Together they form a coven and start to exact revenge, with some genuinely chilling tricks up their sleeves.

The Omen

(Richard Donner, 1976)

11.35pm, FilmFour

More black magic. When people call young Damien a little devil, they ain't kidding. The adopted son of American ambassador Gregory Peck (Charlton Heston was first choice) and Lee Remick has an impish sense of humour, making his nanny hang herself, for instance. But then, Damien is the son of Satan. Quality horror, this; scary without overly resorting to gore, the hair-raising Ave Satani screeching away in the background and a cast including David Warner, Billie Whitelaw and Leo McKern that takes it seriously.

Afterglow

(Alan Rudolph, 1997)

1.25am, Sky Premier

Leisurely, painfully comic study of two failing marriages. Jonny Lee Miller is young, ambitious, sure that everything is fine at home; but sexually frustrated wife Lara Flynn Boyle is far from happy and instantly attracted to philandering repairman Nick Nolte, husband of Julie Christie's fragile ex-movie actress. The relationships are finely drawn in indie director Rudolph's witty, perceptive script.

webTitle: TV and radio: Head On The Block. BBC2

fields.headline: A man of ideals
fields.trailText: If the German educationalist Torsten Friedag were a Harry Enfield character, he would have the tag Hopeless Idealist or Trusting Liberal. Friedag - Labour's first £70,000-a-year Superhead, charged with reviving a ruined school in Finsbury Park - candidly described his disastrous experience to John Humphrys on Radio 4.
fields.body:
If the German educationalist Torsten Friedag were a Harry Enfield character, he would have the tag Hopeless Idealist or Trusting Liberal. Friedag - Labour's first £70,000-a-year Superhead, charged with reviving a ruined school in Finsbury Park - candidly described his disastrous experience to John Humphrys on Radio 4. It now turns out that his media-friendliness was not merely after the event. A camera crew followed him throughout the job for Head On The Block (Thursday, 9.50pm, BBC2), a compelling three-part series.

It has become a reviewer's truism that the future of the observational documentary is threatened by the wariness of the participants. Anyone who had seen The House or another of the early excursions in the genre would either refuse to admit the cameras or behave with obsessive circumspection in their presence.

But Torsten Friedag disproves this, because of a personality so emollient and trusting that you feel he'd agree to an offer from a stranger in the street to look after his wallet and car keys for him. The series is like watching the innocent in a thriller or panto. You keep wanting to scream to Friedag: "They're behind you!" Or rather, in the case of the students, not behind you.

Simon Dickson's film is smartly edited so that, while the Superhead plays Beatles' songs in assembly to teach a lesson about helping our friends, the viewer knows that police are on the way to deal with "one child threatening to stab another child". While Friedag lectures his new staff on the "ethos" of the school, he has forgotten to draw up the timetable and wasps infest the classrooms.

Head On The Block is a triumph for BBC2 but may also solve a problem at the neighbouring channel. The job of Controller is virtually impossible in the current environment and many have failed at it. But Torsten Friedag - his idealism apparently unbroken - is probably the only person in the country who would willingly agree to run BBC1.

webTitle: TV and radio: Harry Enfield,  10pm, Sky One

fields.headline: Dirty Harry
fields.standfirst: When Sky poached Harry Enfield from the BBC, it looked as if the broadcaster was aiming for respectability. But, says  Mark Lawson, the real purpose was to let the comedian move downmarket
fields.trailText: When Sky poached Harry Enfield from the BBC, it looked as if the broadcaster was aiming for respectability. But, says Mark Lawson, the real purpose was to let the comedian move downmarket
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's Sky TV promised - at its launch in the mid-80s - to be a new kind of television network for Britain. This turned out to be true, although viewers didn't perhaps realise the novelty would be that the network was devoid of its own ideas. The schedule consisted of attractive American acquisitions (The Simpsons, Friends, etc) and canny acts of blackmail in which viewers were forced to buy satellite dishes to see football or cricket which had previously been beamed to their aerials.

But now Sky seems finally to have developed artistic ambitions. For the first time, the company is originating expensive entertainment series. Harry Enfield's Brand Spanking New Show is the first example of a major star in the BBC and ITV galaxy agreeing to go extra-terrestrial.

This had seemed a strange decision by Enfield. At the same time he sought a larger audience than the BBC - with his first cinema release Kevin And Perry Go Large - he was prepared to accept the much smaller satellite audience. A viewing of the first two episodes, however, makes Enfield's reasoning explicit - explicit being the key word - and suggests that it is a little early for Rupert Murdoch to claim cultural respectability.

The series introduces 25 characters, and the most prominent is the Frank Pharmacist, a South African running a London pharmacy. At first the intent seems to be political - he is rude to his non-white assistant - but in fact the nationality seems only to follow from a linguistic connection between Boer-ish and boorish.

The joke is that while chemists are generally known for their discretion, this pharmacist bellows a monologue combining clinical detail with playground scatalogy. Returning with a cure for diarrhoea, a middle-class woman is quizzed on the firmness of her "turds" and "stools" after the "real bowl-splatterers" caused by her condition. A young man flirting with another customer is unmanned when the chemist returns to deafeningly check whether the herpes cream he needs is for the oral or genital sort.

The second stand-out character is a Cornish fisherman who boasts in the snug-bar about the awesome intercourse and other acts he has achieved with most of the world's famous beauties. The target here is presumably male sexual boasting but the main point of these sketches seems to be to allow Enfield to explore the vocabulary of the bedroom in the way that the dentist liberated the language of the bathroom.

These two loose-lipped creations establish that Harry Enfield's Brand Spanking New Show is not about Rupert Murdoch becoming respectable but Harry Enfield courting unrespectability. In one of the show's best jokes, he is using Sky One as a sort of comedic page three. Other comics - Mike Reid, Alan Davies, Frank Skinner - have used video or nightclubs to do this stuff. Enfield - with amusing subversiveness - is using the television channel of a man whose British newspapers often campaign against filth on TV.

But, except in vocabulary, the rest of the show confirms Enfield's talents rather than extending them. The comedian once did the voices on Spitting Image and he remains an impressionist in the sense that his characters derive from a distinct verbal delivery. The difference is that while Rory Bremner and Alastair McGowan impersonate the famous, Enfield does non-celebrity social types with occasional exceptions. The new series shows this to be a common-sense policy - his portrayal of the footballer is one of his weakest.

Because he begins with accent, Enfield's subject as a comedian is essentially class. But, in the class war, he fights on both sides.

Characters from Ascot and the dog-track, Hampstead and Hackney are "paired" like absentee MPs so that they cancel out any political message. For Loadsamoney (thick and grasping working-class), there was Tim Nice But Dim (thick and complacent upper-class). In the new series, there's a revolting rich businessman called Edward Carmichael, who, in a good example of Enfield's sharp ear, has a habit of barracking the answers of others with a chorus of "yuh, yuh, yuh" which betrays his irritation at the wait until he can dominate the conversation again. But he faces across the Commons of Enfield's imagination Short Bloke, a yob who compensates for lack of height by picking fights in pubs.

Like The Fast Show - the other mainstream comic hit of the 90s - Enfield uses an accent and a catch-phrase to create what might be called karaoke comedy: the routines are easily repeated in offices and pubs next day. He also shares with The Fast Show the favourite device of having people say in a social situation what they would generally only think.

His filthy pharmacist and lurid Cornishman are examples of this. His Paxman simply tells ministers to "fuck off". His long-term married couple making love actually read the newspapers and look at carpet samples in the middle of the act rather than their minds wandering off.

And the series itself invites this cynical simultaneous translation. The comedian may have said that his decision showed that Sky One had arrived as a network but the truth is that the Digger lets him do some filth

 Harry Enfield, tonight, 10pm, Sky One

fields.headline: Out with the old, in with the new
fields.standfirst: The Proms lose a conductor but gain a violinist:  Tim Ashley catches this year's closing performances
fields.trailText: The Proms lose a conductor but gain a violinist: Tim Ashley catches this year's closing performances
fields.body:
The flag-waving began a day earlier than expected. As Valery Gergiev and the World Orchestra for Peace brought Shostakovich's Leningrad Symphony to its shuddering close at the Proms on Friday, the colours of the Russian Federation swirled above the Promenaders' heads. The symphony - for so long the symbol of anti-fascist resistance - has now taken on the connotations of liberation from communism as well. Whether it is a pacifist work, and therefore suited to the ethos of an ensemble founded to affirm "the strength of music as an ambassador for peace" is open to question.

The brainchild of Georg Solti, the orchestra was created in 1995 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, and takes its players from 65 orchestras worldwide. However, variable quality is always the peril when you band together a group of soloists. The Leningrad Symphony was superlative in its rage, terror, grief and exultation, but Debussy's La Mer, which preceded it, had more than its fair share of problems. Some of the playing was scrappy, as if we were listening to a trial run. Gergiev doesn't have the full measure of the score: textures are hard and glacial rather than sensual. Throughout, we are closer to expressionist emoting than impressionist fluidity.

The following evening, the bacchanalia of Last Night of the Proms was offset by tinges of sadness. It marked Andrew Davis's departure from the BBC Symphony Orchestra, which he has led for 13 years, and the pain of farewell was in the air.

The first half brought the "youth and music" theme of this year's Proms to an ambivalent close. The imperious 20-year-old Hilary Hahn played the 19-year-old Mozart's Fourth Violin Concerto with a distinct lack of warmth, interpolating cadenzas that seemed to have strayed from Sibelius. Strauss's Salome, opera's 16-year-old necrophiliac, shed her orchestral veils with something less than depravity, before Jane Eaglen voiced her final scene with steely tone. Eaglen seemed happier when she had mutated into Britannia. Flinging quotes from Wagner into the melee, her voice cleaved the air with Baroque extravagance.

Shostakovich surfaced once more in the form of the strangely titled (Lost) 2nd Jazz Suite. This is not the famous effort to which Nicole Kidman stripped in Eyes Wide Shut, but a reconstruction from sketches by Gerard McBurney of a piece written in 1938 for Stalin's State Jazz Orchestra. Shostakovich re-used some of the music in his searing Eighth Symphony; hearing themes we associate with monumental despair accompanied by a bluesy walking bass was unnerving.

When it was nearly all over, Davis replaced his traditional speech with song, bursting into a variant of General Stanley's patter from HMS Pinafore - "This is the very model of a modern music festival" - including a wry dig at his successor Leonard Slatkin, whose remarks about the sartorial recklessness of female musicians have caused controversy.

The Promenaders gave him a signed score of Britten's The Rape of Lucretia, before Nicholas Kenyon arrived to present him with the manuscript sketches of Elgar's Third Symphony, the world premiere of which was one of the triumphs of Davis's career. Visibly moved, he plunged into Parry's Jerusalem, played the National Anthem and left the platform. The audience sang Auld Lang Syne - but when we meet again Slatkin will be at the helm, and things may be very different.

As Valery Gergiev and the World Orchestra for Peace brought Shostakovich's Leningrad Symphony to its shuddering close at the Proms on Friday, the colours of the Russian Federation swirled above the Promenaders' heads. Whether it is a pacifist work, and therefore suited to the ethos of an ensemble founded to affirm "the strength of music as an ambassador for peace" is open to question. webTitle: Arts: The strange world of alt. country outfit, the Handsome Family

fields.headline: He's eaten cat food. She used to think God was a helicopter
fields.standfirst: Ian Aitch  enters the strange world of the Handsome Family, alt.country's finest
fields.trailText: Ian Aitch enters the strange world of the Handsome Family, alt.country's finest
fields.body:
The Handsome Family are at the forefront of a distinctly urban new wave of country music, known as alt.country or insurgent country, that has grown up in the bars of Chicago. But hear a few songs by this husband-and-wife team, and you imagine them hunting squirrels in the backwoods. Their recent CD, In the Air, is so brimming with nature that you feel it should have been recorded on a chunk of mighty redwood, rather than on the brittle plastic of a compact disc. Dogs leap, birds sing, cicadas hiss and many things die.

"I'm kind of obsessed with the two sides of nature," says lyricist Rennie Sparks. "The beautiful, tranquil side of it, like, 'Oh, look at that cute little kitten.' And the really horrible, dangerous and bloodthirsty side of it, like, 'Boy, that alligator ate that zebra in one bite!' I watch a lot of nature shows on TV where it's just all one big bloodbath."

Rennie and husband Brett, who writes the music and sings most of the songs, are perhaps a little too morbid for mainstream American tastes. They have often been referred to as the Manson family or the Addams family by less kind reviewers who fail to see the beauty in Rennie's macabre lyrics.

Their previous CD, Through the Trees (1998), was the darkest recording to come out of the US this side of death metal. It opened with a track featuring the downbeat chorus: "This is why people OD on pills and jump from the Golden Gate Bridge" and closed with the true story of Brett's stay in a mental hospital, with him strapped to a bed quoting Nietzsche. In 1995, during the recording of their second CD, Milk and Scissors, Brett's manic depression had taken such a hold that Rennie was forced to check him in to the hospital for his own protection. He was spending wildly, drinking heavily and had taken to eating cat food.

"I was delusional," he says. "Incapable of getting anything done. I really thought I was the Messiah. I was writing my own bible and starting fires in the apartment. I was a fucking lunatic. I would go two weeks at a time without sleeping, I was down to about 145lb. So I went to the nut-house for a few weeks. They put me on lithium, among other things. Long-term lithium, which I am still taking to this day." Rennie has also had her own share of problems with depression and thoughts of suicide and, like Brett, is still taking the pills. Religion seems to loom large over the work of the Handsome Family. Brett was brought up a southern Baptist, and it was in church that he learned about music and how to sing in such a delightfully doomy baritone. He has also been influenced by the Louvin Brothers, a 50s Christian country act whose cautionary tales were every bit as dark as the Handsome Family's.

Rennie was brought up a Jew in New York but has also dabbled with some less than orthodox spiritual beliefs, as revelealed in the lyrics for When That Helicopter Comes - the story of the second coming, with helicopters taking the place of Jesus. "I've always been obsessed with helicopters," she says. "When I was little I thought God was a helicopter. I had all these feelings that after I died I would turn into a helicopter."

It is surprising to learn that lurking behind the rolling hills and falling trees of In the Air is the latest in technology. The couple may have recorded the album in their living room, but it was all done on a Macintosh G3 computer - hardly a traditional piece of country kit. But then, neither was the drum machine that regimented their previous album and was intended to alienate traditionalists in the alt.country scene. "It was completely out of spite," says Brett. "Musically it did work, but I thought that people would be really critical of it. But that record was on every critic's top 10 list in the US last year. It surprised the hell out of me."

Oddly, Chicago's country revival was largely kick-started by two ex-pat members of Leeds art-punks the Mekons, who now live in the city. Jon Langford seems to be at the centre of any drunken guitar-led stomp worthy of mention with his various bands, such as the Waco Brothers, who evoke the spirit of Johnny Cash before he was born again.

The morality tales of Rennie's lyrics are not lost on Brett, who at least seems to have learned to go a little steady on the drink. "My classic joke is that if I get drunk and act like an asshole, then Rennie's going to write a song about it and I'm going to have to sing it over and over," he says. "My punishment is having her pull my spiritual trousers down every night."

 The Handsome Family play the Charlotte, Leicester (0116-255 3956), tonight; Maguires, Leeds (0113-245 5630), tomorrow; the Louisana, Bristol (0117-926 5978), on Wednesday, then tour.

fields.headline: Carrying the can
fields.standfirst:
Some rules for resignations are required

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The responsibility of ministers for what is done in their name by civil servants, officials and quango executives is a constitutional black hole. The pursuit of Lord Falconer over the Millennium Dome and Sam Galbraith over Scottish exam results have this in common - nobody has a clear idea of the standard against which their alleged failings are being measured. And that lack of doctrine is itself remarkable. Whitehall's executive agencies were meant to clarify the boundaries between politicians and operatives. But it did not happen under the Conservatives and with Tony Blair, it has been business as usual - confusion.
fields.body:
The responsibility of ministers for what is done in their name by civil servants, officials and quango executives is a constitutional black hole. The pursuit of Lord Falconer over the Millennium Dome and Sam Galbraith over Scottish exam results have this in common - nobody has a clear idea of the standard against which their alleged failings are being measured. And that lack of doctrine is itself remarkable. Whitehall's executive agencies were meant to clarify the boundaries between politicians and operatives. But it did not happen under the Conservatives and with Tony Blair, it has been business as usual - confusion.

Old salts, noting precedents going back at least as far the Crichel Down affair in the 50s (when a Tory minister resigned to expiate the sins of his civil servants), say it is naive to seek rational or objective measures of ministers' performance. It is all a matter of political weights and circumstances. A strong prime minister, his backbenches secure, can offer a beleaguered minister unconditional support (Blair to Falconer: hang on). A weaker premier will have to accept sacrifices, regardless of the merits of the case (why John Major failed to egg Mrs Currie on).

But there must be more to assessing ministers than realpolitik. The Commons' resolution passed thanks to the work of Giles Radice's committee in the mid-90s suggests a minister has to go if he or she has been shown to be deceitful. This is a rehash of the Profumo doctrine - forgive the sin but not lying about it to colleagues. Applying it to Sam Galbraith, he would have to go if it were shown he was told about problems at the Scottish Qualifications Authority and wilfully misled either the Scottish parliament or his executive colleagues. It is hard to see how Lord Falconer has betrayed confidence. He knew as much about the dome's deficits as Chris Smith and other ministers. Personally, he deceived no one, however much we were all deceived.

webTitle: Arts: Architecture: The Autonomous Environmental Information Centre

fields.headline: Earth works
fields.standfirst: It's one thing to build with mud in the heat of Africa - but wet old Wales?  Jonathan Glancey investigates
fields.trailText: It's one thing to build with mud in the heat of Africa - but wet old Wales? Jonathan Glancey investigates
fields.body:
The Autonomous Environmental Information Centre is a bit of a mouthful; it is also one of the greenest buildings in Britain. In plain English this is the shop and information office of the Centre for Alternative Technology (Cat), north Wales, which has just celebrated its 25th birthday.

This building, designed by the Shropshire-based architects Pat Borer and David Lea, is special - it is one of the first modern public buildings in Britain to make use of rammed-earth construction. This technique involves slabs of mud, 5-6ins deep, being rammed into a tall mould of wooden shuttering; when they are compressed down to a depth of about 2ins, they form a stable construction that can be used in place of brick, concrete or cement-block walls.

The result is beautiful: columns of rich brown earth that you want to run your hands over. In fact, so many people have been rubbing their hands over them, even before the building's official opening, that Borer has had to place glass panels in front of them. Fortunately, this adds to their lustre and character.

"We could render the columns," says Borer, who has worked for Cat pretty much since its founding, "but this would mean losing their character." It is rather wonderful to see the roof of a new building supported by mud. It is, in fact, a strong material, but, sadly, given the wet climate of north Wales, the columns must be protected from the elements by glass-and-timber walls. "They would disintegrate in the rain," Borer points out - which is why mud buildings are rare in damp old Britain, but common in north Africa.

These rammed-earth columns offer us not just a pleasant sight, but a building material that uses substantially less energy to make than their concrete equivalent. "The carbon dioxide emissions of the concrete industry are very high," says Borer. "Cat aims to show how we can build using as little energy as possible."

The question often asked about low-energy architecture is whether it has to be worthy, shaggy and, well, primitive? The answer, judging by the new building at Cat, is a qualified no. Yes, it is a bit shaggy, but then this is in keeping with the spirit of Cat, and, by the way, no insult. Perched high on an ancient slate hillside between Dolgellau and Machynlleth, Cat has integrity and intelligence. The new building sits by the entrance to the centre, which is accessed by a water-powered funicular that travels up from a car park to a kind of Welsh version of a Japanese temple. Like Clough William-Ellis's fantasy village Portmeirion a few miles away on Tremadog Bay, this is a magical place. The buildings are low-key, yet each is a delight. Apart from the new information centre, there's an earth toilet, a solar-powered telephone kiosk, an underground gallery aimed at showing how creepy-crawlies live and a remarkably grand theatre designed and built by Borer and Co last year for £23,000 (put that in your Dome and count the cost).

These are linked by muddy paths criss-crossed by dragonflies and birds. Between the buildings, there are examples of low-energy machines, which you can try out for yourself. There are also utterly uncondescending exhibits of building materials and ways of heating water and flushing (or not flushing) toilets. In fact, the place is filled with information about how to design and build in ways that make you want to set fire to every crass new executive housing estate - except that would cause pollution.

The roof of Borer's latest building is also fitted with solar panels. The energy produced not only heats the information centre itself, but can also produce a surplus. "The roof can generate 50kW at any one time," says Borer. "That's enough to light up the bars of 50 electric fires. When the building itself doesn't need the energy, the hot water can be pumped to other buildings around the Cat site."

Can the rest of us learn new (or very old) tricks from Cat? Yes. The new bookshop and information centre may not be to everyone's taste. But there are things we can think about: wool insulation instead of weird artificial fibrous gunk; limewash rendering for houses (it "breathes", and so doesn't crack like concrete). You could install solar heating. In fact you could do so many things, but in the hurly- burly of our modern lives, it is hard to get round to any of these good, green things.

So we must rely on organisations such as Cat to keep working away for the rest of us, to encourage the building industry to be more responsive to ecological concerns. It has been happening, slowly; ironically, some of the greatest strides in ecologically sensitive architecture have been made by architects celebrated for their use of the very latest technology, such as Renzo Piano and Norman Foster. Somehow we need to meet in the middle, between the latest green(ish) skyscrapers and Borer's low-energy buildings; between muddy paths and our desire to walk through this life sanitised and squeaky clean.

 The Centre for Alternative Technology is at Machynlleth, Powys. Details: 01654 311329.

fields.headline: The age of dissent
fields.standfirst: Rewarding rubbish
fields.trailText: Rewarding rubbish
fields.body:
Bad news for Olga. She has just learned that the frightful fellow who two/three-timed her a year ago, years after he had two/three-timed his wife and forsaken his children, has now been made a sir. She is sickened by this and longs for the good old days when members of the judiciary (and sadly he is one) were obliged to have a lovely clean private life, especially, one hopes, if they were to be knighted.

Now any old toad can be knighted for the oddest of reasons. Just look at the ghastly crop of lords that has erupted of late. For starters we have lords Foster, Branson and Lloyd-Webber, exalted for making mistakes, being a megalomaniac and writing wimbly-wambly non-tunes respectively. All have had a humility bypass.

You can't even cast these fellows to the back of your mind. They will insist on sticking their marks everywhere: the geodesic dildo, the wrong colour marble, the hot air balloons, the trains that don't work, the chain of shops that don't make a profit. And pity the poor Germans. In the Ruhr valley a whole theatre has been devoted not to Schiller, Brecht or Goethe, but solely to the works of Lloyd-Webber.

Meanwhile, a Nazi and a child abductor are both about to be canonised by the Pope, and yesterday morning Rosemary was thrown into a temper because she heard three show-off men spouting on the radio: "Sounding forth, interrupting and scoring points. Mandelson, then Heseltine, and even David Owen has been dragged out of the woodwork." The petulant squabbling has started already and parliament isn't even open for weeks.

Sometimes, it helps to understand a phenomenon, then you don't get so cross about it. So Rosemary is studying Lord Jeffrey Archer's biography for enlightenment. It was no help. She found his life compulsively odious - there was nothing to redeem him at all. No wonder Rosemary has lost what faith she had. The rich, ruthless and rubbishy seem to be inheriting the earth.

But there's no point dwelling on these things, so for a diversion I went to meet a chum for coffee at Euston Station. His train was 50 minutes late. Guess what sort of train it was. Got it in one. Virgin.

Sometimes, it helps to understand a phenomenon, then you don't get so cross about it. So Rosemary is studying Lord Jeffrey Archer's biography for enlightenment. It was no help. She found his life compulsively odious - there was nothing to redeem him at all. No wonder Rosemary has lost what faith she had. The rich, ruthless and rubbishy seem to be inheriting the earth. But there's no point dwelling on these things, so for a diversion I went to meet a chum for coffee at Euston Station. His train was 50 minutes late. Guess what sort of train it was. Got it in one. Virgin.

fields.headline: Neither in nor out
fields.standfirst:
Britain is in a muddle over Sierra Leone

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The freeing of seven hostages, six of them British soldiers, held in Sierra Leone is a welcome development from a humanitarian point of view. These men appear to have undergone a horrific ordeal since being captured last month, including being terrorised by mock executions. The government's judgment that negotiations for the prisoners' release were going nowhere and that they were at "extreme risk" must be accepted at face value. But the cost at which their freedom has been secured is but one of many questions which come to the fore in the wake of yesterday's bloody battle in the Occra Hills, east of Freetown. About 25 members of the West Side Boys militia were reportedly killed. But one British soldier also died, with 12 others injured, and although the militia's commander was among those captured, it cannot be assumed that this is the last that will be heard of the group. Britain now potentially faces the prospect of an ongoing blood feud - and of an unplanned, possibly deepening involvement.
fields.body:
The freeing of seven hostages, six of them British soldiers, held in Sierra Leone is a welcome development from a humanitarian point of view. These men appear to have undergone a horrific ordeal since being captured last month, including being terrorised by mock executions. The government's judgment that negotiations for the prisoners' release were going nowhere and that they were at "extreme risk" must be accepted at face value. But the cost at which their freedom has been secured is but one of many questions which come to the fore in the wake of yesterday's bloody battle in the Occra Hills, east of Freetown. About 25 members of the West Side Boys militia were reportedly killed. But one British soldier also died, with 12 others injured, and although the militia's commander was among those captured, it cannot be assumed that this is the last that will be heard of the group. Britain now potentially faces the prospect of an ongoing blood feud - and of an unplanned, possibly deepening involvement.

Other immediate questions include how highly trained, well-equipped and armed members of the Royal Irish Regiment managed to get themselves into such a predicament in the first place; why they had apparently wandered so far off the beaten track; and exactly what their orders and objectives were. Since plunging into Sierra Leone last May and pulling back the following month (over-hastily, as we argued at the time), the government has given repeated assurances that remaining British personnel are tasked only with helping to train a more competent government army. But this incident suggests, not for the first time, that British troops are in fact being asked to do much more. That suspicion, if well-founded, prompts more questions. Why have parliament and public not been kept more fully informed? And should more troops be deployed, if only to prevent such episodes being repeated?

The broader issues linked to Britain's Sierra Leone involvement are if anything more murky still. There is no peace process in place. The RUF rebels remain undefeated. The UN force, despite reinforcements, makes only minor advances. It is riven by command disputes and corruption claims centring on the Nigerian contingent. Since Britain stepped back last summer, the overall situation has shown signs of stagnation and worse. Yet Britain's present choice is unchanged: do the job properly - or get out.

webTitle: Law and order arrives on the electronic frontier

fields.headline: Law and order arrives on the electronic frontier
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: When regulators come knocking on your door you had better be ready. Last week we received a letter from the financial services authority. This is the body responsible for supervising banking and deposit taking activity and therefore has an interest in "payment gateways" such as us.
fields.body:
When regulators come knocking on your door you had better be ready. Last week we received a letter from the financial services authority. This is the body responsible for supervising banking and deposit taking activity and therefore has an interest in "payment gateways" such as us.

A letter from a regulatory body is enough to cause a few butterflies but we were confident of our position. We know we are operating in a complex legal environment. Regulations within the financial services sector tend to be tighter and more numerous than elsewhere and the service that we provide needs to comply with the Banking Acts and legislation on money laundering.

We have spent a tidy sum on lawyers who are experts in financial services. It is the third biggest area of expenditure for us to date, after systems and staff. What our learned friends turned up changed the nature of our business.

We could have offered credit ourselves; but on our lawyers' advice we will be operating the payments gateway in partnership with a number of licensed deposit takers - that is, banks.

If this had not been a legal requirement we would have been technically capable of launching the service months ago (although we do have other, strategic reasons for partnering with banks). As it is, integration with banks means that the solution takes longer to develop, not just because banks tend to be slow-moving. On the upside, the added complexity is likely to provide us with some protection from new entrants in what is rapidly becoming a highly competitive online payments environment.

It is not clear that all new online businesses are receiving the same quality of legal advice. The internet is still a relatively new phenomenon and it has given many professionals the opportunity to position themselves as experts in the field without the requisite amount of experience. As the saying goes, you don't know what you don't know.

We came across many of these supposed experts when we were searching for lawyers - some whose actual expertise stretched only to drawing up terms and conditions for a straightforward e-commerce site.

Our recent conversations with the FSA have confirmed that even some of the players in the complex and sensitive field of electronic payments have not necessarily been receiving proper legal advice.

This deficiency could prove costly for investors and business partners, particularly as regulators start to focus more keenly on this area.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of rools.com a new service that enables teenagers to shop online

fields.headline: No: 1717
fields.standfirst: Charles Saatchi
fields.trailText: Charles Saatchi
fields.body:
Not to be confused with:
Maurice Saatchi, Charles's younger brother; the Liam to his Noel.

He's an advertising mogul?
Yes, you buffoon, of course he's an advertising mogul. As everyone knows. But he's now better known for his art collection.

He buys pictures?
Not just pictures. He recently paid £15,000 for Tracey Emin's soiled bed.

Doesn't he give something back too?
Oh yes. In 1998 Saatchi auctioned works by, among others, Damien Hirst, Chris Ofili and Sarah Lucas, raising £1.6m for young artists' bursaries. Last year he donated 100 works to the Arts Council, at a cost of £600,000...

Wait! Don't tell me! This year he's pickled himself in formaldehyde as a selfless contribution to the art world, nay, society at large?
No.This year he has given 39 pieces, including work by Marcus Taylor, Richard Woods and Katherine Dowson, to nine of the British museums that have suffered most under spending cuts. Their worth is conservatively estimated to be around about the £200,000 mark.

A modern Medici?
Modern being the operative word. It was Charles who described art history as "Pollock-Warhol-Hirst". He is, arguably, the pioneer of Young British Art, buying in bulk and showing off his acquisitions in the Saatchi Gallery.

Bit of an exhibitionist?
As well as being the creator of neurotic realism, Saatchi was responsible for the Sensation exhibition at the Royal Academy, famous for Myra Hindley, elephant dung, and upsetting the Mayor of New York. And now he's giving us Ant Noises...

He's a Dr Dolittle too?
No, Ant Noises is simply an anagram of "Sensation".

You mean it's just the same old stuff, but shown in a different order?
The thought never entered my head.

But is it art?
Oh shut up.

Do say:
Art patron.

Don't say:
Ant art pro.

fields.headline: Zarak buy fuels Spirent's ambitions
fields.standfirst: US capture gives telecoms tester the edge in voice over networks
fields.trailText: Spirent Communications, the telecoms testing company which will join the FTSE 100 later this month, will buy Californian Zarak Systems for £284m to gain expertise in networks that can handle voice and data communications.
fields.body:
Spirent Communications, the telecoms testing company which will join the FTSE 100 later this month, will buy Californian Zarak Systems for £284m to gain expertise in networks that can handle voice and data communications.

Zarak's big selling point is its knowledge of the lucrative "voice over internet protocol" market. Its well regarded Abacus product allows companies to mix voice, fax, and modem data calls over a variety of lines to test how well they cope.

Spirent will purchase Zarak Systems for 44.7m of its own shares. At the Spirent share price of £6.36 at the close of business on Friday, this values the company at £284m.

Nicholas Brookes, chief executive of Spirent, said: "The acquisition marks the next step in Spirent's development. As voice over IP has become a critical issue in the network, Zarak strongly reinforces Spirent's position at the leading edge of this technology."

This will be Spirent's second biggest acquisition and is the latest development in its rapid growth in advanced communications testing.

Mr Brookes added that it was another "major capture" for the company which allows them to be the first to the market with an integrated product which tests voice and data.

Mr Brookes said that the acquisition would be earnings enhancing from the outset.

Iain Milnes, Zarak's president, said: "Spirent will provide us with the resources to develop further our fast growing business and complementary technologies to help develop an exciting new generation of voice-based testing systems."

Zarak has seen its operating profit rise over the year, from $7.5m for the year ended December 1998, to $12.5m in 1999.

Spirent, a market leader in a highly fragmented market, is rapidly growing and consolidating. Last year the company boosted its testing business by acquiring America's Netcom Systems for $463.6m. The company also bought DLS Testworks for about $26.2m.

Other acquisitions over the last five years include Telecom Analysis Systems for $30.2m and Global Simulation Systems for £14m.

Strong interim figures last week and hints of an acquisition and promotion to the FTSE 100 sent Spirent's shares to an all time high of 679p on Friday, before they eased back to close at 636p. Spirent's share price closed at the end of this week up 15% on the week before.

Spirent Communications has joined the FTSE 100 with Baltimore Technologies and Dimension Data, adding to the growing number of technology companies to be listed.

The company, formerly called Bowthorpe and established in 1936, states that it is a global business with a focus on high growth, high margin and hi-tech activities.

Spirent increased turnover by 264% to £114m and operating profit by 226% to £39m in the six months to June 30 2000, compared to the same period in 1999.

Organic growth was 80% in both and new product expenditure increased by £3.6m to £13.5m.

Spirent has said that it expects testing equipment to provide an increasing share of its earnings, as telecommunications networks expand to cope with the growth of the internet.

Zarak and Spirent Communications share a common customer base, including Lucent Technologies, Cisco Systems and AT&T.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sport4cast in £10m punt
fields.body:
Sport4cast in £10m punt

Sport4cast, an online horseracing tipster, is to bet its future on the stock market by floating next month at a value of £10m.

The sports analysis and results forecasting service wants to use cash raised to expand into overseas markets. Chairman Sir Rodney Walker said there was nothing to stop the firm becoming the market leader.

Sport4cast said it held a competitive lead after setting up alliances including with the British horseracing board and Littlewoods.

White sauce for Posthouse

Celebrity chef Marco Pierre White is to work with Posthouse hotels on branded brasseries at selected hotels. Posthouse, with 80 hotels in Britain, said the first site would be in Hampstead, London. Posthouse said the 100-seater "MPW Brasserie" would then be introduced to other Posthouse hotels, starting at Heathrow.

Boots up by 1,000 degrees

High street chemist Boots said yesterday it had recruited 1,000 graduates over the summer to support its expansion into the health and beauty market. The group is rolling out dentistry and chiropody practices, as well as physiotherapy, osteopathy and massage services.

webTitle: Staff fear axe as DLJ chief cashes in

fields.headline: Staff fear axe as DLJ chief cashes in
fields.trailText: Hundreds of people working for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in Britain will be told whether they still have a job over the next few days following the US investment bank's takeover by Credit Suisse.
fields.body:
Hundreds of people working for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in Britain will be told whether they still have a job over the next few days following the US investment bank's takeover by Credit Suisse.

Department heads face the task of wielding the axe as details emerge of the bonuses being paid to the bank's most senior executives. Joe Roby, DLJ's chief executive, is to be paid a one-off retention award of $18m in shares once the $11.5bn acquisition is completed later this year as well as a guaranteed bonus and salary adding up to almost $50m over the next three years.

Mr Roby, who earned $20.7m last year, is to become chairman of the combined group's investment banking business. The 60-year-old's package, filed as part of the merger agreement to the securities and exchange commission, also includes a continued "consulting fee" for three years after he leaves the company.

Credit Suisse has set aside an additional $1.2bn to retain the staff it wants to keep. The group has already said that there will be few redundancies in the corporate finance and fixed income departments out of a total of more than 2,000 job cuts in the US and Europe.

Support staff are expected to bear the brunt of the cuts, followed by equity research analysts and traders in New York and London.

Where there is no clear difference between two sector analysts at CSFB and DLJ, senior executives have admitted that the job would most likely go to the acquiring bank's staff.

Hector Sants, who has built DLJ's international equity operation from scratch over the past two years, oversees more than 200 professionals in London. His counterpart at CSFB manages more than 500 people.

CSFB's ambitions to enter the global super league of companies in the bulge bracket -firms which have cashed in on mergers and acquisitions by acting for both parties involved - are likely to mean that some effort will be expended in trying to keep highly rated members of staff at DLJ, including Mr Sants.

European executives are understood to want to adopt an "orderly" approach to the lay-offs, citing employment legislation for a relatively "softly, softly" approach.

A bigger challenge may be trying to retain the bankers who relished DLJ's boutique-style of operation. Insiders say that many of the close-knit teams working in the City for DLJ are not happy about the prospect of moving to the larger firm, which is based in Canary Wharf.

No decision has yet been taken on what will happen to DLJ's headquarters, however.

The most senior investment banking jobs have already been announced.

Hamilton James, a senior banker at DLJ, will become co-head of global investment banking at the combined firm, for which he will be granted a retention award of $13.3m in Credit Suisse shares.

fields.headline: Stark message
fields.standfirst: Protesters to disrupt forum
fields.trailText: Police in Melbourne turned the city centre Crown casino and hotel complex into a virtual fortress yesterday ahead of the three-day Asia-Pacific economic summit, which starts today and is expected to be disrupted by protesters.
fields.body:
Police in Melbourne turned the city centre Crown casino and hotel complex into a virtual fortress yesterday ahead of the three-day Asia-Pacific economic summit, which starts today and is expected to be disrupted by protesters.

In nearby Treasury Gardens 1,000 protesters held an rally. Business executives and government leaders, including Microsoft's Bill Gates, are due to attend the summit to discuss future economic developments in Asia. Kristen Bartram, who runs a Melbourne computer consultancy, plans to join today's protest. "Corporations don't seem to take into consideration what they are doing to the planet," she said.

Dozens of groups, including pupils at an exclusive girls' college, homosexuals claiming they are exploited by corporate greed and environmentalist lawmakers, plan to march under the S11 banner - the name taken from today's date. Senator Bob Brown of the Australian Green Party said the Greens were opposed to the growth of a new aristocracy among multinational corporate bodies who were "becoming a de facto, undemocratic world government".

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

The former boss of media services group Wace and some members of his family committed insider dealing on a huge scale, according to a report by the Department of Trade and Industry. The report found that John Clegg , Wace's former chief executive, his father and his uncle were guilty of flagrant breaches of company law and stock exchange rules from 1984 to 1992.

Dixons has held informal talks exploring options to link Freeserve , its internet subsidiary, with World Online , the Dutch company which last week announced a £3.4bn merger with Italian rival Tiscali . The report does not cite sources.

Sunday Business

Vodafone is close to selling Infostrada, the Italian fixed-line telephone operator, for £7bn-£8bn to Wind , a consortium backed by Milan-based electricity group Enel and France Télécom .

Allied Domecq is thought to be contemplating a £1bn bid for Southcorp , the Australian wine producer and owner of labels such as Lindemans and Penfolds, should it fail in its attempt to buy the wine and spirits business of Seagram . The report cites sources familiar with the situation.

Sunday Times

Two of America's biggest oil groups are understood to be close to concluding a £55bn merger. Executives say that Chevron and Phillips should decide on the merits of a full merger by the end of the year.

Computer and printing equipment manufacturer Hewlett Packard is in talks with PricewaterhouseCoopers , the accountancy firm, to buy its global management consulting business in a deal worth £14 bn.

Sunday Telegraph

Thomas Cook is about to be bought by German travel business C&N Touristic in a deal worth more than £700m. Talks between C&N and Thomas Cook shareholders, led by Carlson, the US-based leisure group, are said to be progressing well.

Land Securities is proceeding with a £370m redevelopment scheme in the heart of the City following the agreement by the City of London Corporation to quit space it occupies in Gresham Street.

fields.headline: First Quench in £225m sale
fields.standfirst: Japanese bank Nomura toasts success after buying up Britain's largest chain of off-licences
fields.trailText: Nomura, Britain's biggest pub landlord, celebrated further success in the drinks business yesterday when it agreed to buy the country's largest off-licence chain for £225m.
fields.body:
Nomura, Britain's biggest pub landlord, celebrated further success in the drinks business yesterday when it agreed to buy the country's largest off-licence chain for £225m.

Thresher, Victoria Wine, Wine Rack and Bottoms Up are to be added to an already varied Nomura investment portfolio after the Japanese bank agreed to buy the First Quench group from Punch Taverns and Whitbread.

Guy Hands, head of Nomura's Principal Finance Group (PFG), controls 4,800 tenanted pubs in Britain and is negotiating to buy the Millennium Dome. More than 2,600 liquor stores will be added to the mix by late October, assuming the deal is given regulatory clearance.

"Based on our track record with similar consumer-facing businesses, we believe that First Quench's full potential can be realised by empowering the management and investing in staff and technology," Mr Hands said.

The off-licence chain had sales of aboput £1.3bn last year and made an operating profit of £15m.

Punch Taverns, run by entrepreneur Hugh Osmond, and Whitbread decided that First Quench was not core to their future plans.

Mr Osmond said he would be using part of his share of the proceeds to pay off debt and the remainder will be invested in the development of Punch's pub estate. He plans to expand its Q sports bars chain, as well as its Great Local neighbourhood pub operation.

Punch acquired its 50% holding in First Quench last year when it beat Whitbread to buy Allied Domecq pub estate.

Whitbread operates pubs, restaurants, hotels and health clubs. It is narrowing its interest away from drinks and this year sold its brewing operations to Interbrew, the Belgian owner of Stella Artois. Whitbread plans to invest in its well known brands which include Marriott Hotels, Cafe Rouge and David Lloyd Leisure.

Nomura is reported to have beaten off a rival bid from PPM Ventures, Prudential's private equity arm, to clinch First Quench. A management buy-out attempt also failed.

Mr Hands' team will have to work hard against growing competition from supermarkets for off-licence sales. Under his guidance the London arm of Nomura has become one of the City's biggest players.

The 40-year-old is a close friend of William Hague and has bought 57,000 Ministry of Defence properties, thousands of pubs and a slice of the privatised railways. Last month he narrowly missed out on Welsh water company Hyder and admitted taking a look at BAe Systems, the country's second largest defence contractor. Nomura has also owned bookmaker William Hill.

"We seek out large businesses others do not find attractive," he explained earlier this year. "They normally appear to lack growth potential even though their cash flow is stable. They are neglected and undervalued by the market".

Mr Hands is understood to be paid in line with PFG's annual profits and has taken home as much as £40m in one year.

webTitle: Comment: Britain's foreign policy is too interventionist

fields.headline: Too many fine sentiments
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: A personal view
Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: If people want moral uplift, Harold Macmillan used to say, they should look to their bishops. But our own pious prime minister in New York last week, as he privately approved the Sierra Leone hostage rescue assault plan, was publicly propounding morality as a basis for policy: it is the west's duty to combat "bad governance" in Africa.
fields.body:
If people want moral uplift, Harold Macmillan used to say, they should look to their bishops. But our own pious prime minister in New York last week, as he privately approved the Sierra Leone hostage rescue assault plan, was publicly propounding morality as a basis for policy: it is the west's duty to combat "bad governance" in Africa.

He might have stopped to reflect that politicians who claim the moral high ground usually get what they deserve. His government has been here before, living to regret the phrase "ethical foreign policy".

A party document on foreign policy to be launched at conference no longer makes Robin Cook's boast that Labour would "make Britain once again a force for good in the world". Since the election, Mr Cook has learned about the difficulties of a country which is a large arms manufacturer claiming to act as a force for good. In opposition, Labour made humanitarian noises about the wickedness of selling arms to repressive regimes. In office, the problem was again discovered about what happens when moralism comes up against the word "jobs".

The new document promises "a more responsible arms trade", but this is humbug. One might as well speak of a more responsible slave trade. There are really only two honest arms policies. One could be called the Alan Clark principle - to sell murderous weapons to all comers who can pay ready cash, and then let whichever savage despots have bought them use them to kill their subject peoples, young conscripts in their neighbours' armies, or British soldiers as the case might be.

The other is not to engage in this disgusting trade at all. The argument that "if we don't sell them, someone else will" could be just as well used by a drug-pusher. And Labour MPs who mutter about the jobs of constituents making armoured vehicles should be asked whether they would take the same line with factories making poison gas.

There are also two honest approaches to broader foreign policy, both well understood in the 19th century. One is "political realism". Instead of using exalted language, Palmerston merely said that England had no permanent friends and no permanent enemies, only permanent interests. And Bismarck said that the great issues of the day would not be decided by resolutions and majority votes but by blood and iron.

What they disliked was dressing up the use of force in sentimental terms. The Crimean war was meant to be "ethical", but Aberdeen, who was prime minister when the war began, bitterly regretted it, and felt tainted by it ever after. He would have been appalled by a British government which preached ethics while selling arms to Indonesia and sending aircraft to the Balkans to kill women and children in a country with which we were not at war.

That intervention was meant to be an ethical policy, just as the original American intervention in Vietnam was. When he became president, Kennedy had famously promised to "pay any price, bear any burden, meet any hardship, support any friend, oppose any foe, to assure the survival and the success of liberty". He thought he was doing that in Indo-China, as Mr Clinton and Mr Blair thought they were in the Balkans, and perhaps Sierra Leone, with dubious results.

As to the other honest policy, there is, or was, a long tradition in this country of principled non-interventionism. It was at one time called Cobdenism after Richard Cobden who, with his great ally John Bright, opposed military interference. Like those who opposed the "ethical" bombing of Serbia or Iraq, they were accused of a lack of sympathy for the victims of oppression. That was answered by Bright: "I have sympathy with Turkey, I have sympathy with the serfs of Russia; I have sympathy with the people of Hungary" - or, one could now say, with the peoples of Kosovo, Iraq, or Sierra Leone.

"But it is not on any question of sympathy that I dare involve this country, or any country, in a war which must cost an incalculable amount of treasure and of blood. It is not my duty to make this country the knight-errant of the human race."

Too many of the western leaders who met in New York did see themselves as knight-errants, Tony Blair notably among them. If he really wants to set an example against bad governance, there are other ways.

Try instead another noble sentence of Cobden's: "The progress of freedom depends more upon the maintenance of peace, the spread of commerce, and the diffusion of education, than upon the labours of cabinets and foreign offices." Mightn't that be the basis for a truly ethical foreign policy?

webTitle: A corner of Russia that is forever Germany

fields.headline: A corner of Russia that is forever Germany
fields.trailText: On a patch of gravel in a northern Russian meadow, a world away from her prosperous Bavarian home, Gertrud Kaes eyed a row of granite slabs engraved with thousands of names and anxiously worked her way along the Ks.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Sologubovka, northern Russia
fields.body:
On a patch of gravel in a northern Russian meadow, a world away from her prosperous Bavarian home, Gertrud Kaes eyed a row of granite slabs engraved with thousands of names and anxiously worked her way along the Ks.

"He must be here somewhere," she sighed. Clutching a dahlia in one hand, the German housewife's fingers traced the list of names in search of two words - Adolf Kroepl.

The Wehrmacht corporal - Mrs Kaes's uncle - died here, south of Leningrad, in 1942 - a year into the Nazis' 900-day siege of the city. He "passed away gently and peacefully", said the death notice the family received a year later.

That was the last they heard until this year when they learned that the remains of Corporal Kroepl were being exhumed and reburied in a corner of a foreign field that may now be forever Germany.

The Sologubovka cemetery, holding 22,000 German dead from the second world war and due to take 80,000, was opened at a ceremony on Saturday, providing a final resting place for Corporal Kroepl and thousands like him more than half a century after they died.

Forty-five miles south-east of St Petersburg on 12 acres on the fringes of the village, Sologubovka is the biggest German war cemetery anywhere, including Germany itself.

Its opening marked the climax to a German quest to locate and rebury the fallen soldiers of the Third Reich all across Russia and eastern Europe in the nine years since the collapse of communism.

"We've got projects like this in Poland, in the Baltic states, in the Czech republic, in Slovakia, in Hungary. All over the former Warsaw Pact in the countries where we couldn't work until 1990," said Fritz Kirchmeier of the People's Union for Care of War Graves based in Kassel, which is the German equivalent of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission.

German researchers have been working systematically across the former communist bloc throughout the 1990s. An estimated 4m German military died between Berlin and Moscow in the war, just over half in what was the Soviet Union. Almost all the German war dead lay neglected for the duration of the cold war, the sites virtually unknown.

So far 250,000 German war dead have been exhumed from unmarked graves and reburied. A German war cemetery was opened in the Polish port of Gdansk a couple of weeks ago, yet another in the Slovak capital, Bratislava, in July.

They are among scores of such projects in a race against time to locate the dead. "The relatives of the dead are getting very old and the eye witnesses who can tell us where the corpses were buried are also very old, so we have to speed up our work. We reckon we've got another five years," says Mr Kirchmeier.

Four teams of six are working in the St Petersburg area alone using Wehrmacht documents and witness testimony to trace the dead. When located, the corpses frequently have ID tags or other means of identification. The remains are reburied in Sologubovka.

The entire cemetery project - including a new tarmac road paid for by the Germans who are also funding the renovation of the village church - has cost more than £1m.

"We Russians are affectionate people, it's good to see these Germans here. They're different from the Nazis," said Lida Titarenko, 67, a local woman who was enslaved by the German forces who occupied Sologubovka in 1941.

"The Germans destroyed this place. Now they're rebuilding it. That's good," she said without bitterness.

But while the Sologubovka villagers welcomed the Germans, digging up the past has also generated resentment, and opposition across the region.

Russian war veterans largely boycotted Saturday's ceremony. "We can't agree to this," said Zoya Kornilyeva, deputy head of the St Petersburg second world war veterans' committee. "The Germans are always preaching reconciliation, but we're not prepared for that. They go around paying big money and unfortunately our people fall for that."

webTitle: Crunch time comes for Burger King's stealth fries

fields.headline: Crunch time comes for Burger King's stealth fries
fields.trailText: Burger King is set for an embarrassing climbdown in the run-up to its £2bn flotation by dropping its hi-tech "stealth fries" - chips claimed to have a special crispier coating - which were introduced worldwide with a massive promotional campaign.
fields.body:
Burger King is set for an embarrassing climbdown in the run-up to its £2bn flotation by dropping its hi-tech "stealth fries" - chips claimed to have a special crispier coating - which were introduced worldwide with a massive promotional campaign.

Dubbed "the appliance of frience", the chips were introduced to Britain in January 1999 with a Free Fry Day, costing £4m. The fast-food chain said they were a key weapon in its war with McDonald's.

However, Burger King's acting chief executive, Colin Storm, is concerned about issues of "quality and consistency". He is testing two options - one a variation on the "stealth fry"; the other a return to traditional chips.

The chips were nicknamed stealth fries because, like the stealth bomber, they have an unprecedented hi-tech coating. In addition to making them more crispy, the coating retains heat for longer and makes the cooking process quicker.

Former chief executive Dennis Malamatinas, who left Burger King last month, was closely associated with the invention - in a series of interviews he waxed lyrical about the fries' superior taste.

Fries have traditionally been a problem for Burger King - many diners prefer the thinner, saltier versions sold worldwide by McDonald's.

Mr Storm is keen to settle the issue by next year, when Burger King's owner, Diageo, intends to float a 20% stake in the business on the New York Stock Exchange.

The public offering is already in danger of being delayed by difficulties in finding a permanent boss for the fast-food chain - Mr Storm, 61, was parachuted in from Guinness to run the business temporarily, but he is approaching retirement age. Diageo intends to float the remaining 80% of Burger King in 2002, when capital gains tax liabilities lapse.
