However, Burger King's acting chief executive, Colin Storm, is concerned about issues of "quality and consistency". He is testing two options - one a variation on the "stealth fry"; the other a return to traditional chips. The chips were nicknamed stealth fries because, like the stealth bomber, they have an unprecedented hi-tech coating. In addition to making them more crispy, the coating retains heat for longer and makes the cooking process quicker. Former chief executive Dennis Malamatinas, who left Burger King last month, was closely associated with the invention - in a series of interviews he waxed lyrical about the fries' superior taste. Fries have traditionally been a problem for Burger King - many diners prefer the thinner, saltier versions sold worldwide by McDonald's. Mr Storm is keen to settle the issue by next year, when Burger King's owner, Diageo, intends to float a 20% stake in the business on the New York Stock Exchange. The public offering is already in danger of being delayed by difficulties in finding a permanent boss for the fast-food chain - Mr Storm, 61, was parachuted in from Guinness to run the business temporarily, but he is approaching retirement age. Diageo intends to float the remaining 80% of Burger King in 2002, when capital gains tax liabilities lapse.

webTitle: Anger as US television airs killers' confessions

fields.headline: Anger as US television airs killers' confessions
fields.trailText: American television viewers last night got to see the latest phase in the relentless transformation of the criminal justice system into ratings-war mass entertainment when Court TV began airing a series of real-life criminal confessions under police interrogation.
fields.body:
American television viewers last night got to see the latest phase in the relentless transformation of the criminal justice system into ratings-war mass entertainment when Court TV began airing a series of real-life criminal confessions under police interrogation.

Last night's launch of the cable channel's new Confessions series - featuring suspects confessing to three murders and a rape - has stirred a fresh debate over whether there are any limits on the entertainment potential of the US criminal justice system.

American viewers can already watch police chases and arrests from their armchairs, while televised trials have become a staple of national and local news channels. Now that interrogations and confessions have been added to the list, some commentators have suggested that it could be only a matter of time before live executions are added to the primetime schedules in the name of the public's right to know.

Yesterday's launch episode featured three confessions from Manhattan. In the first, the suspect Steven Smith confesses to raping and killing a doctor in New York's Bellevue Hospital in 1989. That was followed by Damiel Rakowitz recounting how he killed his girlfriend before boiling her dismembered body in 1989. Finally, David Garcia, a male prostitute, admits to a 1995 murder he had previously claimed was self-defence.

"What they have to say can be stunning, but not because of the details," one reporter who was able to see a preview of the first programme said. "It's the banality and diffidence that is most striking."

The decision to go ahead with the new series stirred a war of words between critics and the Court TV network.

"This type of violent TV programming brings the media to an all-time low," Los Angeles city councillor Nate Holden wrote in a letter to Court TV's parent company Time Warner. "Is it not enough that we are inundated with news of actual crimes and violent, reality-based television on a daily basis? Do we need to take it a step further and get into the minds of these criminals?"

"For a network that does nothing in many respects but cover trials and investigations and bad people not to show the bad people in their own words is kind of ridiculous," Court TV chairman Henry Schlieff countered.

"Confessions makes me retch," the television critic of the New York daily Newsday wrote.

Under pressure from its critics, Court TV made one concession before airing its new show. Last night's first programme was followed by a 30-minute discussion on the decision to air the programme.

"We believe that valid concerns have been raised regarding the need for additional context about this programme," Mr Schlieff said in a statement.

"Drama and entertainment and non-fiction are coming together in a certain way. Look at the movies constructed out of real events," the producer of Confessions, Richard Kroehling, said. He said his programme was "very well executed".

fields.headline: Bill Waddington
fields.standfirst: Fame after retirement: the Street's Percy Sugden
fields.trailText: Few people are able to start, two years after the usual retirement age, a new career which makes them better known than anything they did in their past lives. But Bill Waddington, who has died in hospital after suffering from Parkinson's disease, aged 84, the entertainer who played Percy Sugden, the officious yet good-natured functionary always eluding Phyllis Pearce's blue-rinsed blandishments in Granada TV's long-running soap Coronation Street, was one of the fortunate few.
fields.body:
Few people are able to start, two years after the usual retirement age, a new career which makes them better known than anything they did in their past lives. But Bill Waddington, who has died in hospital after suffering from Parkinson's disease, aged 84, the entertainer who played Percy Sugden, the officious yet good-natured functionary always eluding Phyllis Pearce's blue-rinsed blandishments in Granada TV's long-running soap Coronation Street, was one of the fortunate few.

He was 67, living alone and disconsolate after the death of his wife Lilian had ended 32 years of conspicuously happy marriage, when, in 1983, he received the telephone call that revived his professional life. Waddington had first met his wife when, as Lilian Day, she was a regular principal boy in pantomime. After her death, he still talked aloud to her, in their modest home near Manchester, in the hope of getting some fresh pattern and meaning to his life.

That call from Granada wanted to know whether, after a lifetime spent amiably as a comedian (beginning in the second world war), he would play the irascible, unpredictable new community centre caretaker Percy Sugden, conceived of as a former Desert Rat with a flat cap and a pencil moustache.

Waddington himself was far from sure, but was determined to give it a try. He asked to see some scripts. In the end, he found that as long as he played the character dead straight, he could give Sugden humour, just as self-important but well-intentioned people in real life can easily appear funny.

Waddington was born in the middle of the first world war - and almost in the middle of the lunchtime drinks his mother was serving in the pub his father was managing for a friend, the Clarence Hotel in Oldham. She went upstairs to have her son, rather to the irritation of his over-worked father, a pliant carpenter who had first turned butcher to work in his ambitious wife's butchery business, and had then agreed to stand in as pub landlord for a friend who had joined up in the war. Waddington always thought he got his easy humour from his father, his will to hold people's attention from his forceful mother.

Expelled from his first school for being unruly, and at the age of ten expelled from Oldham parish church choir for pinching two bananas from the harvest festival display, he went to grammar school, but left at 14 after being described as "the clown for the class".

He had already done his first comic writing - a poem written after his boyhood crush, Gladys, suddenly got her long hair cut, revealing a dirty neck: "Oh Gladys, your neck/ Is a dirty old wreck/ And something is wanted to clean it./ Pan shine and soap/ May be a hope/ But emery's the stuff and you need it."

His flair for comedy was turned to more practical and chivalrous account when serving in his mother's butchery shop, increasing its turnover. When his mother, possibly enjoying another strong personality better from a distance, suggested he branch out for himself, he got a job selling medical equipment, which was overtaken by the second world war.

An admirer of the comedian George Formby, Waddington had mastered the ukelele and became an entertainer in the army's Blue Pencils concert party. He wrote his own comedy routines. These were well received by the radio critics when the BBC broadcast excerpts. Soon he was billed as "the Army's Top Comic".

As a postwar civilian comedian he was for 20 years, on a simple handshake, under the wing of the agents and impresarios Lew and Leslie Grade. He appeared with top calibre artists like Lena Horne and Frankie Laine, did a Royal Variety Performance, ran a Rolls Royce, bought a farm, failed as a pig rearer but succeeded as a breeder of racehorses at the stud he owned in Shropshire.

Racehorses remained a passion even after the traumatic death of his wife Lilian in 1980, when he found himself talking to a pile of manure: "I'll be back to clean you up in a minute," he said. That lapse into sanitary conversation told him that he badly needed a new interest.

Coronation Street and its off-screen social life supplied it. He was even thrilled when Percy Sugden's grumpiness won him the title, through a tabloid newspaper poll, of the third most hated person on TV, after JR of Dallas and Alexis of Dynasty. His character left the Street to move to a care home in 1997 after Waddington reportedly objected to the soap's ever-more racy storylines.

He married four times - once, briefly, during the war, then long and successfully to Lilian, by whom he had two daughters, Anne and Barbara. After Lilian's death in 1982 he married Irene, again briefly, and then, in 1995, Sheila, who survives him.

webTitle: Comment: Britain is throwing its weight about in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Throwing our weight about
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: A personal view
Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Any thought that the aftermath of Nato's Kosovan imbroglio might have dimmed Tony Blair's enthusiasm for "humanitarian wars" has been dispelled. His government has emerged as the most interventionist British administration since decolonisation. No opportunity is now to be passed up, it seems, to raise the 21st-century crusader's flag across the globe.
fields.body:
Any thought that the aftermath of Nato's Kosovan imbroglio might have dimmed Tony Blair's enthusiasm for "humanitarian wars" has been dispelled. His government has emerged as the most interventionist British administration since decolonisation. No opportunity is now to be passed up, it seems, to raise the 21st-century crusader's flag across the globe.

The increasingly grim Sierra Leone adventure, with its kidnappings and yesterday's bloodstained, military rescue, is the third time in 18 months that New Labour has used British armed force outside UN control. Sierra Leone has also been the biggest independent British overseas military operation since the Falklands war.

Thirty-nine years after the union flag was hauled down in Freetown on almost two centuries of bloody colonial rule, British squaddies have now been back in significant force for months, their commanders directing the conduct of a gruesome and intractable civil war.

With barely a murmur of public debate at home, British troops are once again shooting Sierra Leoneans dead in their own land, while Royal Navy gunboats patrol the west African coast and the limb-hacking rebels of the Revolutionary United Front are routinely compared to Nazis, the standard designation for all post-1945 British enemies.

The scaled-down British "training mission" and its backup security units - denounced by the UN commander for their "Rambo tactics" - are embroiled in a wider conflict with, among others, renegade British-armed militias. More paratroopers have been shipped out to hold an indefensible line. The declared intent is not only to rescue hostages and maul the erstwhile government-supporting "West Side Boys", but also to take back control of Sierra Leone's lucrative diamond fields.

The Blair administration's intervention sprees began with the four-day Anglo-American missile onslaught against Iraq in December 1998. The bombing raids there have continued, outside the terms of UN resolutions and opposed by a majority of the permanent UN security council members, while the US and Britain's enforcement of the failed sanctions regime - described by US Democratic congressman David Bonnier as "infanticide masquerading as a policy" - is now almost universally recognised as having created a humanitarian disaster.

But it was Nato's self-proclaimed war of values over Kosovo that triggered Mr Blair's clarion call last year in Chicago for a new wave of worldwide intervention, based on what he described - echoing the liberal imperialists of the late 19th century - as a "subtle blend" of self-interest and moral purpose.

A year on, reverse ethnic cleansing proceeds apace in Kosovo.

But the full flowering of Mr Blair's new line has been in Africa, where the Unites States still fears to tread in the wake of its Somali debacle of the early 1990s. After weeks of British interference in the internal crisis in Zimbabwe - with British ministers repeatedly championing the cause of white landowners who made up the backbone of the racist Rhodesian regime, while denouncing the black leadership which defeated it as "uncivilised" - Blair's paratroopers were despatched to Freetown to fill the vacuum left by the disintegrating UN peacekeeping force Britain refused to join a year ago.

The fact that Iraq, Zimbabwe and Sierra Leone are all former British colonies does not seem to trouble the cheerleaders of the new "doctrine of international community", enveloped as they are in a blanket of cultural amnesia about the horrors of Britain's colonial past. It is less than 50 years since British soldiers shot dead striking Sierra Leoneans on the streets of Freetown, were paid five shillings for each Kenyan Kikuyu they killed, nailed the limbs of Mau Mau fighters to cross-roads posts and had themselves photographed with the severed heads of Malayan guerrillas.

With such a record, it might be thought that Britain was the last country on the planet to sort out the "savagery" of its once-captive subjects. The world, we are told, has moved on. But for the people of Africa - burdened with western debt, arms, mercenaries, mineral-hungry multinational companies and commodity prices that have been falling for more than 40 years - it has not moved on enough.

After supporting one corrupt dictator after another in Sierra Leone, Britain has thrown its military and diplomatic weight behind President Kabbah and his supporters, who Tony Blair insists are the democratic "good guys", against the rural-based RUF, led by vice- president Foday Sankoh until his capture by British soldiers in May.

But the 1996 elections which brought Kabbah to power were held when the country was already engulfed in civil war, did not include the RUF and were undermined by violence and ballot rigging claims. While the RUF has the worst record of atrocities, according to Amnesty International, Kabbah and his kamajor militias have also been heavily involved in torture and extra-judicial killings, and his ally Johnny Paul Koroma is responsible for the mutilation and massacre of thousands of civilians. These are the people British troops are supporting - until Koroma's former proteges, the West Side Boys, started kidnapping British soldiers.

The reality is that Britain and its friends are part of the problem in Sierra Leone and that no outside force can impose the necessary internal settlement. If Mr Blair wants to build a genuine international community, he should be working through the UN and universally accepted regional bodies - rather than, as Nelson Mandela charged earlier this year, playing "policemen of the world" with the US and "introducing chaos into international affairs" by acting unilaterally.

The record shows that the more effective peacekeepers in Sierra Leone have been regional forces. The most useful contribution Britain and other western states - which still refuse to write off the debts of countries such as Nigeria - could now make to Sierra Leone would be to support an African solution to an African crisis.

seumas.milne@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Big bores
fields.trailText: I don't know why Simon Hoggart (Saturday Review, September 9) is getting so exercised about Big Brother. We have been subjected to the antics of "unpopular and dysfunctional extrovert bores" ever since they started broadcasting parliament.
fields.body:
I don't know why Simon Hoggart (Saturday Review, September 9) is getting so exercised about Big Brother. We have been subjected to the antics of "unpopular and dysfunctional extrovert bores" ever since they started broadcasting parliament.
Richard Towers
Lymm, Cheshire

 Cabinet meetings could be televised and each month the public could vote to require resignation of one member.
Paul Roberts
Farndon, Cheshire

fields.headline: Challenges for the unions
fields.trailText: The TUC wants to bring its "social partnership" up to levels "common throughout the rest of the EU" (Morris warns TUC to beware euro danger, September 8). But this requires measures wider than the proposal by the European Commission for rights to information and consultation in enterprises with 50 employees or more.
fields.body:
The TUC wants to bring its "social partnership" up to levels "common throughout the rest of the EU" (Morris warns TUC to beware euro danger, September 8). But this requires measures wider than the proposal by the European Commission for rights to information and consultation in enterprises with 50 employees or more.

In many European countries, unions have legally protected rights of access to the workforce. In Britain, a right to general access is confined to the period before a ballot in the recognition procedures of the 1999 legislation.

Many unions are also able to sue in the courts on behalf of their members' collective interests. In Britain, employees must enforce employment protection rights by individualised claims.

In Germany and France, the employer must make a "social plan" providing for compensation to workers because of regrading and other changes. The German version must be agreed between the works council and employer, or is imposed by bipartite arbitration if they cannot agree. In France, collective dismissals effected in the absence of a "social plan" are null and void, and workers in such cases must be immediately reinstated. Here, even in cases of unfair dismissal reinstatement is a rare remedy.

For a modern system of protection of workers, we must still look to national systems of law and collective bargaining. EU rights rarely go beyond rights to consultation.
Lord Wedderburn

 Trade unionists should consider breaking with New Labour when it comes to the use of their union's political levy. Ordinary members of trade unions have little or no say over how their political levy is used. This issue is even more important when one considers the present government's record on the minimum wage and privatisation and the way in which New Labour now funds itself with donations from big business.
John Boocock
Invergordon

fields.trailText: Matthew Taylor's article on employment growth only touched on the geographical differentials in employment that are now the main obstacle to further jobs growth (Still more jobs required, September 8). The latest estimates from the labour force survey show that in 238 parliamentary constituencies the employment rate is now lower than it was in early 1997.

The latest estimates from the labour force survey show that in 238 parliamentary constituencies the employment rate is now lower than it was in early 1997. These falls are heavily concentrated - nine of the Merseyside constituencies have seen falls in employment.

A growing economy and the New Deal are great achievements but do not go far enough for some poorer areas. There is a case for stimulating employment in these areas through selective reflation and cutting employee national insurance rates.
Frank Field MP

fields.headline: Comprehensive support
fields.trailText: We've put five children through comprehensive schooling; two of them have degrees equally as good as Tony Blair's and the others have the qualifications to go on for a degree. So what's with this "failing" comprehensive system (Blair plans schools revolution, September 9)?
fields.body:
We've put five children through comprehensive schooling; two of them have degrees equally as good as Tony Blair's and the others have the qualifications to go on for a degree. So what's with this "failing" comprehensive system (Blair plans schools revolution, September 9)? Instead of an exam at 11-plus, we will now have teachers deciding who will qualify as an academic and who will be called vocational candidates (school-speak for a bit thick).

In my day it was call an apprenticeship, but it got the majority of us out of the way, whilst the "bright" people were allowed to sparkle. Mr Blair's revolution is going to create the same divisions, but he is going to have many successful, comprehensively educated, parents opposing him. They won't want their kids consigned to the dustbin.
Joe Phillips
Bingham, Notts

 As a governor of an excellent comprehensive school and a Labour party member I am doubly mortified by Tony Blair's comments. His "one size fits all" claim seems to be based on an Islington experience which ignores the successes of comprehensive schools in many other parts of the country. I fully support the reaction of the Secondary Head's Association, which described Mr Blair's comments as "scandalous". At least headteachers know something about education.
David Allan
St Albans, Herts
david.allan1@ntlworld.com

 Does Mr Blair really not know of 40 years of dedicated work in our schools, exploring differentiation, testing the best ways of grouping students to further their attainment, building cohesion and social inclusion, and creating opportunities for success for everyone, even the least likely. You don't improve a system by constantly denigrating it and, instead of addressing real weaknesses, inventing a list of new ones that never existed.
Rev Gunter Helft
Worcester
gunterhelft@lineone.net

 My son's secondary school has just enabled two-thirds of the students to again achieve at least five A-C passes at GCSE. At the same time, the school has supported several pupils rejected by more selective local schools and has provided a specialist education to a dozen deaf pupils. I fail to see what is wrong with a system that can enable a broad range of pupils to achieve such success.
Cliff Turner
Winchester
Edepwrct@aol.com

 How did "the failing model of comprehensive education" became such a maxim of Guardian journalism that it can be so casually tripped out. This seems to me a rather shabby patch upon the paper to which so many hard-working teachers will have turned on Saturday.
Mike Hawthorne
Ludlow school

 Your story comes shortly after the best-ever A-level and GSCE results. Evidence for failure in the story: nil.
Martin Francis
London

 The real failure comes from a government which seems unable to recognise how badly the state sector is undermined by allowing the brightest (and the wealthiest) students to be creamed off year after year and educated in the privileged environment of the selective and/or private sector.
Nick Young
Worcester

 Comprehensive schools have been setting their pupils for many years. Introducing measures to enable schools to deal effectively with the disruptive behaviour of the few who impede the learning of the many - now that would be revolutionary.
Cathy Bailey
Peterborough

fields.headline: UN has the last word
fields.trailText: Contrary to George Monbiot's claims (Letters, September 8), when ambassador Razali Ismail was president of the UN general assembly he never made any public pronouncement that would suggest that business plays a formal role in UN decision-making.
fields.body:
Contrary to George Monbiot's claims (Letters, September 8), when ambassador Razali Ismail was president of the UN general assembly he never made any public pronouncement that would suggest that business plays a formal role in UN decision-making.

What he did was to lay the foundations for implementing the outcome of the Rio conference on environment and development, where industry - along with seven other "major groups" (including churches, NGOs, labour and academia) - was called upon by governments to implement various provisions.

The point here is that it is governments that request other actors make certain contributions. To quote a memo from Unctad (UN Conference on Trade and Development) on cooperation on competition policy to show that business has a formal role in decision-making is to misunderstand how policy formulation occurs at governmental and intergovernmental level.

Regarding the humanitarian forum, it is a fact that Kofi Annan sent brief remarks to this event following the request by the high commissioner for refugees. This was not an inaugural speech: he wasn't even there physically. Nor did the UN chair this event.

And as for the UN logo, there is no other organisation that guards its logo as closely as the UN. The guidelines on the use of name and logo are on our website for everybody to see.
John Ruggie
Assistant secretary-general, United Nations

fields.headline: Transport takes the biscuit
fields.standfirst: Over 20 years ago, Fritz Schumacher suggested that a man from Mars would conclude that biscuits need to spend eight hours trundling around the motorway network in order to be mature enough to eat. Disparities in prices mean that it is cheaper to make, say, all ginger nuts in the south-east and all custard cremes in Scotland.
fields.trailText:
Over 20 years ago, Fritz Schumacher suggested that a man from Mars would conclude that biscuits need to spend eight hours trundling around the motorway network in order to be mature enough to eat. Disparities in prices mean that it is cheaper to make, say, all ginger nuts in the south-east and all custard cremes in Scotland. Add this to the fashion for just-in-time production, and it is inevitable that motorways will be full of biscuit trucks. Markets are good at producing short-run prices but not at accounting for longer-run effects. Someone else will pay for those.
Prof Michael Pidd
Lancaster University

On holiday in Italy and France I calculated that their motorway tolls are equivalent to £3 per gallon for a car doing 35 miles per gallon. Even if one did only half one's mileage on toll roads, this means an equivalent of about £4.50 a gallon. At under £4 our petrol is a bargain.
Brian Hughes
Leckhampton, Glos

We might sense some serious intent at improvement when this "customer" nonsense is expunged and the focus returned to the service itself.
Ken Ward
London

fields.headline: Logos and Lib Dems
fields.trailText: I am appalled (New logo for London Transport, September 6) that Transport for London is thinking about a new logo "to establish a new identity". What the people of London need is better services like cleaner stations and newer buses, not new logos
fields.body:
I am appalled (New logo for London Transport, September 6) that Transport for London is thinking about a new logo "to establish a new identity". What the people of London need is better services like cleaner stations and newer buses, not new logos.
HF Heinemann
St Andrews, Fife

 Charles Kennedy says "tax and spend policies suck" (Kennedy's £7bn tax and spend gamble, September 7). Show me one government in the world that doesn't "tax and spend". What Kennedy really means is that in well-off constituencies the Lib Dems will promise tax cuts, and in poor constituencies the Lib Dems will promise every form of spending under the sun. That's how the Lib Dems behave, and it sucks.
Colin Challen
Wakefield

 I can assure Jody Lammas-Daniell (Letters, September 9) the sports editor is not given to "... promotion of black role models...", condescending or otherwise. If he were, we might have seen a photograph of Mark Alleyne, the most successful captain in English cricket. If only he had decent thighs ...
Peter Caswell
Warrington

 So your reviewer finds Colin Buchanan's audio tape of Tony Parsons's Man And Boy to have "falsetto female voices [that] are irritating and almost absurd" (Saturday Review, September 9). Could it, by any chance, be related to the failure of Mr Parson's ex-partner, Julie Burchill, to make a career for herself on TV and radio?
Vic Allen
Otley, Yorks

 I have just finished watching another memorable Last Night of the Proms on BBC TV, once again posing the question: "Britons never never will be slaves" or "Britons never never shall be slaves"?
John Kremer
Kendal, Cumbria

fields.headline: ... without a fresh start
fields.trailText: While Rebecca Smithers offers a fair assessment of "fresh start", it is part of a much wider strategy to turn around failing schools (School's out, September 6). Before this government came to power, many failing schools were simply allowed to drift on in a pattern of continuing failure.
fields.body:
While Rebecca Smithers offers a fair assessment of "fresh start", it is part of a much wider strategy to turn around failing schools (School's out, September 6). Before this government came to power, many failing schools were simply allowed to drift on in a pattern of continuing failure.

The government is determined to break that pattern and is successfully doing so. Since 1997, 571 failing schools have come off special measures, having been given a clean bill of health by Ofsted. We are seeing real improvements in most schools, particularly inner-city schools.

In future, fresh start schools will be required to set clearer targets for improvement and we will be providing heads with the support they need - including additional funding where fresh start schools can demonstrate this will help. Where these measures don't work, the school will have to close - as 108 failing schools have done. Fresh start was an alternative to closure.
Estelle Morris MP
Minister of State, Department for Education

 I was for 13 years the deputy head of the fresh start school in Hull, Perronet Thompson, now renamed Kingswood. The staff of Perronet endured nearly four years of "special measures", endless time-consuming inspections and derogatory local comment.

At a meeting with the local education authority the then chair of the education committee told Perronet's assembled staff: "You have failed the children." Since it remains official government policy that the "failure" of working-class children to achieve the requisite GCSE grades is the fault of the teachers, are the teachers in the new "fresh start" schools now to be blamed and shamed? If not, can teachers like me who were "blamed and shamed" - and fired and retired - look forward to receiving an apology?
Sally Walker
Hull

webTitle: UN warns Jakarta refugees could die

fields.headline: UN warns Jakarta refugees could die
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The UN warned Indonesia yesterday that it would be held responsible for the fate of some 130,000 East Timorese refugees in West Timor who are facing deteriorating conditions and a dwindling food supply following last week's evacuation of international humanitarian organisations.
fields.body:
The UN warned Indonesia yesterday that it would be held responsible for the fate of some 130,000 East Timorese refugees in West Timor who are facing deteriorating conditions and a dwindling food supply following last week's evacuation of international humanitarian organisations.

With stocks of rice, the refugees' staple, and medicine exhausted in many of the 200-odd camps in West Timor and running dangerously low in the others, UN officials are warning that unless Jakarta changes its policy towards the refugees then thousands could soon die.

"If they do starve then it's because of a decision by the Indonesian government," said Andrew Harper, who was the programme coordinator of the UN's refugee agency (UNHCR) in West Timor until all staff of international organisations were withdrawn following the murder of three UNHCR staff by pro-Jakarta militiamen on Wednesday.

"Indonesia has a major programme to distribute rice across the archipelago to feed its 200m people and it has the resources to carry out this programme," he said. "So another 130,000 mouths should not be a problem. All it will take is the political will."

Such political will has been in short supply in Jakarta since the UN staff were killed. After an emergency cabinet meeting on Friday, the vice president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, announced that 100 tonnes of rice would be sent soon to the refugees in West Timor.

That is about 6% of the amount the UN has been distributing to the refugees each month through its partner organisations since October. Most of the refugees were forced to leave East Timor by the militias following the territory's overwhelming vote for independence from Indonesia in a UN-sponsored referendum.

In the past refugees have said that even when they were given food, much of it was seized by the militiamen who control the camps.

webTitle: Two Koreas will march as one into Olympic stadium

fields.headline: Two Koreas will march as one into Olympic stadium
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Korea
Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: North and South Korea will march together under the same flag at the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in Sydney next week in a further sign of the blossoming spirit of detente on the divided peninsula.
fields.body:
North and South Korea will march together under the same flag at the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in Sydney next week in a further sign of the blossoming spirit of detente on the divided peninsula.

The flag will show a map of the whole of Korea and will be carried by two athletes, one from the North and one from the South. The team name on display will be simply "Korea" although the athletes will then compete as separate countries.

The International Olympic committee president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, said he had personally negotiated the deal over the last five days.

He announced the agreement yesterday in Sydney, flanked by the IOC members from both North and South. The North's delegate, Chang Ung, said the deal was appropriate because "we are the same blood".

South Korea's team is several times the size of its neighbour's, but in the opening ceremony, the South's numbers will be cut so the North Korean athletes are not visibly outnumbered. Both teams will also march into the stadium wearing the same uniform.

The IOC announcement comes as North-South relations continue to defy predictions that the momentum of detente begun at the June summit in Pyongyang would have flagged by now.

A delegation from Pyongyang arrived in Seoul yesterday to start planning for a return summit in Seoul. If this is staged it will be an even more momentous occasion.

The North's leader, Kim Jong-il, has only made one official visit outside his country so far - to China - although he hinted in June that he had made trips incognito to other destinations.

Pyongyang is obsessively concerned with security and the South Korean authorities will have great difficulty in providing the well-regulated atmosphere which can easily be laid on in the North.

The South's president, Kim Dae-jung, at a meeting on Saturday with US business leaders in New York, called on them to promote investment in the North. He said that the summit had helped to change the region into "a very stable and favourable investment destination".

Work will begin later this month on rebuilding the divided North-South railway across the demilitarised zone. President Kim will attend a ceremony in a week's time before engineer battalions are sent in to clear minefields.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Police told to be more polite
fields.body:
Police told to be more polite

Police officers would avoid many sticky situations if they are more polite and used words such as "please" and "thank you". Peaceful situations often escalate to violence because officers are just too rude, says the Police Complaints Authority which received 1,028 complaints of incivility last year.

Indian air crash survivor dies

An orthopaedic surgeon who survived a plane crash in India in which his wife was one of 56 people killed in July has died from his injuries. Pramond Kumar, 45, of Newton Mearns, Glasgow, and his two children, Pratchi, 18, and Ketan, 13, were among seven passengers who survived the crash at Patna airport in Bihar.
Kirsty Scott

Would-be peers apply here

Members of the public who would like to be peers will have to fill in an application form, enclose a CV and provide two referees under proposals to be put forward by the independent House of Lords appointments commission this week.

Farmer killed in accident

A farmer who died after becoming trapped in his combine harvester was named by police as John Kirk, 64. His body was found by his son Peter on his farm in Stokesley, North Yorkshire.

Two share £7m

Two tickets shared Saturday's£7.3m lottery jackpot with numbers 3, 4, 24, 25, 35, 43. The bonus ball was 7. The Thunderball was not won.

Indian air crash survivor dies An orthopaedic surgeon who survived a plane crash in India in which his wife was one of 56 people killed in July has died from his injuries. Pramond Kumar, 45, of Newton Mearns, Glasgow, and his two children, Pratchi, 18, and Ketan, 13, were among seven passengers who survived the crash at Patna airport in Bihar. Kirsty Scott Would-be peers apply here Members of the public who would like to be peers will have to fill in an application form, enclose a CV and provide two referees under proposals to be put forward by the independent House of Lords appointments commission this week. Farmer killed in accident A farmer who died after becoming trapped in his combine harvester was named by police as John Kirk, 64. His body was found by his son Peter on his farm in Stokesley, North Yorkshire. Two share £7m Two tickets shared Saturday's£7.3m lottery jackpot with numbers 3, 4, 24, 25, 35, 43. The bonus ball was 7. The Thunderball was not won.

webTitle: Red Oskar to remain in exile, for now

fields.headline: Red Oskar to remain in exile, for now
fields.standfirst: Lafontaine says tide has turned against the left
fields.trailText: The Sun dubbed him "The Most Dangerous Man in Europe". Fellow Germans knew this key figure in European politics as the "Napoleon from Saarland", and when he stormed out of the German government in March 1999 it was front-page news around the world.
fields.body:
The Sun dubbed him "The Most Dangerous Man in Europe". Fellow Germans knew this key figure in European politics as the "Napoleon from Saarland", and when he stormed out of the German government in March 1999 it was front-page news around the world.

Today, "Red" Oskar Lafontaine cuts a different figure. He spends his time writing articles, reading German classics, and picking mushrooms in the woods around his home.

Mr Lafontaine was in reflective mood as he talked in his house in Saarbrücken near the French border. Though speculation about a comeback has been rife in Germany since April when he made a public apology to his colleagues in the Social Democratic Party (SPD), he told the Guardian he is not looking back. In his first interview with a British newspaper since he quit, he said he could see no point in re-entering politics while so few of his party colleagues -"I would say 30, 40%" - shared his doubts about the "Third Way" course being steered by chancellor Gerhard Schröder.

"A comeback in the present situation is unimaginable," he said. "I do not know what I shall be doing in 10 years, but for the moment my decision is clear."

Another factor was his profoundly gloomy assessment of the prospects of applying leftwing policies in the current international setting.

"Without a new architecture for international financial markets, it is not possible to practise social democracy," he said flatly. "The international financial markets have become a machine for redistributing wealth from the poor to the rich. And social democracy is not to redistribute from the poor to the rich."

Mr Lafontaine said the alternative was a Blairite "Third Way" programme that amounted to a "pack of lies". He himself had been able to in troduce only relatively minor changes while in government.

Some degree of mystery continues to surround Mr Lafontaine's shock resignation last year from his job as finance minister. He says now that one factor behind the decision was a change he underwent after an assassination attempt 10 years ago.

"You have the experience that life can end. Today. In the next hour. You get a new feeling for life. You learn that there is no life without family, without friends, without literature, art and so on.

"Perhaps, without this attack, I would have had another road in politics, a different will to fight," he said. Further clues to the causes of his departure are given in his book, The Heart Beats on the Left, which is published in English this week. It suggests that there were deep-seated policy differences between Mr Lafontaine and Mr Schröder.

Mr Lafontaine's own recipe for change in Europe runs very counter to the Third Way. He would include stabilising exchange rates and curbing short-term capital movements to prevent speculation on macro-economic trends. Measures to do so could easily be agreed by the Group of Seven most economically powerful nations, he said, but there was little hope they would do so.

"The two candidates for the presidency of the United States are financed by Wall Street and so, if you are financed by Wall Street, you must respect the interests of Wall Street."

In Germany, nevertheless, the situation was less stable than it appeared. "In the centre of Europe it is not possible in the longer term to have a policy of neo-liberalism." Mr Lafontaine argued.

Gerhard Schröder's coalition with the Greens had so far benefited from huge doses of good luck. Its "Blairite" policies had initially cost it a string of defeats in regional elections. But since then, the euro had plunged, giving Germany an unexpected export-led boom. And over the same period, the other main party, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) had become embroiled in a hugely damaging scandal.

"Yet we have a little bit the same result as two years ago after the election. My opinion is - and my experience is - that, if the Christian Democrats are in a situation like this, we should have 10% more." If his analysis is correct, Mr Schröder's grip on power is more tenuous than it appears and a comeback by the "Saarland Napoleon" might not be quite as remote as he insists.

In the meantime, though, he and his wife will continue looking for a farm on which to live with their three -year-old son.

"I will not be a farmer. I am too stupid to be a farmer. But I like to be in contact with nature. If I find a big farm, I am going to need staff because I am not able to organise a farm. I never learned how to," he said and laughed."Perhaps I can have some chickens."

The Heart Beats on the Left by Oskar Lafontaine. Polity. Prices: £45.00 (hardback); £12.99 (paperback).

fields.headline: Six die in Italian flood
fields.trailText: The rain-swollen waters of a stream swept through a camping ground filled with disabled campers in southern Italy before dawn yesterday, killing at least six people and injuring dozens as they slept.
fields.body:
The rain-swollen waters of a stream swept through a camping ground filled with disabled campers in southern Italy before dawn yesterday, killing at least six people and injuring dozens as they slept.

Vincenzo Gallitto, prefect of the Calabrian city of Catanzaro, said that as many as 13 people were missing from Le Giare campground, including a handful of tourists who were not part of the organisation for the disabled.

The flood waters turned the campground where disabled campers from Calabria and their volunteer aides have gone every summer for seven years into a sea of mud, turning over cars, shoving caravans into trees and smashing bungalows.

One of the first victims to be identified was that of 52-year-old man from Catanzaro who used a wheelchair because of disabilities caused by Alzheimer's disease, the Italian news agency Ansa said.

Carabinieri paramilitary police in Soverato said the other five victims were not disabled campers. One of the dead was Rosario Russo, 17, who was carried hundreds of metres by the raging waters after he helped save his father, who uses a wheelchair

After weeks of intense heat, storms struck much of southern Italy on Friday, isolating dozens of coastal hamlets

fields.headline: Police shaming killed kerb-crawler
fields.trailText: The suicide of a man caught kerb crawling has sparked uproar in Italy over a new police tactic to expose and humiliate prostitutes' clients.
fields.body:
The suicide of a man caught kerb crawling has sparked uproar in Italy over a new police tactic to expose and humiliate prostitutes' clients.

A 25-year-old engineer hanged himself from a tree near his parents' house after police impounded his car and charged him with exploiting the prostitute in the passenger seat.

He had not broken any law and would not have been convicted. Police knew, however, that the news of his arrest would dominate gossip in his village of Colfesco, near Venice, where he had a girlfriend and family.

The interior minister, Enzo Bianco, immediately distanced himself from the policy of naming and shaming and ordered an inquiry into the decision to arrest the man, named only as Antonello.

"I have never given a directive telling police to sequester the cars of clients," said Mr Bianco.

The issue threatened to split the centre-left government after the prime minister, Giuliano Amato, said zero tolerance was necessary to combat Italy's soaring number of streetwalkers, estimated at 50,000.

Prostitution is not a crime in Italy, but aiding and abetting prostitutes is, so several cities have started targeting clients with a law originally aimed at pimps.

Police credit the tactic with dramatic reductions in kerb crawling. Lawyers are fighting to have it declared illegitimate and a violation of privacy.

The village priest told mourners they had lost a decent young man who made a mistake and paid too high a price.

Maurizio, a friend of Antonello, told reporters: "They killed him. He was humiliated, he was a boy who lived in a village where everyone talks about everyone."

According to yesterday's Il Messaggero newspaper, the crackdown has resulted in Rome's kerb crawlers swapping cars for bicycles, which are less likely to be confiscated. The women are carried on back carriers.

"They are afraid of the fines," said a Nigerian prostitute who had been with three cyclists that day.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Mugabe spurns £280m lawsuit
fields.body:
Mugabe spurns £280m lawsuit

Zimbabwe dismissed yesterday a $400m (£280m) lawsuit brought against President Robert Mugabe in the US as a "non-event".

The civil case, filed during the UN's millennium summit in New York, accuses Mr Mugabe of orchestrating violence to keep his ruling party in power and says he was responsible for human rights abuses surrounding the parliamentary elections in June. AP , Harare

Poor turnout in Hong Kong vote

Hong Kong voted in disappointing numbers to elect a new legislative council yesterday. The final turnout is expected to be 10% down on the 1998 election.

Observers said voters knew that the council has few real powers and were disillusioned by recent po litical rows. Only 24 out of 60 seats are directly elected, and seats in the two other categories are dominated by pro-government groups. Full results are expected today. John Gittings , Hong Kong

Macedonians go to the polls

Macedonians voted in local elections yesterday, the first in a series of polls in the Balkans which could prove a watershed in the region. The election, a showdown between the reformist government coalition and the Socialist opposition, will be followed by presidential, parliamentary and municipal elections in Yugoslavia on September 24. Reuters , Skopje

Prince injured in Paris crash

The son of the Grand Duke of Luxembourg was in a serious condition in a Paris hospital last night after a car accident. Police said 37-year-old Prince William's car flipped several times into the path of oncoming traffic. His 32-year-old wife, Sybilla, suffered minor injuries. Two other people were also hurt in the accident near Paris. AP , Paris

webTitle: Freed hostages recall terror in the Philippines

fields.headline: Freed hostages recall terror in the Philippines
fields.trailText: After 140 days of "living hell", the four westerners released at the weekend by Muslim separatists in the southern Philippines spent their first full day of freedom yesterday enjoying the delights of a luxury resort before preparing to fly home.
fields.body:
After 140 days of "living hell", the four westerners released at the weekend by Muslim separatists in the southern Philippines spent their first full day of freedom yesterday enjoying the delights of a luxury resort before preparing to fly home.

But the Philippines' worst ever hostage crisis, on the remote, jungle island of Jolo, is still far from over. Leaders of the Abu Sayyaf guerrillas said yesterday there was no timetable for the release of their four remaining hostages following a gun battle between rebel factions on Saturday that left at least three people dead.

Those still being held are one Filipino - the only one of the original 21 people kidnapped on April 23 - two of three French journalists who were seized while covering the crisis, 12 evangelical Christian preachers taken when they went into the jungle to pray for the hostages and an American seized two weeks ago.

But German Marc Wallert, Frenchman Stephane Loisy, and Finns Risto Vahanen and Seppo Franti, the last of the 10 westerners in the original group to be freed, spent yesterday savouring normal life.

Once they had surfaced after a night of celebrating, Mr Loisy went scuba diving, which is what he was preparing to do when kidnapped from the Malaysian resort island of Sipadan on April 23. "It feels like freedom," he said.

The others spent most of the day lounging by the pool, reading about themselves in newspapers and toasting their freedom with red wine.

"We have had a lot of time to consider our lives, consider our values," Mr Vahanen, who owns an engineering firm, said. "I think our lives will be changed after this." He was keen to get back to work. "Anything will feel like a vacation after what we have been through."

Mr Franti said drawing helped him through depression. "I was very down. I drew and this helped me very much," he said. At one stage, he said, he was very close to suicide.

Most of the hostages, including those released earlier, said the worst moments of their captivity were when they were twice caught in mortar and gunfire between the guerrillas and Philippine soldiers soon after they were captured.

At one time while they had to dive out of the bamboo hut in which they were sheltering when a gun fight erupted. Mr Vahanen said they found the hut roof riddled with bullet holes when they went back to it.

Mr Franti recounted that he vomited often from the smell of human waste and rotting food as the crisis dragged on and conditions deteriorated.

Even though they said they could never forgive Abu Sayyaf for abducting them, the four blamed the Philippine government for causing the crisis.

"[They] can't neglect remote areas." Mr Vahanen said. They have to give similar chances to all people, no matter what their religion, no matter where they live. What we saw in Jolo was real poverty, and this kind of poverty is always the seed of this kind of guerrilla movement."

As with the six westerners freed two weeks ago, the four men will fly home via Libya so that the Libyans, who paid the $4m (£2.8m) that secured their release, can bask in their success. The Libyan negotiator Rajab Azzarouq insists that the money is for development projects, but it is clear the rebels are using much of it to buy new weapons and to attract recruits.

Arguments over the distribution of the cash is believed to have caused the battle on Saturday. The senior Abu Sayyaf commander, Ghalib Andang, said yesterday that he could not release the remaining prisoners until he had dealt with the faction that rebelled against his leadership.

A separate faction is holding the American Jeffrey Schilling. Yesterday it released a tape, which it claimed was an interview with him."Although I am kept in either chains or handcuffs, I am not mistreated," said the tape, broadcast on the Radio Mindanao network.

"Their negotiators are ready to compromise on their part. Use the Libyan government as negotiators and end my captivity as soon as possible."

webTitle: How to pose for your byline picture

fields.headline: How to pose for your byline picture
fields.trailText: The hand job. A hand framing or supporting face is easily the most popular pose. Examples: Sue Carroll, Alexander Walker, Anne Robinson. Pro: Versatile, conveys quizzical image. Con: Can look camp or arch.
fields.body:
The hand job. A hand framing or supporting face is easily the most popular pose. Examples: Sue Carroll, Alexander Walker, Anne Robinson. Pro: Versatile, conveys quizzical image. Con: Can look camp or arch.

Gormless grin. Increasingly in vogue, as editors look to banish glumness. Examples: Garry Bushell, Gabby Yorath. Pro: Helps nation to start day with smile on its face. If nation not further depressed by seeing grinning face of lucky rich git, that is. Con: Looks daft if writer feels sudden need to pen serious column.

I'm a star too. For high-earning columnists or interviewers: simple pose, serious face, but heavy-duty cosmetics and top photographer, making writer look just as classy as stars she slags off or profiles. Seen with mag editor columnists - Alexandra Shulman, Liz Jones. Pro: Quality of image guarantees regular flannel panel appearances. Con: Hack visibly part of celeb world, no longer mediator between reader and famous.

Commentator (old style). Ideal pose requires baleful gaze at reader as if he/she personally responsible for politico-moral decay. Examples: Peter Hitchens, Sin Simon, any Daily Mail curmudgeon. Pro: Suggests man so nauseated by state of nation he is barely able to stop himself vomiting. Con: Role of male Cassandra hard to sustain - risk of disillusioning readers if seen giggling tipsily in local pub.

Commentator (new style). Prettification reaches the comment zone, with political penseurs portrayed with a nascent, ambiguous smile. Examples: Simon Heffer, Simon Jenkins, Andrew Rawnsley. Pro: Embodying nation's agony under socialism/ Thatcherism/Blairism full-time no longer required. Con: Followers from grumpy days likely to ask, "What's he got to smirk about? Country's going to the dogs!"

Chameleon. Appearing in utterly disparate guises in different outlets. Examples: Andrew Marr pre-BBC job (jovial in the Observer, but martyr to constipation in Express); Suzanne Moore (close to Medusa-like Guardian image in New Statesman, but mumsy figure in Mail on Sunday). Pro: Makes important statement about plural nature of self. Con: Relies riskily on lefty friends not seeing rightwing papers, or vice versa.

Age cannot wither. When photo remains unchanged after 40th birthday. Examples: Geoffrey Wheatcroft, Fay Maschler. Pro: Risk of recognition - hence of horse-whipping by angry public sector workers (Wheatcroft) or chefs (Maschler) - reduced. Con: Could be arrested as impostor if using prestige of name for, eg, hotel bookings. Need to keep picture of real, ageing self in attic.

Prop or gimmick. Examples: Germaine Greer (cat), Tara Palmer-Tomkinson (beau du jour); John Walsh (full-length clad as Paris bohemian c. 1925); John Peel (horizontal full-length). Pro: Grabs attention. Con: "Poseur" charges hard to rebut.

Making friends. With arms around shoulders of celeb "pals", or entire staff of restaurant. Examples: Michael Winner, Garry Bushell, Piers Morgan (when on Sun). Pro: Conveys gregarious bonhomie, even if columnist really snobbish, misanthropic monster. Con: Might be thought to compromise journalistic objectivity. JD

Country's going to the dogs!" Chameleon. Appearing in utterly disparate guises in different outlets. Examples: Andrew Marr pre-BBC job (jovial in the Observer, but martyr to constipation in Express); Suzanne Moore (close to Medusa-like Guardian image in New Statesman, but mumsy figure in Mail on Sunday). Pro: Makes important statement about plural nature of self. Con: Relies riskily on lefty friends not seeing rightwing papers, or vice versa. Age cannot wither. When photo remains unchanged after 40th birthday. Examples: Geoffrey Wheatcroft, Fay Maschler. Pro: Risk of recognition - hence of horse-whipping by angry public sector workers (Wheatcroft) or chefs (Maschler) - reduced. Con: Could be arrested as impostor if using prestige of name for, eg, hotel bookings. Need to keep picture of real, ageing self in attic. Prop or gimmick. Examples: Germaine Greer (cat), Tara Palmer-Tomkinson (beau du jour); John Walsh (full-length clad as Paris bohemian c. 1925); John Peel (horizontal full-length). Pro: Grabs attention. Con: "Poseur" charges hard to rebut. Making friends. With arms around shoulders of celeb "pals", or entire staff of restaurant. Examples: Michael Winner, Garry Bushell, Piers Morgan (when on Sun). Pro: Conveys gregarious bonhomie, even if columnist really snobbish, misanthropic monster. Con: Might be thought to compromise journalistic objectivity. JD

fields.headline: Still full of beans
fields.standfirst: Forget the net. As far as Tony O'Reilly is concerned, the newspaper has a secure future - a belief he is backing up with hefty new investment in the Independent titles. Roy Greenslade on an astonishing act of faith
fields.trailText: Forget the net. As far as Tony O'Reilly is concerned, the newspaper has a secure future - a belief he is backing up with hefty new investment in the Independent titles. Roy Greenslade on an astonishing act of faith
fields.body:
Dot.com missionaries beware! What you are about to read is heresy. The counter-revolution is under way. Mucky "old media" is fighting back against the online upstarts and their predictions of a paperless world.

Leading the Charge of the Print Brigade is Tony O'Reilly's Independent News & Media (INM), which appears to have had second, and then third, thoughts about the commercial potential of new media.

When presenting their interim results last week, the company's senior executives were making it abundantly clear that it is time to bring a sense of proportion to internet mania.

Too much money has been wasted by too many companies on a hunch that people will eventually prefer to run their lives through their computers. Instead, after a gradual period of reassessment, INM has become convinced that newspapers have a great future. Turning on its head a bit of web jargon, papers therefore remain "the ultimate browser".

Senior INM executives are less starry-eyed about those once-fashionable claims that "the guy with the ponytail will steal our business". After a think-tank weekend in Deauville recently, it became clear that newspapers, rather than the net, are to get the company's greatest attention.

As in so many companies that spent millions on new media, its directors just can't see where the profits will come from. E-commerce has not taken off. Classified advertising hasn't vanished to the net.

Gavin O'Reilly, who runs the company's Irish interests, is fond of telling an anecdote about taking a break on the Shannon with a friend who asked him to buy an English paper he doesn't normally read. Idly scanning the pages, his eye was drawn to an obituary of a viscount who had had a fascinating life. O'Reilly had never heard of the man and realised that the chances of his ever having had the pleasure of reading such a piece on the paper's website would have been virtually nil.

It confirmed his growing view, one developing fast among others in the company who had, only a year ago, been convinced of the internet's primacy, that newspapers are far from dying. They are special and different and will be with us for as long as we can imagine. This philosophy now underlies much of INM's strategic thinking and will be given concrete expression in a couple of weeks' time when it announces a massive new investment in the paper that has cost it a fortune in the past three years: the Independent.

No one at the company is prepared to disclose exactly what form the injection of "millions" will make, but I would guess that it means the introduction of new sections at the very least, in both the daily and its stablemate, the Independent on Sunday. It proves once again that Tony O'Reilly, now executive chairman of INM, is as dedicated as ever to Britain's lowest selling national titles.

Since INM became the sole owner of the papers in 1997, having bought out Mirror group's portion after an unhappy joint ownership, it has spent £7m on the editorial side alone and, so far, has not had a penny back from the persistent loss-maker. Now, though, there appears to be a spring to O'Reilly's step, and that of his UK chief executive Brendan Hopkins. The last vestiges of their links to the Mirror are finally being severed as the Independent titles move out of the Canary Wharf tower to their own Docklands headquarters.

Hopkins predicts that, by next year, the titles will move into profit for the first time since those long-ago days in the late 80s when the paper was briefly fashionable. Well, he would say that, wouldn't he? But INM's six-monthly figures do appear to confirm his forecast. The UK operation, which combines the Independent titles with groups of smallish suburban papers in Greater London and Kent, managed to turn in a profit of some £100,000, a tiny return on a turnover of £51m, but a move in the right direction.

I understand that the move from the Wharf may well cut £5m from the bottom line, so it's easy to see why Hopkins is so confident. By the time the annual results are announced next spring, INM's UK arm will also be boosted by revenue from its most recent £300m purchase of the Belfast Telegraph group, a sale forced on Trinity-Mirror by the competition commission. In fact, a comparison between the current fortunes of Trinity-Mirror and INM shows how the balance has moved in the latter's favour. Before Philip Graf's regional outfit, Trinity, merged with the Mirror each of them was greater in size than INM. Now INM is larger than the merged Trinity-Mirror unit.

The reason, of course, is INM's global status. O'Reilly has built an international media company with a market capitalisation of £1.3bn, assets of £2bn and a turnover in excess of £1bn. It is the leading newspaper publisher in Ireland, South Africa and New Zealand, the leading regional publisher in Australia and even has a large interest in two of the top three papers in Portugal. It is also an important radio broadcaster in most of those countries and, in Ireland, could be on the verge of the big time with its cable operation.

Its Irish newspapers will be printed from November on new presses in a £40m state-of-the-art printing plant on the outskirts of Dublin. It will run with almost half the former staffing in the old works after a lengthy and complex negotiation with the unions that culminated in a voluntary redundancy agreement.

O'Reilly scorned the idea of "doing a Wapping" in Dublin to achieve staff cuts. "He has known those guys in the press hall for years," said an executive who would have preferred a swifter resolution in the Murdoch mould. "He just wouldn't countenance confrontation."

Before we get too carried away with the O'Reilly phenomenon, and all those mind-boggling figures with their endless noughts and double-digit earnings growth, let's come back to earth in Britain for a moment.

There is little doubt that INM has the capacity to have withstood losses at the Independent titles, and could do so again. It's heartening for its journalists, many of whom have gloomily watched the papers career from crisis to crisis in the past decade, to know O'Reilly is in for the long game.

But is the Independent really viable? It was noticeable that after last week's INM press conference even the Financial Times, which is surely supposed to scrutinise company claims, reported that the Independent titles are "enjoying improved circulation".

With respect, that gives a whole new meaning to the word "improvement". Here are the facts: the Independent in August last year sold 222,200 copies. This August it sold 223,608. So it improved by 1,408, less than 1%. Similarly, the Independent on Sunday managed to improve by just 1,844 copies, also less than 1% over the 12 months.

But that isn't the end of the story. In August last year, the Independent's total included bulk sales - those giveaways that are so helpful when massaging statistics - of 32,168. This year the bulks were 33,765, a rise of 1,597 copies. In other words, in real terms, the Independent sales haven't improved at all.

When we turn to the Independent on Sunday (Sindy), the truth is even more stark, the polar opposite of claims of improved circulation. In August last year the Sindy reported bulk sales of 21,805. This August, bulks had risen to 36,288. So its real sale, the bit that can't be boosted by shoving out more quires to an airport lounge, has gone down by a considerable amount - about 7% over the year.

Okay, so I've caught INM out. I could probably have done the same to the Guardian and the Observer, but they aren't boasting to City analysts about improved sales. INM is hardly the first newspaper company to put a gloss on sales figures and, credit where credit is due, under editor-in-chief Simon Kelner the titles have performed much better than in the past. There is a greater coherence about them and some of the writers, such as Donald MacIntyre, David Aaronovitch and John Walsh, command attention.

Clearly, INM knows the true situation, and that hasn't inhibited its decision to plough back yet more into the papers. Despite the sales figures, the latest readership statistics from NRS offer a sunnier view. The Independent is reported to have attracted 15% more people in the 15-44 age bracket while both the Times and Daily Telegraph have suffered losses - of 13% and 24% respectively.

Kelner also points to another ray of sunshine: "Our market share of full-rate sales is growing and has done so for the past seven months."

That's fine. But the Independent's difficulty in winning sales reminds us that all papers are finding the market very tough indeed just now. So INM's corporate decision to throw its weight behind newspapers at this time is an astonishing act of faith.

fields.headline: Reading the runes
fields.standfirst: Roy Greenslade  on this month's newspaper sales figures
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade on this month's newspaper sales figures
fields.body:
Why, someone asked recently, does the circulation chart make the major comparison of the latest month's sales with those of the previous month? Rationally, he pointed out that it isn't anything like as relevant as comparing the month this year with the same month the previous year. With monthly fluctuations due, for example, to holiday periods, the start of the football season, and the occasional five-week month followed by a four-weeker, it's difficult to get a full and broad picture.

I regularly make the year-on-year comparisons within my articles, so why not publish the full set of figures? Well, one important reason is that the current way of presenting figures does help to show rapid ups and downs. Even taking into account the specific reasons listed above, it provides the most up-to-date picture.

Similarly, in making year-on-year comparisons, as editors inevitably point out to me, it is easy to overlook the fact that 12 months ago a particular paper had a promotion which boosted its sales - and perhaps depressed those of its rivals - which hasn't been repeated. So, once again, apples haven't been compared to apples. Needless to say, editors tend to latch on to any positive twist, no matter how arcane, to suggest that their circulation is better than before, using the previous month, the month last year, the six-monthly figures, market share, the full-rate sale and so on.

I just wish there was room to put in all sorts of figures, especially those controversial bulk and foreign sales, along with the hundreds of thousands of subscription and discounted copies. Anyway, having said all that, I have come round to the idea of changing the chart to the year-on-year sale, putting up with complaints that I seem to have forgotten that paper X ran a win-a-house competition last time around. So, from next month, the chart will change.

Meanwhile, back to this month's sales. Among the tabloids, the Sun enjoyed a very good August, due to the clever juxtaposition of its millionaire contest, its cleavage froth and the start of the football season. For the moment at least, the Sun and Daily Star appear to have halted the Mirror's revival in its tracks. Among the broadsheets, whose readers generally spend most of their Augusts abroad, it was a flat month. Except, of course, north of the border where the Scotsman leapt back over 100,000. Whatever critics say about publisher Andrew Neil and editor Rebecca Hardy - and they do make an awful lot of unflattering remarks about them - they have fulfilled their sales boasts.

Yes, the paper is cheap at 20p. But it looks as though the company is committed to maintaining it at that price and the opposition would do well to contemplate what happened when the Times more than doubled its sale after price-cutting. Rivals tended to do too little too late. If the Glasgow-based Herald is going to compete, it has to prevent the Scotsman's new readers from building the habit of buying its old competitor.

Turning to the Sunday titles, it is clear that the News of the World's name-and-shame campaign has done its sale no harm. It enjoyed a better August than last year, while its main rivals, the Sunday Mirror and the People, recorded year-on-year losses.

fields.headline: Picture power
fields.standfirst: Why are papers suddenly teeming with journalists' faces?  John Dugdale  traces the strange 30-year history of the press's cult of personality
fields.trailText: Why are papers suddenly teeming with journalists' faces? John Dugdale traces the strange 30-year history of the press's cult of personality
fields.body:
This morning the Daily Telegraph opens a new front in its ferocious sales war with the cut-price Times, introducing a redesign described to Press Gazette as the final "topping out" of a five-year revamp. In declaring that "the masthead will remain as it is", however, the trade weekly overlooked a symbolically important change: the Telegraph's "flannel panel" - photos and 'trails' promoting the attractions inside the paper - will now appear above, not below, the words "The Daily Telegraph" and space has been freed for extra faces alongside the title. This differentiates it sharply from the Times, although both papers already put their flannel panel above the title on Saturdays.

How did we reach the point where moving a flannel panel, not acquiring new writers, is at the centre of a quality paper's autumn offensive? And how did the broadsheets, once so hostile to the cult of personality, come to outstrip the tabloids in their enthusiasm for hacks' faces?

Thirty years ago, after all, things were very different. Tabloids then readily used picture bylines (henceforward 'pb's), but observed strict rules, only dishing them out to star writers or other reader magnets: chief political commentator, obligatory humorist, chief sportswriter, female figurehead - Marje Proops, Jean Rook, Lynda Lee-Potter - and maybe the astrologer. Broadsheets, whose pages then consisted of almost unbroken text, expressed their seriousness by keeping their named contributors as faceless as leader writers. If egos or inter-paper rivalry required a pb, caricatures were preferred to photos.

These rules began to change in the first half of the 1980s, when the tabloids, led by the Sun, sought to use grinning mugshots to manufacture personalities rather than just reward Fleet Street's accepted aristocracy with stand-out status on the page commensurate with their salaries.Part of the same pattern was an increase in stories in which tabloid journalists become leading characters instead of invisible observers - when "our Sally" tried out a diet or tested the impact of a new bra on men in the street, while "our Kevin" described his problems in getting a plumber. Hence many more hacks were now photographed, but the implicit message of these photographs was still the same: "this paper is written by people who look - and think - just like you".

The broadsheets, meanwhile, sniffily set about making grudging accommodations with this mystifying fascination with journalists' looks, although the two cultures still remained firmly separate. By the early 80s, for instance, columnists Hugo Young, Peter Jenkins and Polly Toynbee were deemed worthy of depiction in the Guardian - albeit via what seemed to be crude photocopies of their photos.

After 1986, however, the Wapping revolution set in train forces - the widespread adoption of new technology and multi-section papers - which overturned the pre-existing tabloid/ broadsheet relationship. By the early 90s, the proliferation of extra sections made broadsheets just as likely to show contributors' faces: often tabloid anyway, these sections were free to make up their own rules, and far more likely to be filled with mugshots than the main news section. And because the overall pagination of broadsheets was much larger, some eventually overhauled tabloids in number of pbs. Until very recently, whether these faces were attractive mattered little. Tabloids wanted their hacks to look ordinary, broadsheets wanted theirs to look thoughtful. But the emergence of flannel panels put an end to such nonchalance.

To compete with other papers on news-stands where rival panels can be compared demanded at least two alluring faces per day, preferably smiling - and the presence of models, actors or attractive media and sports stars can not always be justified. Often journalists had to become the front-page lure, such as the Times's finance expert Anne Ashworth or the Independent's sports columnist Gabby Yorath. Escalating this battle of the beauties, the Telegraph now slyly resorts to using photos of mod els on its panels to trail articles penned by women who presumably don't meet its aesthetic criteria .

The rise of the flannel panel - driven by the broadsheets, as the tabloids lack the necessary free space around their mastheads - has made papers generally more looks-conscious, with countless journalists undergoing makeovers which make them look fun-loving rather than frowning and forbidding. The Telegraph expensively re-photographed all its regular contributors, enabling some apparently to shed 20 years .

The message of all these faces is quite different from that of the tabloid pbs of the 70s. They say: "Look how many smiley, young, glamorous people we've got writing for us, as well as the middle-aged blokes you know about! Some you will fancy; others will mirror your own amused, bemused or irate perspective on the world."

So the 2000s have begun with the media which once cherished the invisibility of their contributors - newspapers and radio - eagerly displaying their faces so that they become as recognisable as TV reporters. And meanwhile television is increasingly sucking in print journalists. It's as if old media are huddling closer together for comfort, terrified of the internet, the medium of the new century which threatens to engulf them.

But, perhaps because it was originally created by nerds, the culture of the internet allows the authors of texts (whether emails or contributions to websites) to enjoy invisibility. Like the quality press before the multi-section and flannel panel revolutions, webzines happily let lengthy articles unfurl without feeling any need to put a mugshot at the top of them.

Ironically, in its preference for leaving writers faceless, the information medium of the future returns full circle to the broadsheet ethos of the 1970s. Journalism may once again become showbusiness for ugly people.
