After 1986, however, the Wapping revolution set in train forces - the widespread adoption of new technology and multi-section papers - which overturned the pre-existing tabloid/ broadsheet relationship. By the early 90s, the proliferation of extra sections made broadsheets just as likely to show contributors' faces: often tabloid anyway, these sections were free to make up their own rules, and far more likely to be filled with mugshots than the main news section. And because the overall pagination of broadsheets was much larger, some eventually overhauled tabloids in number of pbs. Until very recently, whether these faces were attractive mattered little. Tabloids wanted their hacks to look ordinary, broadsheets wanted theirs to look thoughtful. But the emergence of flannel panels put an end to such nonchalance. To compete with other papers on news-stands where rival panels can be compared demanded at least two alluring faces per day, preferably smiling - and the presence of models, actors or attractive media and sports stars can not always be justified. Often journalists had to become the front-page lure, such as the Times's finance expert Anne Ashworth or the Independent's sports columnist Gabby Yorath. Escalating this battle of the beauties, the Telegraph now slyly resorts to using photos of mod els on its panels to trail articles penned by women who presumably don't meet its aesthetic criteria . The rise of the flannel panel - driven by the broadsheets, as the tabloids lack the necessary free space around their mastheads - has made papers generally more looks-conscious, with countless journalists undergoing makeovers which make them look fun-loving rather than frowning and forbidding. The Telegraph expensively re-photographed all its regular contributors, enabling some apparently to shed 20 years . The message of all these faces is quite different from that of the tabloid pbs of the 70s. They say: "Look how many smiley, young, glamorous people we've got writing for us, as well as the middle-aged blokes you know about! Some you will fancy; others will mirror your own amused, bemused or irate perspective on the world." So the 2000s have begun with the media which once cherished the invisibility of their contributors - newspapers and radio - eagerly displaying their faces so that they become as recognisable as TV reporters. And meanwhile television is increasingly sucking in print journalists. It's as if old media are huddling closer together for comfort, terrified of the internet, the medium of the new century which threatens to engulf them. But, perhaps because it was originally created by nerds, the culture of the internet allows the authors of texts (whether emails or contributions to websites) to enjoy invisibility. Like the quality press before the multi-section and flannel panel revolutions, webzines happily let lengthy articles unfurl without feeling any need to put a mugshot at the top of them. Ironically, in its preference for leaving writers faceless, the information medium of the future returns full circle to the broadsheet ethos of the 1970s. Journalism may once again become showbusiness for ugly people.

fields.headline: Media Diary
fields.standfirst: This week's media diary is guest edited by the Media Monkey, diarist at our newly-launched sister website MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: This week's media diary is guest edited by the Media Monkey, diarist at our newly-launched sister website MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.body:
The Media Monkey recorded last week that all Haymarket staff were emailed an urgent missive from one of head honcho Michael Heseltine's minions: "Haymarket has a quantity of Michael Heseltine's book, Life in the Jungle, published today, at the special price of £10," it read. Sceptics that we are in the media bunker, we doubted the lines would be jammed. But no, on Friday we were proved wrong by a touching follow-up from the great man. Apparently the response was so terrific that Hezza has promised to sign every one personally. "His generosity exceeds our wildest expectations," said a Haymarket source.

Andrew Neil, speaking at the recent People and Profits in the New Economy conference: "If you have trouble with recruitment and retention, then your company sucks." Could that possibly be the same Andrew Neil who has recently had quite a lot of trouble with staff retention at the Scotsman? Your words, Andrew.

Word that retiring Labour MP St Mo of Mowlam is considering a TV career has got the Media Monkey flicking through its contacts book in search of old broadcasting muckers who may be able to help her out. The first call will undoubtedly be to the ITV Network Centre, where they are still a chief executive short of a full ITV council. St Mo would be the ideal candidate - after all, she has plenty of experience of a job where people are always knifing you in the back. But Media Monkey would welcome any other suggestions.

Does the low cunning of the BSkyB marketing department know no bounds? Imagine little Johnnie and Jemima's delight when, after a spot of bulletin reading courtesy of Sky News during their visit to the Millennium Dome, they are given a videotape of the performance to take home and treasure. But picture their disappointment when, on getting home and watching the video, they have to sit through several minutes of trailers for Sky TV services before glimpsing their brief moment of fame. How fiendishly clever.

Lots of hot air is being generated over BBC Worldwide's advanced launch plans for a new celebrity teenage magazine this autumn, linked to a relaunched Live & Kicking on Saturday mornings. However, astute publishers are taking comfort from the fact that sales of Worldwide's new glossy for mature women, Eve, which had its debut in August, are described euphemistically within the trade as "soft". If you listen carefully you can hear the ripples of relief from quarters ranging from Emap's Red to NatMags' She.

It's official: advertising agency names are getting sillier. First there was Mother in London - the trendy, Clerkenwell-based agency that looks after Harvey Nichols and Hoegaarden Beer. Then the disgraced political lobbyist Derek Draper launched an ad agency and mysteriously decided to call it Farm. Now Swiss banking giant Credit Suisse - a company that's surely old enough to know better - has appointed an agency called Strawberry Frog to handle its ads. It makes you long for the good old days, when adland was full of egotists who called their agencies after themselves, and had done with it.

Far be it from us to suggest that anyone in advertising takes the whole business of making ads too seriously. But the reaction of Heineken international marketing manager Frazer Thompson to the French ban on alcohol ads may have been a little extreme. "In France the world has gone dark," said a grief-stricken Thompson. Do get a grip.

News that Channel 4 is planning to bring out a Big Brother jigsaw in time for Christmas has inspired the Media Monkey to ponder what other sensational TV tie-ins broadcasters may have up their sleeves. We'll start the ball rolling with the mouth-watering prospect of Channel 4 linking up with Armitage Shanks and Triton to bring out Big Brother-branded toilets and showers with built-in CCTV cameras.

"Living In Scotland Now" seems a very suitable cover slogan for Caledonia, a glossy for posh Scots which claims to outsell Tatler amongst Edinburgh "Yahs" and Highland Fionas. But maybe not if your September cover star lives on Merseyside: "Driving through Southport is a sombre experience," opens the profile. "Yet one man is happy to have made this place his home - perhaps the best centre-half Scotland ever produced: Alan Hansen." How about: "Not Living In Scotland Any Longer"?

A final thought from the Monkey's ceaseless tours of media launch parties (motto: we drink so you don't have to). Monkey was delighted to note at the do for new women's mag Bare that the previous daggers-drawn hostilities in the world of female publishing must have ceased. For, and surely this must have been in tribute to its honoured rival, the drinks being served were Cosmopolitans.

fields.headline: The battle for Britain
fields.standfirst: Last week, ITV recorded its lowest-ever audience share and was declared 'in terminal decline'.  Maggie Brown asks network boss David Liddiment, is the channel in crisis?
fields.trailText: Last week, ITV recorded its lowest-ever audience share and was declared 'in terminal decline'. Maggie Brown asks network boss David Liddiment, is the channel in crisis?
fields.body:
In his quiet, intense voice, David Liddiment, ITV Network programme director, says: "Our performance is not as good as I would have liked. But there are still four months of the year left. It's not over yet. This is a very important season."

Though the plight of his rival Peter Salmon, controller of BBC1, is grabbing headlines, ITV is in difficulty too. Each network targets the mass market. They study each other's schedules like hawks. Both are having an annus horribilis as pay television relentlessly gains share and competition from all quarters increases.

So, when Merrill Lynch weighed in with a report last week, saying that poor viewing figures and lacklustre advertising revenue could trigger ITV's terminal decline - a verdict underpinned by the news that the previous week had seen the network record its lowest share ever (25.7%) - it set nerves jangling. And especially since BBC1 may be about to bounce up from the floor with a massive spending boost.

"We are concerned; we want a healthy commercial television sector, and that is difficult if the brand leader isn't healthy," says Nick Phillips, director general of the ad agencies' trade body, the IPA. He has put out feelers, asking ITV's top executives from Granada Media's Charles Allen downwards to attend a summit with top agencies and media buyers later this month.

The call for dialogue comes because the ITV Network is still without a chief executive, despite a sky-high salary on offer of £500,000 a year. A key issue is that ITV has missed its peak time (7pm-10.30pm) audience targets of 38.5%, set with advertiser approval. The running total of peak time share over eight months is 36.7%, and the trend in August was down again (34.7%), worse than July. The targets were dreamt up three years ago by former chief executive "Saint" Richard Eyre to break a mindset resigned to inexorable decline. But could such aspirations be a thing of the past?

Zenith Media, key power brokers because they buy slots for big advertisers, are now predicting that specific targets will be abandoned after December, to end ITV's embarrassment. Instead, only the gap which ITV still maintains over BBC1 in peaktime will be publicised.

This is not academic. The move of BBC1 news to 10pm, freeing up the network to compete head-to-head with ITV at 9 pm for the first time in 30 years, is putting the fear of God into the sector. Some think that BBC1 might even put on audience share. "We want that gap of superiority over BBC1," says Phillips. "We want to hack chunks out of BBC1," says Bob Wootton, director of media and advertising affairs at the advertisers' association ISBA. "If Dyke reflates BBC1, then it will be a major headache, a migraine for ITV. Dyke has the autonomous power to move money and the schedule around."

So, is ITV abandoning targets? "That's hugely premature," says Liddiment. "We've had no conversations internally about that. You've got to go back, to remember why they were first set in place. ITV was serious about taking hold of things, squeezing the maximum performance from the channel." Liddiment, at heart an innovative programme-maker, also faces a more wounding criticism. The view is ingrained that ratings slippage has led ITV to eschew risks and leave others to innovate in the autumn schedule, so reflecting the decline in morale and self confidence critics identify. Big Brother is a sensation - but on Channel 4. BBC1 was first to revive daytime soaps, with Doctors. ITV is responding with Emmerdale stripped five nights a week, and Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? every week this autumn.

Liddiment points to these and Fat Friends, Kay Mellor's drama about a slimming club, as bold strokes, when asked if he's playing safe. "I don't think so. But we're operating a big, popular channel, aiming for huge audiences, and at all times we have to balance the level of risks we take. "When the risks don't take off the downside is . . ." he trails off, perhaps remembering his doomed high profile failure to revive the sitcom with Carsey-Werner's Days Like These. Nick Elliott, ITV's controller of drama, confirms the policy is for longer US-style runs of series that work - Peak Practice, Where the Heart Is, The Bill - broken up by occasional specials and two-parters. All different from three years ago.

At a Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival session where advertisers listed programmes from heaven and hell, ITV had the largest clutch of downwardly-mobile offerings, with persistent mentions of stalwarts such as London's Burning and Blind Date joining the more predictable Wheel of Fortune, You've Been Framed, Tonight at the London Palladium and Police, Camera, Action in the hell category. "Like the English diet of the 17th century, all meat and bread, meat and potatoes, never a green in sight," sighs Wootton.

Liddiment is also fixing ITV's daytime schedule, another area of poor performance (arguably due to the emphasis on peak) and now shorn of Home & Away, poached by Channel 5. The uninviting mix of Minder repeats and Jerry Springer, dubbed as "thin workhouse gruel" by adland critics, will be replaced by the resuscitated Crossroads, with repeats of the new teatime soap Trafalgar Road. As for the big investment planned for BBC1, Liddiment notes calmly: "It's a factor you have to take into account," while adding that ITV has been investing well ahead of inflation for some years now. Behind the scenes pressure is growing for ITV's two big owners, especially Granada, to plough back the savings from merger into a matching investment in programme content, even though that will mean smaller dividends for shareholders.

Some of the advertisers who lobbied so hard for moving News at Ten now say sheepishly they had assumed a 9pm news on BBC1 was immovable. Compounded with all this is the unsexy but very real corrosive influence of multi-channel television and specifically Sky Digital, a platform ITV has refused to join since its launch two years ago. Under chief executive Tony Ball, Sky is at its most aggressive, last week making five-year supply pacts with NTL, its largest cable rival, while simultaneously promising to market its own enhanced video recorders.

Zenith's influential quarterly report, Zenith On TV, is headed by a telling foreword by an advertiser - Mike Moran, commercial director of Toyota - who describes his (digital) household viewing during a 10-day summer break: "In the multi-media paradise that is Moran Towers, neither the kids nor my wife nor I once felt the urge to switch from widescreen into 'TV from the heart', ITV never registering.

"With the biggest claimed budget of a single channel across Europe, what has gone wrong with their schedule, programme content, and marketing and promotion that led to a situation where family Moran had dialled out of ITV consciousness?"

Charles Allen's view, expressed at Edinburgh, that by 2003 ITV would be broadcasting on digital satellite, has gone down badly. In August, ITV's share in Sky Digital homes fell again, to 15.9% (compared with 17.7% in July), worse for a second month than BBC1 (17% in August), which is on digital satellite. ITV says the cost of having to rent 23 transponders to fulfil its regional commitments, rather than one like everyone else, is too high, and that the Independent Television Commission (ITC) is taking a hard line. Yet BBC1, Channel 4 and Channel 5 make do with one transponder, and BBC1 puts out News 24 in the 6.30pm regional news slot. ITN News has managed to buy into digital satellite without a problem. With digital gaining further momentum, waiting seems risky.

Yet there are hopeful signs too. The consolidation of ITV into two big shareholders, as Liddiment says, "has happened as painlessly as possible." And with the ITC prepared to talk to settle the News at Ten dispute, a period of neglect may be ending as Granada cracks the whip. Further, the Network Centre team broadly commands respect, with Elliott rated the most successful and consistent drama controller of any channel.

The crucial commercial issue is whether advertisers can do without ITV and switch ads to other channels. The answer remains no, or at least not yet. "The great point about ITV is that it rapidly reaches most people," says Nick Phillips of the IPA. Advertisers are still paying a premium for its airtime. This is expressed as the cost per thousand adults. ITV's price is £7.65 per thousand, Zenith points out, compared with Channel 4's £7.06 and and the average which fluctuates below £7.

So its condition is troubling, but not grave. But defending a role as the biggest, most resourced commercial network pulling the largest audiences is becoming harder and harder to pull off.

fields.trailText: Revealed - the shortlist for the Guardian Student Media Awards
fields.body:
Entries for the 22nd Guardian Student Media Awards were last week whittled down to a shortlist by a panel of judges including Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian. This year's winners, to be announced at an awards ceremony following the student media conference later this year, will receive cash, European flights courtesy of Go, and work experience on the relevant desk at the Guardian.

fields.headline: OK, the cameras are ready, start the race
fields.standfirst: Tony Moss  explains how television bought up the Olympics
fields.trailText: Tony Moss explains how television bought up the Olympics
fields.body:
NBC will break all the records when it comes to the Sydney Olympics. The biggest, the longest, the most expensive coverage in history . . . The statistics trip off the corporate tongue as only Americans know how. Yes, they're promising more than 3,000 staff broadcasting a record 441 hours to an estimated 230m American viewers. And yet not one second of the games will be shown live on TV.

Nothing to do with time zone differences, the apparent explanation is that neither their viewers nor their advertisers want to watch everything as it happens.

This may seem remarkable given that NBC has paid £1,000m (another record of course) for the rights to Sydney and the 2000 Winter games, effectively bankrolling the entire Olympics organisation.

However, the broadcasting giant is confident of its games plan. Chairman of NBC Sports, Dick Ebersol, says that the network made a major error during the Atlanta Games in 1996 when it mixed live and pre-recorded elements, leaving viewers dazed and confused about what was going on. Similar complaints bedevilled CBS's coverage of the Nagano Winter games.

The overwhelming complaint from journalists, athletes and tourists at Atlanta, however, was that NBC abandoned its live coverage when there were no home competitors in with a medal chance and instead showed taped packages of US triumphs. For the Sydney 2000 games, American viewers may be spared the sight of foreigners winning anything.

But for NBC it's not really about winning or losing at all: "The majority of people who tune into the Olympics come to watch the stories, not the results," Ebersol claims.

At a crucial three-day gathering of 350 key staff in Salt Lake City over the summer producers and reporters were instructed on how to capture viewers' hearts and minds by focusing on the human dimension. One example shown looked at Australian swimming star Ian Thorpe's relationship with a 13-year-old who has cancer.

But it is a road fraught with danger. Another clip showed a woman runner falling down with the commentator speculating that she had obviously burst an ovarian cyst. Not quite what NBC has in mind.

Nevertheless female concerns are a big issue. Or as Ebersol puts it: "There's a different audience for the Olympics [which is] one of the last real family event shows in our country. "You can't do it with straight sports reporting. Every time it's been done that way, it's failed"

What NBC would really like is more of the sports that their viewers like to watch. Back in 1994, senior executive Peter Diamond, a member of the International Olympic Committee's television commission, admitted: "I'd like the IOC to find a way to have another day, or two, or three of artistic gymnastics." He was also keen on more swimming, figure skating and other events with bodily appeal.

Since signing an unprecedented, five-Olympics deal with NBC for the exclusive US rights back in 1995, the IOC has seen fit to introduce synchronised swimming and beach volleyball as official events. Wet T-shirt contests can only be a matter of time.

One event that American viewers love - and in fact the only one that is being shown "as live" on TV (four hours later at 8pm primetime) - is the opening ceremony. Drama, breath-taking beauty and entertainment and all designed for television - and that's just the opening shot.

When broadcasters from around the world first converged on the spectacular site for the 2000 games they were unanimous that the views would provide them with the shots of a lifetime. But NBC's Ebersol thought Sydney could do better.

He envisaged an opening shot which could frame the Harbour bridge and the stunning skyline of north Sydney while effortlessly tilting through to the lip of the roof of the stadium itself (the biggest in Olympic history, need I say it?) and down into the flaming cauldron.

A broadcasting tower the height of the stadium itself was quickly agreed to, but more problematic was Ebersol's request that all the city's power lines "blocking" the view should be pulled down and re-routed.

Eventually, after great controversy, Australia's Olympics minister Michael Knight made the reputedly $7m decision to acquiesce to what the press dubbed "Dick's vision"- and the taxpayers are still footing the bill.

It is a perfect illustration of the power and influence of NBC over the Olympics movement. So much so that Ebersol, a personal friend of Juan Antonio Samaranch, IOC President since the 70s, acts as if he were an official spokesman of the Olympics rather than a representative of one local broadcaster.

Ebersol arrived in Sydney last week on the first of 28 specially-chartered NBC 747s, mostly reserved for advertisers, to deliver a presidential-style speech praising the work of local Olympic organisers while attacking the Australian media. "Almost everything I can think of about these games has been perfect except for the PR, and 90% of that I rack up to the bizarre nature of your tabloid press," he said.

In this he was perfectly echoing the views of Samaranch who has always been concerned about the Australian media's refusal to ignore the stories that have haunted the IOC in recent years. Facing a grilling from a British journalist at a press conference in Lausanne, Samaranch typically brazened it out, until finally snapping: "Are you from Australia?"

Indeed Sydney's organising committee has found it tough to work in the gaze of a free and independent press - making every decision from the siting of the stadium (on a disused abattoir) to the price of the meat pies inside it a source of continuous discussion, dispute and ridicule.

Attempts to make the city fit for the world's media have been tracked and exposed at every turn. While Atlanta got away with bussing out the city's homeless well in advance, Sydney's more subtle decision to floodlight many of the areas where the city's homeless regularly sleep has been widely publicised.

And most of all, the media has been preoccupied with what will happen at the opening ceremony - after the cameras have panned through outer space, and the Statue of Liberty, that is.

After months of secrecy, rumour and the odd leak, little has been revealed, except that Olivia Newton John will return from two decades of Californian exile to sing. The press reaction has not been encouraging. Presumably NBC is happy to have one of their own presiding.

Ever since the much-maligned announcement that there would be three official mascots, Sydney's organisers appear tormented by the desire to please and appease every section of the community - from the city's hip and exotic crowd to the rural backwaters and the aboriginal community.

And the final piece in this chaotic jigsaw appeared with the announcement a fortnight ago that the closing ceremony would feature a Mardi Gras-style drag queen display. So, that's the gay and lesbian community sorted.

Amid the outcry from the outback, there were reports that American affiliates and advertisers were demanding the scenes be excised from their TV screens. (Presumably to make way for highlights of US gold medal triumphs).

But Olympic officials were quick-ish to explain. By the following day the drag queens had become a homage to the film Priscilla Queen of the Desert as the entire closing ceremony was to be a celebration of great (sic) Australian movies from Crocodile Dundee to Babe.

I guess to be fair, though, the final word must go to NBC: the ultimate compliment to the host city. "You've built all the facilities magnificently, you got them there early, you've tested them and Sydney will get more coverage than any other off-shore Olympic city," says Ebersol. Let the cameras roll.

fields.headline: I don't like to talk about it
fields.standfirst: Advertising agencies love to do a bit for charity - but does it work? The Big Issue is certainly hoping its latest campaign will do the job and Saatchi & Saatchi is so proud of its own work with worthy causes that it's published a book.
fields.trailText: Advertising agencies love to do a bit for charity - but does it work? The Big Issue is certainly hoping its latest campaign will do the job and Saatchi & Saatchi is so proud of its own work with worthy causes that it's published a book. Emma Hall reports.
fields.body:
Ever since Smashy and Nicey spelt it out for us, doing "a lot of work for charidy" has been universally interpreted as a ruse by the overpaid and over-the-hill to turn around a tarnished public image.

So when two well-heeled advertising agencies announce new charity initiatives in the same week, the cynics are bound to go into overdrive.

TBWA, wearing its conscience on its sleeve, has created a bold new campaign for the Big Issue. And to pay for the media space, it has arranged a soiree at the Science Museum with guest speakers Mo Mowlam and Big Issue founder John Bird.

The agency is inviting around 50 of its bigger clients to the evening and in return will ask them to donate a double-page spread from their own media schedules to the Big Issue's cause.

Saatchi & Saatchi, meanwhile, has just launched a big, glossy coffee table book called Social Work - Saatchi & Saatchi's Cause-Related Ideas. They seem to have forgotten the second half of Smashy and Nicey's line: "I do a lot of work for charidy but I don't like to talk about it". A 300-page book outlining their good deeds smacks of bragging.

But advertising executives are an all too easy target. Ed Jones, who compiled the Saatchi book, says: "People think we're all sabre-toothed tigers and it's not true. But it wouldn't even matter if it was true - as long as the good causes benefit. The book shows that advertising can be a force for good in the world; it's often presented as an evil activity."

The good causes represented in the book include Greenpeace, the NSPCC, the Commission for Racial Equality, the Gun Control Network and Partnership for a Drug-Free America. And, despite its self-congratulatory tone, the work on show is some of the most creative, thought-provoking and memorable advertising of the past 30 years.

Who can forget the "pregnant man" poster or, more recently, the NSPCC "full stop" campaign? Whatever the adman's motives, people take notice and the good causes benefit.

Barnardo's latest campaign - the one where a baby injects heroin - provoked outrage and brought almost as much media attention to Bartle Bogle Hegarty as it did to the charity. But Barnardo's head of advertising Suzanne Heaney doesn't mind one bit. "We don't feel used," she says, "because it all works in our favour."

The cynical people tend to be the young creatives who want to make a name for themselves. They pick on a charity, make a shocking ad on spec and then persuade said charity to run the ad. The next step is for the team to place the ad in some obscure 4am television slot and - hey presto - they win an award. In adland, one decent award can double an already fat salary, and a creative team can make a whole career on the back of it.

Saatchi's book contains an ad for that well-known "good cause," Islington council. It shows a man emerging from his front door first thing in the morning, clad only in his pyjamas. He pulls his pants down, squats on the pavement and after much straining, deposits the fruit of his labours right on his own doorstep. A businessman walks past on his way to work and - surprise, surprise - slips on the mess.

The line is: "You wouldn't. Don't let your dog", and it won awards for the team that created it. There is not so much a social conscience at work here as a childish sense of humour and a hunger for recognition.

Charity clients, however, are getting wise to these tactics. Most now employ sophisticated career marketers who want to know that an ad will fit with their brand image before they approve it. Even if an agency is offering its services for free, the client won't just roll over and be grateful.

Johnny Hornby of TBWA says that he will only consider the Big Issue campaign a success if the agency succeeds in getting plenty of free media space from its clients. "I like doing ads that run rather than ads that win awards," he says.

But let's face it, Johnny Hornby is never going to be homeless. As he's the thirtysomething joint managing director of one of London's top advertising agencies, the size of his pay packet could stand up to comparison with the most affluent of his generation.

To be fair, Hornby is not pretending that TBWA has anything more to offer than advertising skills. He is no bleeding heart: "It's good for agency morale when we all pull together to do something that makes a difference," he says. "They are nice ads. We're just doing what we do anyway. And it's more interesting than toothpaste."

Lucie Russell, the Big Issue Foundation's chief executive, says: "Obviously we're good for their corporate CV and they always mention that we're a client in their quarterly reports. If they get press out of the new campaign then it's fine by us. We don't pay them and no one is completely altruistic. But TBWA seems genuinely to want to help us."

On a recent away day, TBWA's 280 staff were given the opportunity to vote on how to spend the £20,000 that management had put aside for a project to "make a difference to the agency". The winning idea was another day away from work, but this time they would spend the day refurbishing a hostel for the homeless.

TBWA's clients include NatWest Bank, Rupert Murdoch's News International and Marlboro cigarettes. Saatchi & Saatchi makes ads for Hewlett-Packard, Sony and Toyota. As long as these corporate giants continue to spend millions on advertising, their agencies will be able to find the time and resources to assuage their consciences through service to good causes.

But there's no need to feel concern for the big clients who fund the saintly impulses of the advertising community. Russell has more of a problem with these "corporate monsters" than she does with advertising agencies. "We are constantly disappointed by the big companies. They always want to know what's in it for them and where their name will appear," she says.

The agencies, of course, already know what's in it for them.

fields.headline: My new media
fields.standfirst: Brent Hoberman
fields.trailText: Favourite sites? Probably Moreover.com, CNN.com and lastminute.com. Who else do I really go for? Orange.co.uk. I'm a subscriber, I always see what new features they're adding from there.
fields.body:
Favourite sites? Probably Moreover.com, CNN.com and lastminute.com. Who else do I really go for? Orange.co.uk. I'm a subscriber, I always see what new features they're adding from there.

Last online purchase? A hotel room in Amsterdam, through lastminute.com obviously.

Most recent technological faux pas? On another website, when I was ordering something to be delivered to my father in New York overnight. It was a major American site and it wasn't clear which was the recipient's address and which was the billing address. I realised my mistake at the end and corrected it. We don't yet deliver overnight but the Americans do.

Main news sources on web? BBC.co.uk, I'm afraid. I use loads of them. The standard.com, which is the industry standard, even Revolution (revolution.haynet.com) and New Media Age (nma.co.uk). I also use news.com and tornado- insider.com, another industry one.

Most persistent spam emailer? The spam ones I filter off.

Time spent on web? Practically all day. Web and email basically.

Next boo.com/clickmango? I couldn't possibly name one. But I guess it would be a site that is approaching too narrow a market, whose business isn't using the power of the internet enough and who has strong competitors already established in its space.

Least useful site/s on web? I'd say probably some of those offline retailers - the bricks and mortars guys - that just put up a catalogue. They're just wasting an opportunity.

Least user-friendly sites? A lot of those personal finance sites are over complicated and you need to fill in endless pages of forms before you can start using the site properly. I would rather see them get little bits of personalisation at each stage.

What screensaver do you use? I've got a second-hand computer from a Cape Town colleague with a picture of Table Mountain on it. Since I'm from there as well, I kept it.

Most irritating thing about the web? People who can't see how much the internet has improved over the past few years and then how much it's going to improve dramatically over the next few years.

Do you bother with old media? Yes, but less and less. I think newspapers will still be useful until we get amazing screens and tablet-based news that are all electronic - a digital screen that will roll up, fit in your pocket, where the resolution will be almost as good as the printed paper.

Brent Hoberman is chief executive of lastminute.com

Most persistent spam emailer? The spam ones I filter off. Time spent on web? Practically all day. Web and email basically. Next boo.com/clickmango? I couldn't possibly name one. But I guess it would be a site that is approaching too narrow a market, whose business isn't using the power of the internet enough and who has strong competitors already established in its space. Least useful site/s on web? I'd say probably some of those offline retailers - the bricks and mortars guys - that just put up a catalogue. They're just wasting an opportunity. Least user-friendly sites? A lot of those personal finance sites are over complicated and you need to fill in endless pages of forms before you can start using the site properly. I would rather see them get little bits of personalisation at each stage. What screensaver do you use? I've got a second-hand computer from a Cape Town colleague with a picture of Table Mountain on it. Since I'm from there as well, I kept it. Most irritating thing about the web? People who can't see how much the internet has improved over the past few years and then how much it's going to improve dramatically over the next few years. Do you bother with old media? Yes, but less and less. I think newspapers will still be useful until we get amazing screens and tablet-based news that are all electronic - a digital screen that will roll up, fit in your pocket, where the resolution will be almost as good as the printed paper. Brent Hoberman is chief executive of lastminute.com

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: With the RIP Act looming, companies are starting to crack the whip. Orange, one-time embodiment of cool, has caught the bug and fired 45 employees for peeking at naughty pictures disseminated via the internet. Rumour has it that the porn wasn't even that bad and employees merely forwarded it via email as a joke, which would seem a trifle strident. But if you didn't know this you would be forgiven for thinking that Orange had purged itself of an evil porn ring. The one thing that Orange should know is the internet was built by techies for the purpose of disseminating porn, and that hidden behind every typo is a porn site. Fans of our very own "Ask" Jack Schofield would, for this very reason, be well advised not to follow up his recommendation to visit www.98lite.com (it should have been .net) to download, ahem, fast software. You have been warned, and yes, your boss is watching.
fields.body:
With the RIP Act looming, companies are starting to crack the whip. Orange, one-time embodiment of cool, has caught the bug and fired 45 employees for peeking at naughty pictures disseminated via the internet. Rumour has it that the porn wasn't even that bad and employees merely forwarded it via email as a joke, which would seem a trifle strident. But if you didn't know this you would be forgiven for thinking that Orange had purged itself of an evil porn ring. The one thing that Orange should know is the internet was built by techies for the purpose of disseminating porn, and that hidden behind every typo is a porn site. Fans of our very own "Ask" Jack Schofield would, for this very reason, be well advised not to follow up his recommendation to visit www.98lite.com (it should have been .net) to download, ahem, fast software. You have been warned, and yes, your boss is watching.

If you think Orange has been strict, spare a thought for the hapless employees of beleaguered sports website Worldsport. As D-Day looms, more juicy details of its internal politics are starting to emerge. Carnivores beware, meat or fish is not welcome AT ALL, and those caught sneaking in the odd saveloy or fishpaste sandwich have been severely admonished for breach of contract (I kid you not, it's in writing). The latest rumour is that, should a rescue package materialise this month, the Inland Revenue is among the growing list of creditors hoping to receive money for non payment of PAYE since February. The taxman should be the least of their worries though.

Fashionmall.com, the clever cookie that bought the boo.com brand, is in grave danger of falling foul of those scrupulous data protection people. First for using boo.com's old email database for mail outs; second for data gathering on the holding page and failing to let people know what they plan to do with the data; and lastly, for failing to include an opt-out box where people can avoid being spammed. Could it be Fashionmall's attempt at relaunching the ill-fated boo.com is doomed before it even gets off the ground? Perhaps it's the brand that's jinxed. Unfortunately, we're going to have to wait until the autumn to find out.

With most British media outlets now avoiding Mohamed Al Fayed like the plague, it was only a matter of time before he found his voice on the internet. Joy. Shy, retiring Al Fayed has added AlFayed.com to his expanding portfolio. It's up to you whether you want to bloat his ego by boosting site traffic, but his slant on conspiracy theories and the gratuitous pictures of Diana, People's Princess, are inspired. The catalogue of conspiracy, read by the very impartial Michael Cole, is worth a listen - if only to hear what the Duke of Edinburgh called Dodi. But be warned, it does drag on, and even the most hardened conspiracy theorist would have trouble making it past number nine (from a total of 21).

fields.headline: The best proposal scene
fields.standfirst: The Luzhin defence
fields.trailText: The Luzhin defence
fields.body:
The Italian Lakes. Natalia (Emily Watson) is in the middle of a game of tennis when eccentric chess grandmaster Luzhin (John Turturro), whom she briefly met the previous day, runs up to the court. Clinging to the wire fence surrounding it, he bellows at her.

"Hello!"

Distracted, Natalia misses her shot. She walks across the court toward Luzhin, smiling politely.

"Hello."

She returns to her game. Luzhin walks around the court, still holding on to the wire.

"I want you to be my wife."

Again, Natalia misses her shot; the ball flies past her ear.

"I implore you to agree," Luzhin goes on. "Then everything will be different, and wonderful. Everything will change."

Natalia comes over, standing opposite Luzhin with the fence between them. He continues.

"You see, the first time when you spoke, your voice, my life... I'd been waiting to hear..."

He starts to cry. Natalia glances around, faintly embarrassed.

"Please. Please compose yourself."

He blows his nose.

"Do you not think before proposing marriage you should at least ask me my name?"

"What is it?"

"Natalia."

"I'm Alexander Ivanovich Luzhin."

Natalia's tennis partner calls for her.

"I have to finish my game."

The pair burst out laughing.

"I can only promise you that, in keeping with the speed of events, I shall try and give you an answer soon."

See also: Seven Chances, Duck Soup, Dazed and Confused, Some Like It Hot

Don't see also: Forrest Gump

Pointless trivia: Emily Watson is an Arsenal supporter.
